name: 60-Credit Research Project for Occasional Students
description: Students will undertake a major research project in an area of their choice.  The research topic is determined by consultation with academic members of staff.  For the duration of their stay in Birmingham, students join the research group of their project supervisor to undertake the project work.  The results of their work are communicated using a written dissertation and an oral presentation; students are also required to attend an interview (viva voce) with their assessors.  Students will also attend a series of workshops on project skills (covering aspects such as literature searching, referencing etc.) for training in these areas.

name: Academic Communication Skills for Biosciences
description: The module aims to develop communication skills that are necessary for effective academic interaction within Biosciences. All key language areas will be covered with a focus on academic writing and communication. The module will build student confidence to integrate with the academic community and participate effectively with the subject area.

name: Academic English for Financial Technology
description: These courses are aimed at PG international students who speak English as an additional language. The course will be taught in a mixed cohort context that consists of stand-alone lecture style sessions for small to medium-sized groups alongside workshops for smaller groups designed to facilitate speaking and communication skills in an academic environment. The overarching aim of the courses are to help students to improve their academic English communication skills, the critical use of academic literature and the planning, structuring and drafting of longer assignment style written texts. Sessions will be developed to include activities and options that are relevant for the programme that students are studying on: tailor made.

name: Academic Language and Learning for Bilingualism
description: Acad Lang &Learn for Biling LM

name: Accounting and Finance
description: All managers, whatever their specialisation have to interpret and apply financial information in their decision making. This requirement does not mean that all managers have to become accountants, but it does mean that managers have to understand the vernacular of accounting and financial management. Managers cannot discuss the cost and finance implications of activity without an appreciation of the processes, information sources, and methods of presentation of financial information. Managers cannot direct accountants unless they know what to ask for.\n\nIn essence, the module aims to give students an appreciation of the perspective and tools available to accounting and finance professionals, and perhaps most importantly the limitations and caveats to the financial information that they can provide.

name: Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning
description: Accredit Prior Exper Learn LM

name: Adult Learning Theory and its Application to Multidisciplinary Healthcare Simulation.
description:
This module covers the underlying principles of adult learning and their applicability to use in multidisciplinary healthcare simulation. Teaching for this module takes place over a period of 5 days and is provided in two blocks; an initial block of teaching over a period of 3 days, followed by a block of teaching over 2 days. A 4 week break between blocks of teaching has been scheduled to allow students time for reflection and preparation for the assessed oral presentations on day 5 of the module.

The module will be offered to students as either CPD or as an accredited module. The students undertaking the accreditation will be registered with the UoB. To be awarded module credits, students undertaking the accredited module will be required to successfully complete an oral presentation and evidence based written assignment.

Academics within the School of Health and Population Sciences at the UoB will provide academic oversight and teaching support to include quality assurance of course content and second marking of assignments. As such, this module is owned by UoB.

name: Advanced Language Training
description: This is an optional 20 credit module in the PGCARMS.  It will provide UoB postgraduate researchers with opportunity to accredit advanced language training completed alongside their PhD studies.  This training will often be provided by external organisations. \n\nThe advanced language will consist of 200 hours learning through a combination of contact hours (e.g. seminars) and independent study.

name: Advanced Research Training in Econometrics
description: The objective of the course will be to provide a thorough grounding in techniques of advanced empirical econometric analysis.  Starting with the general linear regression model and extensions such as restricted least squares and generalized least squares, which will largely be taken to be known, the course will develop themes such as maximum likelihood methods, testing principles based on maximum likelihood methods, and simultaneous equation models.  The course will also consider recent techniques in modelling with non-stationary data, including testing for unit roots, and Johansen tests for cointegration (including determining cointegrating rank, identifying the cointegrating space and determining the cointegrating vectors.)  We shall also consider models of panel data and their uses and the analysis of limited dependent variable models.It will be an important part of the course to illustrate matters using numerous examples of econometrics in practice. Class exercises will be provided which will focus on the use of various techniques and routines within commonly available software such as E-Views and Stata to develop empirical models which will be of use to the students' future research. These exercises will aim to complement the more formal teaching delivered as part of the lectures and will be an important part of the training.

name: Advanced Research Training in Macroeconomics
description: The aim of the course is to give students intending to pursue PhD level research in macroeconomics a good foundation in the relevant literature and introduce them to the relevant techniques and models. Whilst the exact content of the course may vary from year to year depending on the interests of both the students and the lecturer topics are likely to  include evidence on money and output; price rigidity and inter-temporal optimisation; the New Keynesian Phillips curve; time-consistency issues; fiscal policy; financial Intermediation and macroeconomic analysis; policy analysis in the new Keynesian model.

name: Advanced Research Training in Microeconomics
description: This module provides a rigorous course in advanced microeconomics. Whilst the exact content of the course may vary from year to year depending on the interests of both the students and the lecturer topics are likely to  include individual and social preferences and choice; choice under uncertainty; games of complete information; games of incomplete information; signalling, communication and mechanism design; voting and theory of implementation; theory of bargaining; learning, evolution and theory of behavioural economics.

name: Advanced Research and Evaluation Methods
description: Topics covered re writing a ForenPsyD thesis 1.\tPlanning research 2.\tQualitative approaches and small samples 3.\tStatistical power analysis in research 4.\tDirect observation of behaviour 5.\tQuantitative analysis of behaviour 6.\tSequential analysis 7.\tStatistical risk measurement: logistic regression, odds ratios. 8.\tStatistical profiling and Facet Theory 9.\tTypologies and Cluster analysis 10.\tTime series analysis and Survival Analysis 11.\tQuestionnaire Design and Loglinear Analysis 12. Path Analysis, Bayesian Probabilities and Multi-dimensional Scaling.

name: Advanced Spanish Translation for Erasmus Students (Semester 2)
Advanced Statistical Methods
description: This module will build on student's learning about statistical principles and methods gained in previous modules.  Through the use of data sets, students will have the opportunity to develop their knowledge and skills of data methods related to analysis of individual epidemiological studies.

name: Advanced Strategy
description: Advanced Strategy takes an in-depth view of the process of strategy formulation and implementation through the lens of key themes/topics pertinent to the contemporary strategists.\nUsing a combination of cases of (un)successful firms, some readings and, most importantly, lively discussion, this module will explore the ways in which long term advantage is built and continuously influenced by contextual issues at firm and industry levels. Students will focus particularly on how the thinking, actions and capabilities of the strategist develops in this process; the mind-set needed to build and sustain competitive advantage over time, and on the strategic implications of understanding what defines firm's success.

name: Anaesthesia and Body Systems
description: The module covers:the anatomy of the heart and circulatory system, cardiovascular physiology (including changes in pregnancy) cardiovascular pharmacology and cardiac problems including arrhythmias, low cardiac output and heart failure. Students will be introduced to the principles of ECG, CVP, PCWP and CO monitoring, the associated skills and their role in the maintenance of patient safety during anaesthesiathe anatomy of the respiratory tract and lungs and the physiology of the respiratory system and the principles underpinning spirometry and the monitoring of blood gasses. It will also cover common respiratory conditions including asthma, COPD and pneumonia and their pharmacological treatment. Skills covered will include chest examination and the interpretation of common breath sounds and the management of the difficult airwaythe anatomy and physiology of the kidneys, liver and endocrine organs, the physiology of blood clotting and the prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis. It will also cover the management of anaesthesia in the pregnant patient, the patient with diabetes, renal failure or liver failure. Pharmacology will include the use of diuretics and anticoagulants. Students will learn the principles and practice of ordering and interpretation of common blood tests and the management of blood loss and coagulopathiesthe anatomy and physiology of the brain and nervous system and the physiology of the neuromuscular junction and pain. The module has a major focus on pharmacology, covering in depth the pharmacology of general, local and regional anaesthesia and neuromuscular blockade and the principles and practice of pain management. Skills include more advanced monitoring and the management of regional and local blocks.

name: Anaesthesia in Clinical Practice
description: The module focuses on the application of knowledge and skills within complex and individuated situations relying on in depth understanding, synthesis and application and the important place of judgement in situations of uncertainty.With regard to the pre-operative period, it covers the process of eliciting a patient history and undertaking a physical examination; the explanation of procedures and the law on obtaining consent and includes advanced communication skills. Students will learn about the importance of including co-existing conditions and familial conditions in history taking and the how these are taken into account in managing anaesthesia.With regard to practice in the operating department, students learn about the management of common emergencies, including anaphylaxis, blood loss, laryngospasm, regurgitation, inability to intubate / ventilate, as well as about longer term management in high dependency / intensive care units.The module also brings into focus the broader context of professional working in the NHS. It covers the principles and practice of evidence-based medicine and the process of clinical audit, the role of professional bodies and the structure and organisation of the NHS. It also looks at coping with difficult patients and difficult colleagues and at complaints procedures and covers advanced communication skills and the skills required for teaching others.

name: Anticoagulation Management
description:
The module aims to provide a reproducible educational framework for clinicians involved in anticoagulation management.  
The course will produce a critical awareness of new insights into the area of anticoagulation management and provide advanced knowledge and skills to enable autonomous practice in dealing with more complex problems. Attention will be focused on developing the ability to critically evaluate current research in the field of anticoagulation management. Achievement of this will allow students to continue to advance their knowledge and understanding.

The module will comprise:
	
1. Pre-course reading material containing self-assessment material at the conclusion of each chapter. This will provide the theoretical background to the subject and help the student to provide a critical appreciation of areas discussed within the taught course. Students will be asked to provide evidence of current literature review when responding to the self assessment exercises.
 
2. Three days contact time involving:
a) Lectures from specialists in the field who will discuss the key theoretical and clinical aspects of anticoagulation management.
b) Group work where students will contribute to discussion, analysis and application of the theoretical perspectives that underpin practice. 
c) Practical workshops provide practical experience for the students, an opportunity to develop protocols and to reflect on requirements for auditing the process.
d) A theory exam, 35 item MCQ paper 
e) Practical assessment will be undertaken using clinical scenarios centred on anticoagulation management. The students will be expected to demonstrate a clear understanding of the clinical issues,  participate in decision making and problem solving practice which will include examples of tackling and solving complex problems 

3. Completion of competencies and further assessment in the students place of work using a clinical supervision system.

4. Course work, written evidence based case study

name: Application of sports science to golf coaching
Applications of Brain Imaging in Cognitive Neuroscience
Applied Golf Coaching and Coach Development
description: Developing the work of Year One and Year Two this module will enable students to further their knowledge and understanding of coaching golf.  Students will learn how to provide detailed analysis of the golf swing and how to correct swing faults. They will be introduced to reflective practice and self-development strategies that can be effectively used within their coaching environment. Students will learn how to apply the Laws, Principles and Preferences model to a range of shots that players of varying degrees of ability may need to execute on the golf course. These include shots from awkward lies and specialist shots requiring players to manoeuvre the ball around objects. They will also learn how to build effective on-course lesson frameworks.A key element of successful coaching is developing a relationship with a player and recognising their limitations Students will learn how to develop successful coach/athlete relationships.

name: Applied Science of Anaesthesia
description: The module provides students with a comprehensive introduction to physics as it relates to anaesthesia and the operating department. This includes the physics of gases and vapours and the principles of pressure and flow. It also includes electricity and electrical safety. Linked to the physics of anaesthesia, students learn about clinical measurement and relevant statistics. Skills development includes basic respiratory function testing.The second part of the module covers the development of the anaesthetic machine and the general scientific principles underpinning the current technology. This includes the physical properties, chemistry and pharmacology of anaesthetic gasses, principles of breathing systems and mechanical ventilation, ECG, NIBP, SPO2, capnography, ventilatory volumes, temperature measurement and depth of anaesthesia. Skills covered include pre anaesthetic checks; setting up basic monitoring and IPPV; suction.

name: Applied Sports Science
description: Developed as a follow on to the 'Introduction to Applied Sports Science and Junior Development' module in Year 1, this module continues to develop the role of sports science within a coaching setting through the integration of theory and application. Students will identify key motor control theories and apply them to coaching situations, and discuss physiological, psychological and nutritional concepts related to improved golf performance. Psychological components of coaching skills to create a self-determining environment will be analysed and reflected upon and the use of basic mental skills will be introduced. Students will be encouraged to take opportunities to apply each area of study to their own coaching and job role with a specific focus towards recreational club golfers.

name: Assessment Issues (Offenders and Victims)
description: Introduction to module/Assessment of general offendingAssessment of family violenceAssessment of violence riskAssessment of sexual violencePolitically motivated offending, needs assessmentAssessments in childcare proceedingsAssessment of non-abusing partners, families, childrenAssessment of adolescent offendersAssessment of life sentenced prisonersIntroduction to post-traumatic stress disorder

name: Assessment and Intervention
description: This module examines how contemporary theories of cognitive development and learning inform psychological assessment and intervention.  The review of assessment practice includes consideration of attainment and ability testing as well as dynamic assessment.  Students are introduced to theoretical constructs which underpin the British Psychological Society's Certificate of Competence in Educational Testing (Level A).  Evidence-based intervention methods are introduced which address pedagogy and the mediation of learning, specialist interventions and the role of motivation and learning style in promoting effective learning.\nIn addition, the module reviews and builds upon the theoretical and research-based knowledge which students will bring from their undergraduate studies of lifespan developmental psychology, giving particular attention to processes of social and emotional development, and paradigms through which difficulties in development may best be understood and addressed.  Constructs of 'Mental Health' and disorders, and 'Emotional, Social and Behavioural Difficulties' are introduced within an over-arching ecological-transactional model.  Placement activity requires students to conduct ecologically-based analyses of children's social, emotional and behaioural development, within families, and early years and school settings, and to utilise assessment data to identify intervention goals and inform selection of methods of intervention.

name: Atlantic Slavery: West Africa and the Caribbean
Atrial Fibrillation Management and Stroke Prevention
description: The module will provide theoretical and practical knowledge of the condition of Atrial Fibrillation and anticoagulation management. The students will acquire a detailed understanding of the pathophysiology, aetiology and epidemiology of Atrial Fibrillation. The diagnosis will be examined, the treatment both medical and surgical will be explained as well as the evidence based management including anticoagulation for stroke prevention. In addition, students will gain experience in diagnosis, treatment and management applying knowledge gained within specialist clinics.

name: Audio-Visual Dissertation (M.A.)
description: The audio-visual dissertation is the culmination of the M.A. programme in Film and Television: Research and Production, combining academic research and analysis with presentation in an audio-visual format. Students are expected to show both academic and technical expertise in the audio-visual documentary and to support this with a defence of research, development, and technique.

name: BICN-Fundamentals in Brain Imaging Methods
description: Lectures will cover the main techniques of brain mapping using MRI with emphasis on functional MRI.  Topics will also include the physics of NMR and MRI, introduction to fMRI experimental design and analysis.  Students will have computer-based training in analysis of brain images, including processing of basic fMRI studies.

name: Basic Life Support
description:
The lectures provide theoretical background and an understanding of contexts within which basic life support might be required. The skills sessions use mannequins on which student develop their life support skills. There is a requirement from the General Pharmaceutical Council that pharmacy students are able to respond appropriately to medical emergencies including the provision of first aid, and an expectation from the general public that all healthcare students working in clinical areas will have the skill to act appropriately with the medical team in resuscitation procedures. Providing training early in the programme is an important signifier of pharmacy student professional responsibility and enhances their confidence in early clinical experience and provides early contact with fellow student healthcare professionals.
The rationale for non-modular status:
a) The size of the component is too small to meet University requirements.
b) Judgement made is on a simple pass-fail basis rather than being graded. Each student's practical skills are assessed according to objective criteria.
This does not fit with the general pattern of academic assessment.

name: Bioreaction Engineering
description: The module deals with the engineering fundamentals of the design and analysis of bioreactors; of the development of scientific background, which can be used to select and design bioreactors to have the specifications required for optimum performance. The module starts with lectures on (i) enzymes, and enzyme catalysis, (ii) enzymatic kinetics, (iii) immobilisation of enzymes, (iv) fermentation and cell growth kinetics, (v) transport phenomena in bioreaction systems.  Sections (i) to (v) provide enough background to the main section of the course, which is (vi) design and analysis of batch and continuous stirred tank bioreactors. This part is then followed by (vii) bioprocess control, (viii) mixing in bioprocesses, (ix) shear effects in bioprocess systems, and (x) non-ideal flow in bioreactors.  Hence sections (vii) - (x) address the major engineering issues that are specific to biochemical reaction systems.

name: Bioscience for Engineers
description: The module covers the basics of bioscience that are required by engineers to work at the engineering – life science interface. Molecules of life - Structure and function of lipids, carbohydrates, proteins and nucleic acids; Cellular structure - Structure and function of components within eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells; Cellular function and activity - Cellular thermodynamics & respiration; Gene expression: Transcription, translation, control of gene expression; DNA organisation & replication, cell cycle, meiosis, mitosis; Cellular signalling and control; Cellular organisation in to tissues and organs, introduction to Anatomy and physiology; Biological systems in engineering – prokaryotic and eukaryotic bioprocesses; Practical skills for microbiology - Aseptic technique.

name: Bioscience for Graduates from Other Scientific Disciplines
Bioseparations
description:
The following topics are covered in the module:
General downstream processing, Recombinant protein hosts, Cell disruption strategies, Aggregation, Fractional precipitation, Centrifugation and centrifuges, Conventional filtration, Membrane separations. 
Introduction to process chromatography.
Principles and theories of chromatography, Chromatography: adsorption & adsorption models; resolution & zone broadening; three phase strategies & linking steps; process development; development of media; scale-up & optimisation.
Alternatives to chromatography including Expanded bed adsorption & Magnetic separations.

name: Business and Pharmaceutical Enterprise
description: This module in intended to introduce students to the key concepts of business planning and enterprise in pharmacy, as well as key concepts in leadership. They will learn the process and pitfalls of planning a new business proposal.Regardless of the sector pharmacists work within, business, entrepreneurial and leadership skills are important. An understanding of these concepts is crucial to their future employability within the sector.  Students with the support of various case studies and suggestions of business ideas will be encouraged to create their own idea of a business case and use the knowledge gained to develop their approach and plan. Students will learn the key concepts of business plans, how to approach them, discuss case studies and learn of previous proposals.The role of leadership in business will also be highlighted, and various models of leadership will be taught. Students will work from various pharmacy related case studies, in order to inform the development of their own business plan. The students will be able to select or develop their own business idea to investigate and develop a business plan of their choosing which can be based on placements they have engaged in. There will be an introduction to the business plan headings and an introduction to the thematic approach of creativity in generating solutions. There will be case studies for students to explore and evaluate as self-directed learning activities, to develop their independent learning skills and they can gain immediate feedback with discuss in their groups. The students will be given opportunities to discuss their roles within groups and work through creative exercises. Formatively the students will be assessed by pitching / presenting their business plans. The student summative assessment will be a written report on their business plan, which explores their learning and linkage to Pharmacy, and a personal critique and reflection on a published model of leadership.

name: Business and Society
description: This module examines the relationship between business and society through a variety of conceptual lenses and frameworks in order to inform the development of policies, strategies and practices that help managers in contemporary organisations manage their relationships with society and the natural environment. These multiple analytical lenses will give students a toolkit to critically appraise organisational challenges in respect of ethics, responsibility, justice and values. Through the use of case studies, videos and role-plays the student will better understand contemporary ethical dilemmas faced by organisations as well as the processes that enlightened organisations have developed to manage such dilemmas.

name: Byzantine Archaeology and Material Culture
description: This course offers a framework, partly empirical, partly conceptual, whereby to engage with the problems of investigating and interpreting Late Roman and Byzantine archaeology.  It introduces all the major types of evidence (artefactual, topographical, monumnetal, environmental), deploying them to test reassessments of major debates in Late Roman and Byzantine Studies.  Tutorial reading develop introduction to archaeology as an intellectual practice within Late Roman and Byzantine historical enquiry, focusing upon archaeology's developing contributions to economic, cultural and politico-administrative history, adn evaluation of best practice in excavation, survey, recording and publication.

name: CBT for Anxiety Disorders
description: This module aims to develop skills in CBT for depression to an advanced level, improving proficiency in the fundamental techniques of CBT and developing competency in the specialist techniques used in the treatment of depression.Specific cognitive and behavioural models of depression, empirical evidence, and assessment and specialist cognitive and behavioural treatment strategies will be covered in workshops.The clinical workshops will provide students with a strong foundation in the evidence base for CBT with depression, and address the most up-to-date research methods.

name: CBT for Depression
description: This module aims to develop skills in CBT for depression to an advanced level, improving proficiency in the fundamental techniques of CBT and developing competency in the specialist techniques used in the treatment of depression. Specific cognitive and behavioural models of depression, empirical evidence, and assessment and specialist cognitive and behavioural treatment strategies will be covered in workshops.  The clinical workshops will provide students with a strong foundation in the evidence base for CBT with depression, and address the most up-to-date research methods.

name: Cancer Immunology and Immunotherapy
description:
Cancer immunotherapy approaches are starting to transform the way we treat cancer, based on an exploitation of our understanding of cancer immunology, with remarkable effects in clinical trials, even in late stage disease. An overall grasp of this area is essential for students wishing to work in the context of clinical or biological research in cancer.

This postgraduate level module will provide the students with an understanding of cancer immunology, giving an overview of the components of the immune system, including a significant focus on the mechanisms by which they function in immunity.

The module will cover the evidence that the immune system can mount potent and potentially curative responses against cancer, including data from clinical studies in humans, and from animal models. It will outline the key challenges that immunotherapy strategies have to overcome, such as immunological tolerance, and immune evasion and immunosuppression mediated by the tumour. The module will outline to students the range and different classes of antigenic targets that are currently a focus of immunotherapy, explaining advantages/disadvantages in relation to factors such as tumour selectivity, applicability to different tumours, and functional role in the tumour. This will include outlining the potential for next generation immunotherapy approaches to target personalised combinations of antigens. The module will also provide an overview of the tissue context in which cancer immunotherapy takes place, and the challenges that the tumour microenvironment presents (eg in terms of accessibility and immunosuppressive effects), but also the opportunities (eg specific antigenic targets). Finally, drawing on specific examples, the module will outline a range of current immunotherapy approaches, focusing on their scientific basis and clinical mode of action. A brief overview of clinical trial pathways and how they apply to immunotherapy modalities will be provided. Immunotherapeutic strategies covered will include antibody therapies, checkpoint blockade strategies, T cell /chimeric antigen receptor adoptive therapy, and cancer vaccines. The material will focus on their advantages/disadvantages, current clinical significance, and potential future development, touching on issues such as positive/negative predictive biomarkers determining treatment success/failure, and scope for personalisation.

Students will be sent a direct reading list one month in advance of the module. Teaching will largely be provided in a concentrated block, which will involve predominantly speakers from within the University, but may include experts from across the country, including from the academic and industry sectors. This will be followed by a period of self-directed study, during which students will prepare a presentation to peers and academics and a written assignment integrating taught material with information from current research papers.

name: Cardiovascular & Respiratory Systems
description: None

name: Cardiovascular Biology
description:
The aim of this module is to ensure that all students on the programme have a firm understanding/awareness of current research issues in cardiovascular sciences and to introduce the students to the topics that will be offered for the research component of the programme. This module will use a selection of lectures from the 3rd year BMedSc modules: "Vascular Biology and Pathology", "Cardiovascular Sciences – Cellular Mechanisms" and "Cardiovascular Science – Integrative mechanisms", which are chosen to provide an introduction to, or refresh the students' knowledge of core Cardiovascular topics (a list of the likely topics to be covered is included at the end of this form).

Following these lectures, students will undertake a period of self-directed learning to expand their understanding of each topic. They will reinforce this by presenting their findings in small group sessions via a variety of methods (eg, a short report, leading a journal club on a particular paper,  or giving a presentation on a selected topic using research sources, etc.).

The SDL component will be developed in a progressive way during the module to ensure that students are proficient in selecting and critiquing the published literature. For example, in the initial stages students will be given the appropriate material for the SDLs and as the module progresses there will be a shift towards the students researching and selecting their own resources. Each student's attendance and presentation of their findings at the small group sessions will form the formative and summative in course assessments for the module.

Towards the end of the module there will be a series of short presentations/discussion sessions from academic staff who will be offering research projects on the programme.

name: Care of the Critically Ill Adults
Case Studies in Chemistry
description: The primary objective of this module is to expose students to an area of chemistry of topical interest.  Thus, students will select a chemical topic from the list available, and research the topic using suitable texts, the internet and other reference sources.  The research findings are to be presented using a written report and an oral presentation, both of which are to be fully word-processed.  The topics available for selection have been carefully chosen to consolidate the material presented in the previous chemistry modules.  The module also allows development of key skills, e.g. communication skills (written and oral), research and analysis skills, student-centred learning etc.

name: Case Study Methods
description: LM Case Study Methods (1st year trainees only)1.Revision of basic statistics: probability and hypothesis testing, descriptive and non-\tparametric statistics. 2.Observing behaviour, measuring behaviour and social interaction analysis.3.Increasing behaviour, decreasing behaviour and contingency management.4.Measurement of cognitive and behaviour change and the use of psychometric tools for assessment and evaluation.5.Case study planning, design, analysis and presentation.6. Critical analysis/appraisal of background articles.

name: Cell Factories
description:
This module allows students to understand the principles of the large scale industrial production of a range of molecules, both pharmaceuticals and chemicals, by fermentation and cell culture. The module comprises one week of seminars, tutorials and practical classes and one week in the pilot plant. 

Material covered will include: choice of production system based on product (bacterial, yeast, eukaryotic cell); benefits and weaknesses of each system; the way in which each system can be used industrially at a variety of scales; and analytical techniques for monitoring upstream bioprocesses. 

The enquiry-based learning module design will allow students to construct their own learning path through the module material and complete a portfolio of coursework that will be assessed to determine whether learning outcomes have been met.

name: Cells and Cancer (Integrated Case Based Learning 1)
Cellular Biochemistry and Biology
description: The aim of this module is to provide a basic understanding of protein biochemistry and build from this to provide an overview of the key processes in cell biology.  Description of the fundamental elements of protein structure and function will be taught alongside the  relevant chemical and physical science principles to provide a context for understanding the basic quantitative elements of biochemistry and an appreciation of how proteins are studied and the applications for proteins in biomedicine.  This will provide the student with sufficient background to understand the second phase of the module, where the fundamental elements of the cell will be discussed, including cell structure, motility, adhesion, signalling, proliferation, trafficking and regulation.

name: Cellular and Molecular Basis of Cancer
Chemical Contamination of Food and Water
Chemical Engineering Design and Professional Skills A
Citizenship, Human Rights and the Environment
description: The module examines issues of social justice in education and has been designed for those with an interest in or responsibility for curriculum development or equal opportunities.  Human rights texts are international and the module will explore how these can be used as a basis for developing policy in schools which are working in a context of linguistic, cultural, religious and ethnic diversity.  The module will examine the contribution of citizenship and environmental education across the curriculum and their contribution to social and political education.

name: Civil Engineering Research Project
description: The module aims to develop skills associated the ability to discover and learn the fundamental elements of a subject independently, to gather, organise and distil information from various sources, to summarise the information succinctly, to draw general conclusions from fragmentary or possibly conflicting data and to present the essential features and the conclusions clearly and coherently.  This module requires the student to investigate a topic in Civil Engineering, broad or specific in nature, to search for and accumulate relevant documents and information from other sources and to present in a formal technical report format.

name: Clinical Core Practice (Medical Studies)
description:
Students will undertake the learning and the required assessment for the module as part of the MBChB. The following description is taken from the standard Clinical Core 2 specification:
This module combines and integrates the students' first hospital experience with continuing experience in community based and the clinical science teaching which supports them both. The module builds on the foundation provided by the mainly theoretical learning during the first two years and on their initial clinical experience in primary care The module itself provides a foundation for the more specialist clinical experience during subsequent years.
Students have two hospital placements (25 weeks in all) – one in each semester and there is a Head of Academy who oversees the provision of experience in each hospital. For each placement, students are assigned to a combined medical / surgical teaching firm which provides supervision and formal / informal small group teaching. However, independent learning is vital in the hospital setting in which learning is often determined by the particular patients and problems present, rather than by a set timetable. Through their independent interaction with patients, students gain confidence and competence in communication and physical examination. They learn about the common problems presenting to doctors in medicine and surgery and the ways in in which they are managed. They also develop some understanding of the thinking processes that underlie diagnosis and the way in which management decisions are made and start to develop the skills in these areas that they require.
In doing this they are utilising, applying and building on the knowledge of clinical sciences delivered in large part through a series of lectures in blocks in the Medical School introducing them to the fundamentals of pathology, clinical chemistry, haematology, infection and immunity.
In their community-based medicine (CBM) placement, students continue to observe and participate in GP consultations, but also take on a 'study caseload' in which they have regular contact through the year with a number of patients in different categories (e.g. a woman at the end of pregnancy; a baby; someone with a chronic condition). The CBM experience in relation to patients with chronic and acute conditions links with hospital experience and helps students to retain a more rounded view of the patient journey.

name: Clinical Core Skills Refresher Course -  MBChB Year 5/GEC4
description:
This module builds and reinforces the general clinical experience that the student will already have gained in the Clinical Core 4 module.

A main aim of the module is to ensure students are fully prepared and able to successfully progress into the next stage of teaching or to become 'New Doctors'.

Students have one short term hospital placement and  there will be a Head of Academy and Senior Academy Tutor who oversees the provision of experience at the placement.

Students may also be required to have a community-based medicine placement.

name: Clinical Core Theory (Medical Studies)
description:
Students will undertake the learning and the required assessment for the module as part of the MBChB. The following description is taken from the standard Clinical Core 2 specification:
This module combines and integrates the students' first hospital experience with continuing experience in community based and the clinical science teaching which supports them both. The module builds on the foundation provided by the mainly theoretical learning during the first two years and on their initial clinical experience in primary care The module itself provides a foundation for the more specialist clinical experience during subsequent years.
Students have two hospital placements (25 weeks in all) – one in each semester and there is a Head of Academy who oversees the provision of experience in each hospital. For each placement, students are assigned to a combined medical / surgical teaching firm which provides supervision and formal / informal small group teaching. However, independent learning is vital in the hospital setting in which learning is often determined by the particular patients and problems present, rather than by a set timetable. Through their independent interaction with patients, students gain confidence and competence in communication and physical examination. They learn about the common problems presenting to doctors in medicine and surgery and the ways in in which they are managed. They also develop some understanding of the thinking processes that underlie diagnosis and the way in which management decisions are made and start to develop the skills in these areas that they require.
In doing this they are utilising, applying and building on the knowledge of clinical sciences delivered in large part through a series of lectures in blocks in the Medical School introducing them to the fundamentals of pathology, clinical chemistry, haematology, infection and immunity.
In their community-based medicine (CBM) placement, students continue to observe and participate in GP consultations, but also take on a 'study caseload' in which they have regular contact through the year with a number of patients in different categories (e.g. a woman at the end of pregnancy; a baby; someone with a chronic condition). The CBM experience in relation to patients with chronic and acute conditions links with hospital experience and helps students to retain a more rounded view of the patient journey.

name: Clinical Oncology Dissertation
description: Students will be taught about forming hypothesis and a variety of research methods and then encouraged and supported in developing their first piece of independent research. The students will be expected to carry out their research over 6-12 months within their local workplace, a School of Cancer Sciences Laboratory or a local Hospital. This will be the final module of the programme whereby the students bring together the analysis skills that they learnt during the Epidemiology and Statistics module with presentation, writing and critical thinking skills that they have developed during the programme to present in dissertation format a summary of an independent research project.

name: Clinical Procedural Skills 4
description: This required component ensures that students are taught clinical procedural skills mandated by the GMC in Tomorrow's Doctors 2009, and undertake relevant observed practice.  During year 4 students continue to use the clinical procedural skills passport they were issued in year 3. This allows the students to record the teaching they have had and to record the observed practice they have undertaken.  Observing assessors will only sign the passport if the student performs the procedure to a satisfactory standard. Students are also required to input the data from their passport onto an online database, so that progress can be centrally monitored.  The data held in the database will be reported to the Year 4 Exam board, and students who have not met the requirements, will be required to complete the passport to a satisfactory level before being allowed to proceed to year 5

name: Clinical Procedural Skills Year 3
description:
Simulated Clinical Skills
To help support your theory, knowledge and clinical practice, please see the list of clinical procedural skills    Download the list of clinical procedural skills that you are expected to complete during simulation when attending clinical skills training. Where indicated these simulated clinical skills should be recorded on Pebblepad and must be undertaken prior to observed practice.

Observed Practice Clinical Skills

You are also required to demonstrate the continual use of these skills under direct supervision in clinical practice, which must be documented via PebblePad. The list of clinical procedural skills below are incorporated into your scheduled skills teaching and training sessions from Year 3 to Year 5.    These are the procedural skills that the GMC requires medical students to be competent in at graduation. For more information about the curriculum requirements of the GMC go to  https://www.gmc-uk.org/education/standards-guidance-and-curricula/standards-and-outcomes/outcomes-for-graduates/outcomes-for-graduates---practical-skills-and-procedures (Links to an external site.)  You can be sure that as an FY1 doctor you will have to perform most of these procedures regularly. Therefore, you really should make the most of the opportunities available to you to gain competence and confidence in these skills. Your learning curve as an FY1 will be steep enough, without having to worry unnecessarily about your basic skills.

name: Clinical Procedural Skills Year 5
description:
This module comprises two components.  The first is that students are required to continue to undertake observed practice in procedures they have previously been taught.  Students will undertake these observations while they are on placement during the CC4 module.  The procedures the students should undertake practice in will be outlined in the clinical procedural skills passport.

The second component of the module requires students to attend the medical school.  The students are required to attend the medical school for a day's teaching in those relevant procedures which students are not expected to learn while on placement.  The students are also required to attend the medical school for a half day to be tested in simulation in some of the 'higher risk' procedures contained in the clinical procedural skills passport.

name: Cognitive Behaviour Therapy - Practical Skills
description: This module aims to provide further teaching in the practical application of CBT methods with all varieties of mental health problems, and includes the consolidating of some core methods such as formulation, reviewing automatic thoughts, behavioural experiments, using homework, bibliography and self-help methods.  It also contains coverage of methods that are required when clients are more 'difficult to help', such as working with complex/comorbid presentations, and dealing with 'roadblocks' in therapy.\n

name: Cognitive Behaviour Therapy for Common Mental Health Disorders
description: The aims of this module are for students to build upon basic Cognitive Behaviour Therapy methods and skills acquired in previous modules.  The module includes workshops on the use of CBT with a range of common mental health disorders present in the adult population, including Depression, Specific Phobias, Panic Disorder, Social Anxiety, Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), Obsessional Compulsive Disorder (OCD), Health Anxiety and Generalised Anxiety Disorder (GAD).\n

name: Cognitive Behaviour Therapy for Complex Cases
description: The aims of this module are for students to develop a sound understanding of the use of Cognitive Behaviour Therapy in a range of more complex adult mental health disorders (including suicidal behaviour, child sexual abuse, eating disorders, psychosis, severe depression and anxiety, low self esteem) which often present in complex ways that can present practitioners (and the clients themselves) with a variety of 'blocks to making effective clinical progress'.\n

name: Combined Speciality Case Report
description:
Students will write and submit a case report comprehensively illustrated with clinical images (and radiographs where relevant) for a patient on whom they have performed a course of treatment involving at least two dental specialities.
The chosen case should require significant treatment planning that allows the student to demonstrate advanced diagnostic, patient management and clinical skills. They should be able to demonstrate the ability to reflect with accuracy on all aspects of the case.

In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: Communicable Diseases in International Health
description: This module will involve 75 hours of student study time in total. Using the lectures for information giving and small-group teaching for contextualisation, students will be introduced to the major communicable diseases, such as malaria, HIV, dengue and measles along with their control in relation to international health. \nStudents will identify one particular disease of interest for independent in-depth study which will be assessed by a 15 minute briefing to the group followed by a 5 minute discussion. Individual supervisors will be available for students to provide guidance on topics.\n

name: Community Based Medicine I
description: None

name: Complex Individual Needs
description: This module aims to consider factors involved in low incidence special educational needs and to introduce students to and familiarise them with a range of relevant teaching and assessment procedures.  There is a focus on ensuring students develop skills in applying preventive, developmental and reactive strategies at both systemic and individual levels of intervention.  The module considers comparative models of disability, the rise of inclusion as a guiding principle in educational planning and the role of educational psychologists in relation to assessing and providing for complex individual needs and evaluating the impact of intervention methods designed to promote enhanced development and learning within an inclusive philosophy.

name: Computers and Safety in Critical Systems
description: This course is primarily intended to give an introduction to railway engineers on the issues that must be considered when computers are used in safety-critical or safety-related applications. The course starts with a rapid overview of the context in which computers are used and the contribution of computer based systems to accidents. The emphasis throughout this introduction is on highlighting areas that are of potential concern to safety engineers. This is followed by a more in-depth examination of the software development process, considering especially aspects of requirements specification, design and analysis that are critical to the deployment of computers in safety-critical applications. The course also considers the software safety case and the structuring and collection of evidence for the software safety case. This module is run by the HISE group at the University of York.

name: Construction Management
description: The module has the following components:Project Management deals with: Project management- concept, project team organisation, key principles, in-house or external provision; Setting project objectives, Risk management and allocation; Contract strategy- work packages, payment systems, organisational systems, contractor selection; the role of the New Engineering Contract.Construction and Project Planning uses examples to distinguish between the art of planning and the application of scientific planning techniques.  Planning techniques addressed include: Bar charts; Time location charts; Line of balance charts; Networks (Precedence and Arrows) and Resources; Crashing; Overlapping activities; Updating Networks; Monitoring and reporting progress; Advanced network planning;  and an introduction to the principles of lean planning.Contract Procedures provides an introduction to construction contract documentation and procedures within the UK legal system.  It addresses how recent UK best practice (as encompassed, for example, in the New Engineering Contract 3rd ed) compares and contrasts with conventional contracts (as encompassed in the FIDIC and JCT Conditions of Contract). Specific topics addressed in detail include: Roles of the parties, contract preparation and administration, dealing with change, and resolution of disputes.

name: Consumer and Conductor of Research (Research 1)
description: The abilities to discover, discern, and use research form an important part of developing practice, informing therapeutic approach and effectiveness.  This module highlights the value that systemic psychotherapists can gain from research and is designed to enable trainees as 'consumers', to understand different paradigms for research and the nature of evidence, in establishing practice in systemic psychotherapy, including for example a range of applicable research methodologies, both quantitative and qualitative, and the importance of randomised control trials in developing the evidence base.  The module also creates a context for trainees as 'conductors' of research to develop systematic skills in researching and reviewing literature, to make critical and relevant use of published research relating to understanding family processes, behaviour and communication, and systemic therapeutic processes, including clinical outcome studies. Attention is also given to the ethics of application of evidence.  The module is reflexively related to the concurrent modules: Systemic Clinical Practice Skills 1; and Systemic and Narrative Theory 1, such that all three modules support and 'feed each other' in turn and provide a platform for development in the second year of the course

name: Consumer and Conductor of Research (Research 2)
description: The abilities to identify, evaluate and apply research form an important part of developing practice, informing therapeutic approach and effectiveness.  This module continues to examine a range of applicable research methodologies, both quantitative and qualitative, and highlights the value that systemic psychotherapists can gain from and contribute to research. The module is designed to enable trainees as 'creators' of research to acquire the skills of research design, identifying a suitable topic to apply to their practice, selecting research methodology appropriate to the research enquiry, including formulation of a research proposal.  As 'conductors' of research, the module builds on Research (Level 1) so that trainees can develop skills to become familiar with the process of research through direct experience, carrying out and reporting on a research assignment, including a focus on ethics of research practice.  The module is reflexively related to the concurrent modules: Systemic Clinical Practice Skills 2; and Systemic and Narrative Theory 2, such that all three modules support and 'feed each other' in turn and provide a platform for development beyond the end of the course.

name: Contemporary Dental Practice
description: This module is designed specifically for distance learning by experts in this subject to develop advanced skills in patient assessment and management with regard to dental caries.Students will analyse caries patterns in their own patients and employ advanced strategies in detection and diagnosis and use the latest minimally invasive management techniques.Students will be introduced to new materials and technologies and will develop refined abilities in assessment and evaluation of the potential for introduction into routine practice.  In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: Continuing Development in Clinical Skills
description: This module consists of a series of generic clinical learning outcomes at Level M against which existing modular credits/qualifications held by applicants can be judged in order to award them the appropriate credit.  This enables the student to demonstrate an advanced level of practice within an area integral to their selected programme.

name: Continuing Professional Development and Mentored Practice
description:
Through a Continuing Professional Development framework, this module facilitates the synthesis of the theoretical and practical aspects of a student's development through a period of mentorship within the work based / practice environment and documented with a professional portfolio. Students will have the opportunity to work in a variety of settings to enable development of existing knowledge and skills and advancement of practice. The Practice Mentor will enable a student's development through a partnership of teaching; researching; managing; observing and discussing with innovative practice being encouraged within the framework of safe, legal, and ethical practice as made explicit in any applicable published standards (e.g. professional registration body, specialist competencies etc). 
The student will undertake pre-mentorship preparation through attendance at a half-day study day, and on-line preparatory study. Students will undertake a minimum of 100 hours (150 hours for MSc/ PGDip Advanced Manipulative Physiotherapy due to Professional requirements) of experience in a work based / practice environment. Learning needs may necessitate a range of environments as part of the mentored experience to ensure that all outcomes are achieved e.g. working with different teams, age ranges, gaining experience of musculoskeletal imaging, etc. The selection of the work -based environment is negotiated by the student, dependent upon their individual learning needs and their programme of registration and any specialist requirements. A variety of patterns of delivery of the required hours experience are possible, encompassing part time and full time modes as well as a variety of models of experience.  

In the event of a student negotiating a further period of specialist mentorship beyond the required hours (owing to individual development needs and / or a failed viva) a further fee will be payable to the University to cover mentorship fees.

name: Corporate Finance
description: The Corporate Finance module aims to provide students with an understanding of, and ability to apply the tools and methodologies of contemporary finance theory. The module takes a practical perspective; it is theoretically robust, but rooted in application. The module will build on the introductory Finance and Accounting module to explore the financial decision-making processes of organisations. In so doing the module will look at the role of financial managers and the scope / remit of their decision-making. Financial decision-making takes place against the constraints of the external environment, and so the module will look at these external factors and the impact that they have. Financial decisions are complex, and so the module will explore methods for evaluating and presenting choices in an accessible manner.

name: Corpus Linguistics
description: This module offers advanced studies in a specialist area of Applied English Linguistics: Corpus Linguistics.  A number of issues in corpus linguistics are considered, including the compilation of a corpus; the information to be gained from concordance lines and collocational information, and how this can be interpreted; the implications for theories of language of observations made from a corpus; contrasting approaches to corpora, and the theoretical assumptions behind each; current applications of corpora, mainly language teaching and/or translation, but also stylistics, ideology and forensic linguistics; possible future directions in corpus linguistics.

name: CranioFacial Biology (CFB)
description: This module builds on the systems based modules studied in Year 1. It is an intensive series of lectures, small group sessions, cadaveric laboratory-based teaching, and interactive anatomage sessions totalling 89 hours of contact, leading to an in-depth understanding of the regional anatomy of the head and neck. Acquired knowledge must be to a level that will permit safe progression to clinical and surgical applications after the Easter break.  Students investigate craniofacial anatomy in lectures and in small groups utilising a range of resources.  Resources available relate to real living human anatomy (using modern radiological resources and living models), cadaveric anatomy (using prosected specimens) , bones and anatomical models in the HTA-licensed teaching areas and Barnes library (including plastic anatomical models),   video-based cadaveric dissection (Acland's Anatomy) available online via the e-course and an interactive virtual dissection package (Anatomage) as well as using 'Complete Anatomy' as an interactive platform for projection of virtual human anatomy by electronic means.

name: Crisis Management
description: Successful crisis management aims to minimize the impact of disruptive events that can result in loss of life, equipment, earnings, customers, reputation, market share or other future business prospects.\n\nPreviously, if a crisis arose, it was often assumed to be the result of a single flawed decision, often by one or more blameworthy individuals. In this view a crisis was an aberration, an unfortunate accident—as much a tragedy for the well-meaning and generally competent leaders who made the decision as for its more direct victims. In contrast in this module we consider the entire system analysing, for example, factors that can preceded and influence crisis such as policy changes, regulatory oversight, licensing criteria, financial concerns, environmental change, or organizational culture. Blending theory and practice, students will work in teams, applying course material in the analysis of real-world crisis management challenges.

name: Critical Care in Clinical Practice
description: This module forms part of the second year of the ACCP MSc / PGDip programme and covers the main clinical components of the critical care part of the programme.

name: Critical Care, Torso Trauma & Burns Management
description: This module has been designed to enable students to gain an understanding of evidenced based practice of trauma critical care, the pathogenesis, natural history, assessment and management of the complications that follow and also reconstruction of acute burn injuries and its application to improve the clinical management of thoraco-abdominal, junctional and burns afflicted trauma.

name: Critical Integration in Management
description: The Critical Integration in Management (CIM) module exposes students to general management and leadership challenges, and the application of solutions that apply approaches from all the core modules on the MBA. Real business issues are multifaceted, and so the CIM module shows students how to integrate the core subjects in holistic analysis of business problems.\n\nIn all organisations, the person who has to adopt this general business perspective is the leader … the chief executive. The module will therefore place a heavy emphasis on understanding the role of the chief executive and leadership generally.

name: Current Issues in Health
description: The module aims to examine current issues in health and health care identified by students as meeting their learning needs with regard to current challenges to health, the organisation of health services or in professional practice including, for example: Changes in the health of society, Changes within the NHS; Partnerships in health care; Supporting the evidence base of practice; Developments in professional practice.

name: Delivering Services and Outcomes
description: The aim of this module is to ensure students understand how to operationalize strategy and policy. It will cover the management of people and resources to achieve service outcomes, and will detail the organisational design and development required to achieve this implementation. The module will also cover the allocation of resources, knowledge management and work processes required to deliver effective services.

name: Democracy, Governance and Participation
description: The aim of this module is for students to develop a strong understanding of how the governance and organization of public services is influenced by the nature of the overall governmental system in which they operate, e.g. representative democracy. During this module students will explore new forms of participation and models of government, both traditional and emerging, and the challenges that are changing societies around the world, and how these are influencing the organization and governance of public services. Students will study new forms of participation and citizen engagement, and the comparative effectiveness of these different models.

name: Design Against Failure
description: The module will describe how stresses are used in combination with materials behaviour to prevent failure under both monotonic and cyclic loading.  Failure within the creep regime will not be considered within this module.  An in-depth analysis of the intrinsic (materials) factors and extrinsic (geometrical) factors which can affect failure criteria will be presented.  Micromechanisms of failure and other influence of microstructure will be highlighted.  The units will cover the following:Conventional engineering design, stress systems and assessment methods.Modes of failure: deflection, elastic instability, plastic instability, plastic collapse, fast fracture, fatigue.  Safety factors and strength of materials.  Principle of superposition, principal planes, yield criteria, stress concentrations.  Plasticity - friend or foe?  Fracture mechanics: crack shapes and stress sytems - mode I, mode II, mode III.  Plane stress and plane strain.  Elastic-plastic fracture.Defect tolerance design: S-N curves, notches and pre-cracked testpieces.  Paris equation and its use.Micromechanisms of brittle and ductile fracture.  Transgranular cleavage: the importance of tensile stress and microstructure.  The ductile-brittle transition and ferritic steels.  Ductile failure: void initiation, growth and coalescence.  Ductile crack growth ahead of a sharp-crack: inclusions and carbides, work-hardening.Accelerated mechanisms of crack growth and degradation mechanisms below the creep regime.

name: Design Against Failure II Supplementary
description: This module takes the Structural Integrity approaches outlined in Design Against Failure (1) on further within a risk assessment framework to full scale components and structures (such as gas turbine discs and nuclear pressure vessels).  Theory explained previously is utilised in specific case studies, including: pipe-line flanges (gas and oil); fatigue crack growth and total life (aerospace); and transition behaviour estimation using sparse date (nuclear).

name: Design and Development of Drug Delivery Systems
Development of Psychometric Measures
description: Overview of the Tool:a. The overview should describe the tool itself, the manual and any published research conducted in relation to the tool.b. It may also include background information about the topic, about your stand and about the criteria you will use for evaluation.c. The overview and the introduction work together to provide a comprehensive beginning to your review.d. Consider the following questions: What are the author's basic premises?  What does the assessment attempt to measure? How does it try to measure it?  What is the literature in this area The important points to cover are:1.  You should begin by describing the assessment you have chosen.  2.  Outline the potential uses of the assessment.3.  Discuss possible alternative and supplementary assessments.4.  Evaluate the tool with reference to the literature relevant to the area assessed by the tool, the criteria specified below and other similar psychometric assessments.5.  Discuss problems with and criticisms of with the tool, including limitations.6. Remember to go beyond a basic reiteration of the manual – if someone wanted to read that, they could – you need to give your reader something more. Added value!Begin your critique with an introduction appropriate to the assignment.  Trainees should include a brief summary of the scope, purpose and content of the tool and its potential uses.

name: Discovering Creative Practice A
description: Students on this module will study Film and Creative Writing, their practical and creative dimensions. In the first part of the semester, students will have taught session related to all aspects of film conception and production, including weeks on outlines and synopses, developing a script, writing a screenplay and building a career in film. In the second part of the semester, students will focus on developing writing techniques, with sessions devoted to poetry writing and short fiction. Both halves of the module will draw on the expertise of creative practitioners across the School, and the module will lay a foundation for students wishing to pursue a creative pathway through the English/English with Shakespeare programmes in their second and final years.

name: Dissertation
description: The dissertation is carried out on a full time basis and aims to provide the candidate with first hand exposure to a real industrial or commercial study; it might involve a literature survey, feasibility study or market research, data collection, analysis, costing and recommending solutions to a particular problem, or perhaps some novel research.

name: Dissertation (Contemporary History)
description: A substantial and sustained investigation of an historical problem relating to the modern/contemporary period in the light of current knowledge and current interpretations and of an analysis of the available primary source materials. The findings of this investigation are then presented in an extended form with full argumentationand scholarly apparatus, so that the identity and value of the sources on one hand and the quality and structure of the argument on the other can be clearly understood by the reader.

name: Dissertation (ELAL)
description: In this module the student undertakes a substantial piece of independent research. This may be based on but will extend work undertaken for previous modules in the programme. There is an element of originality in the research and the research may make a contribution to the field of study. The student reports the research in a dissertation of 15,000 words in appropriate academic English. In designing, carrying out and writing up the study, the student is supported by a supervisor.

name: Dissertation (Local Government Studies)
description: This dissertation module forms the key personal research element of the programme, and as such complements and provides the opportunity for putting into practice some of the ideas and methods covered in the other taught modules. Students select their own dissertation topic at an early stage on the course, albeit subject to the approval of the Programme Director, and progress work on it over the period of their registration with one-to-one supervision provided by a dissertation tutor, assigned because of their specialist knowledge of the chosen topic. In addition to one-to-one supervision, students will be required to attend 15 hours of taught provision - focusing on generic skills and techniques for dissertation design, methodology and writing of a dissertation. The dissertation module is to be particularly focused on an aspect of research related to the field of public services and associated management or policy-making. In this way the dissertation aims to provide a learning opportunity for specialism in a distinct field of public policy or public management and to address aspects of the role of research in such a context.

name: Dissertation (MA Shakespeare and Education)
description: The dissertation is an opportunity for a student to extend ideas encountered in the 'Shakespeare and Pedagogy' module.  Thus the dissertation will have a primary focus on methods, materials, or the philosophy/sociology/history of 'teaching Shakespeare'.  It is possible, therefore, that a student (particularly if a practising teacher or lecturer) may be undertaking a practical project and the dissertation will be a report and assessment of the project.

name: Dissertation (MA West Midlands History)
description: A substantial and sustained investigation on an historical problem relating to the history of the West Midlands.  The investigation's findings will be presented in an extended form with full argumentation and scholarly apparatus, allowing the identity and value of the sources and the quality and structure of the argument to be clearly understood by the reader.

name: Dissertation (MSc Anaesthesia Practitioner)
description: This module provides students with an opportunity to use the professional understanding they have developed through practice and through the taught component of the Anaesthesia Practitioner Programme as a foundation for planning and undertaking a major piece of scholarly work (usually but not exclusively a piece of research).  The student is expected to demonstrate novel thinking in an area relevant to Anaesthesia Practitioner practice or to the development of the Anaesthesia Practitioner profession.  Although academic supervision will be provided, the main impetus for the work and the critical thinking with regard to subject, approach and presentation must come from the student.

name: Dissertation (MSc App Met)
description: Dissertation (MSc App Met)

name: Dissertation (Master of Public Health/Health Research Methods)
description: To demonstrate students' applied knowledge and skills in a specific area of public health theory or practice.

name: Dissertation (Shakespeare)
description: In this module the student undertakes a substantial piece of independent research.  This may be based on but will extend work undertaken for previous modules in the programme.  There should be some element of originality in the research and the research may make a contribution to the field of study.  The student reports the research in a dissertation of 12,000 words in appropriate academic English.  In designing, carrying out and writing up the study, the student is supported by a supervisor.

name: Dissertation (Urban and Regional Studies)
description: Dissertation (Urban & Reg St)

name: Dissertation on Criminal Law or Criminal Justice
description: Topics may be chosen from areas covered in the taught modules or, with the agreement of the programme director, a related area.  The topic for the dissertation, which must be in an area of Criminal Law or Criminal Justice, is formulated with the agreement of a member of staff in the School of Law who will act as the student's supervisor and is subject to the formal approval by or on behalf of the programme director.  Students are allowed to write only one such dissertation.

name: Dissertation on a Commercial Law Topic
description: Topics may be chosen from areas covered in the taught modules or, with the agreement of the Course Director, in a related area.  The topic for the dissertation, which must be in an area of commercial law broadly defined, is formulated with the agreement of a member of staff who will act as the student's supervisor and is subject to the formal approval by or on behalf of the Course Director.  Students are allowed to write only one such dissertation.

name: Dissertation on a Legal Topic
description: Topics may be chosen from areas covered in the taught modules or, with the agreement of the Course Director, in a related area.  The topic for the dissertation, which must be in an area of law broadly defined, is formulated with the agreement of a member of staff who will act as the student's supervisor and is subject to the formal approval by or on behalf of the Course Director.  Students are allowed to write only one such Dissertation.

name: Dissertation on an International Commercial Law Topic
description: Topics may be chosen from areas covered in the taught modules or, with the agreement of the Course Director, in a related area.  The topic for the dissertation, which must be in an area of international commercial law broadly defined, is formulated with the agreement of a member of staff who will act as the student's supervisor and is subject to the formal approval by or on behalf of the Course Director.  Students are allowed to write only one such dissertation.

name: Dissertation: MA Soc Res African St
description: LM Diss: MA Soc Res African St

name: Doctorate of Clinical Psychology Year 1 Research Module
Documentary film-making
description: This module is designed to critically acquaint students with the concept of documentary filmmaking, recognisable across histories, genres, nationalities and media.
