Weekly seminars cover a range of styles and tones of documentary filmmaking from early cinema to reality television as students gain a firm theoretical grounding in the debates and controversies surrounding this creative mode. Students are encouraged to interrogate questions of fact, truthfulness, manipulation and entertainment in relation to the films and television programmes they analyse and evaluate. As part of this analysis, they will develop a strong appreciation of the technical complexities of documentary filmmaking, understanding the relationship between intention and form. The module serves as an ideal preparation for those students wishing to embark on the audio-visual dissertation as part of their Masters course.

name: Earth and Environmental Sciences
description: This module will examine the interplay between geology and environments through time to show how they have shaped the world in which we live. A broad range of topics will be covered from the origin and composition of the Earth, to modern environmental change, demonstrating the co-evolution of life and planet Earth. A series of lectures will deliver the fundamentals of Earth processes (such as volcanism, plate tectonics and the evolution of our oceans and atmosphere), while practical classes will introduce investigative earth and environmental skills (such as rock and mineral identification and handling environmental data).

name: Economic Evaluation in Health Care
description: This module is designed to go beyond the first principles of economic evaluation. Its focus will be the development, extension and application of the main issues and techniques fro economic evaluation that were discussed in the introductory module. The material covered by the course includes an in depth coverage of the components of economics evaluations, such as, cost data collection and analysis, outcome data analysis, health state valuation in general and discounting issues. Alternative methods for economic evaluation and the relevant frameworks will be discussed with case studies and policy applications. The module includes a full day's inter-active practical session in which 'hands-on' application and analysis of alternative modelling approaches used in economic evaluation will be demonstrated with full discussion of the advantages and appropriateness of the alternative techniques.

name: Economics and Economic Policy for Business
description: This module will give students an understanding of the economic and the wider political and social context in which business operates. In so doing the module will look at the foundations of contemporary macro and micro economics. The module will develop in students an understanding of the factors which underpin economic analysis, and how economic contexts can vary and evolve over time. The module will also look at the linkages between economic analysis and government policy. A key focus will be the internal economics of the firm, the environment in which firms operate and in turn how these factors can, and should be used to inform management decisions. The module will introduce fundamental concepts and analytical approaches used in economics, and will show how these concepts are applied in business decision making.

name: Economics of strategy, risk and globalisation
description: The module aims to deepen understanding of ideas and theories that underpin the economic analysis of decision making by economic agents in the context of the social and business environment and the wider international economy. The analytical ideas explored in this module aim to raise understanding of the complexity of the economic environment in which individuals, financial institutions, firms and governments operate. The theoretical core will help to develop analytical skills in choice theory, game theory and international economics. Students will have the opportunity to study the interplay between decision making, economic theory and economic policy and to critically examine some of the arguments for external regulation of markets. The theory examined will relate to important economic and social issues such as business regulation, strategic decision making by firms and other agents, informational problems and international trade. The knowledge and understanding  acquired will help students to understand the arguments and analysis that they will be exposed to in other modules on their programme of study which deal with related aspects of the global socio-economic environment.

name: Education Policy and Improving Schools
description: This module will enable you to critically review current debates in education policy and the implications of alternative stances on education policy for school improvement and professional practice. The module will focus on (i) the different contributions that are made by parents, students, education professionals and policy makers to the outcomes of schooling and (ii) the impacts of professional practice and school organisation on the interactions between education professionals, parents, students and policy makers.

name: Education as an International issue
description: This module will examine key educational issues, themes and perspectives internationally.  It encourages analysis of participants¿ own and other national contexts from an international and comparative perspective.  Participants develop an understanding of important theories and debates, such as:  the relationship between education and national development; effects of globalisation; how ideology and culture influence education provision; models of education management.

name: Educational Audiology (Distance Education)
description: This module considers issues related to the science of audiology and its application in the educational and developmental management of hearing impaired children and young people.  The module aims to develop skills in teachers in order to facilitate efficient audiological management of hearing-impaired children.  Areas covered include the physics of sound and acoustics; anatomy and physiology of the ear; the physiological measurement of auditory functioning; the nature and function of amplification of systems; and the efficient use of residual hearing and the development of listening skills.

name: Effective Management
description: The appreciation of generic management skills, by participation in activities to encourage self-awareness and to develop competence in those skills.  The course, specifically designed for EngD, is undertaken at the University.  The students are introduced to core management skills in time management, Health and Saftey, Communications (written, verbal), projects, meetings, leadership and delegation, concluding with an introduction to team-working.  The course is structured to give opportunity to experiment and practice in the application of those skills within the course by role-play exercises and activities.  Students participate in a debriefing after each half-day of the programme, for the purposes of collective feedback and discussion

name: Effects of Work on Health and Fitness for Work
description: The first part of this module covers the adverse impact that harmful exposures and practices at work may have on health, the skills of diagnosis and attribution of ill health to work and the application of evidence-based decisions to prevent ill health. Topics include a systems exploration of disease and injury (focusing largely on classical occupational diseases and cross-linked to other modules on the MSc OH course) health screening and surveillance.\nThe second half of the module examines the impact health and fitness may have on the capability of an individual for useful work and how evidence-based decisions may be made to strike the proper balance between safety and minimising restrictions on employability. Topics will include: setting task-related health and fitness standards for employment: adapting work to minimise health and fitness restrictions; applying task-related standards to pre-employment, during employment and when determining if and when employment should be terminated.  Reference is made to a range of occupational cases and their diagnosis in presentations. The use bio-medical equipment for health screening is demonstrated including interpretation of data.

name: Embodiment and the Carceral
description: This module introduces notions around carcerality and migrant detention within the context of broader questions of embodiment. It is informed by and extends theoretical developments across a range of geographical debates.Carceral spaces can include institutional spaces of formal imprisonment and detention, such as prisons and immigration removal centres, and also spaces outside of such institutions, but which are also affected by carceral processes, such as family, community and urban spaces.Students will select from a range of theoretical frames within which to investigate these topics, including, for example, spatial theorisations of gender, embodiment and temporality, considered in 'carceral' contexts.

name: Engagement and Assessment of Patients with Common Mental Health Problems
description:
This module aims to equip trainees with the skills and knowledge that are essential as they embark on their new role as low intensity workers.  It addresses the contextual issues that they will need to be aware of to work in an NHS setting e.g. policies, professional practice, and clinical pathways in order to help them understand their position as a resource amongst other resources available to their clients.

An essential part of their work involves direct and indirect client contact.   Therefore the module will also focus on basic skills of engagement and rapport building and other common factors/ generic therapeutic competencies.    Once skills of engagement have been acquired an essential part of trainee's role is assessment, therefore the module also aims to provide explanatory models from the dominant discourses in care systems (medical, social, psychological) to enable trainees to understand the management implications for problem definition, and to equip them as workers with conceptual and practical skills to reach collaborative useful definitions of problems with their clients.  This will include knowledge of the: incidence, prevalence and presentation of common mental health problems and their diagnostic categories which will enable trainees to help their clients make informed evidence-based treatment choices.

The importance of good case management, including appropriate record keeping and communicating with others relevant to the circumstances of each client is highlighted so that trainees can both understand and implement this as good practice as early as possible in their new role.

name: Engineering Production and Risk Management in Construction
Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description: The Entrepreneurship and Innovation module is about entrepreneurs, innovators, and the things (products, services and processes) they create.Entrepreneurship is not confined to the context of new ventures or start-ups. For example, entrepreneurship can occur within large and mature organisations, and as often as not occurs within the non-profit sector. Similarly, innovation is not just about ideas, inventions and technology. The module takes a very broad view of innovation, and for example will look at process innovations, and organisational innovations as well as new technology, products and services.

name: Epigenetics and Epigenomics
description: The completion of the human genome project has paved the way for major advances in our understanding of human genetic disease and the pathogenesis of cancer. Nevertheless, these advances have also revealed that genetics is only part of the story and there is increasing recognition that epigenetics will be critical for understanding human disease and the practice of genomic medicine. UoB is home to several research groups focussing on epigenetic research, as well as clinicians who use "epigenetic drugs" in their daily practice. This module will draw on world-leading local scientists to provide expert coverage of this fascinating topic.

name: Equipment Technology and Applied Custom Fitting
description: Although the process for custom fitting a player is essentially the same the PGA Professional must be able to understand the variables that apply when fitting a player for other clubs such as drivers and putters.  More recently with the introduction of new materials into the construction process it is important that the PGA Professional has knowledge of materials, construction processes and how they can influence performance and a club's playability.  This module focuses on clubhead and ball design, their influence on performance and the requirements of the golfing authorities relating to design and construction.

name: Ethics and Law in Clinical Practice: A Reflective Case Study
Ethics in Research
description: This module introduces students to the ethical issues surrounding the use of human participants in research.  It will look at international codes such as the Declaration of Helsinki, consent and confidentiality in research, the balance of harms and benefits in determining whether research is ethical, the on-going debate about the validity of therapeutic/non-therapeutic distinction, the particular needs of vulnerable patients (such as children or people with learning disabilities), research on retained tissue (including genetics research), the use of placebos, research ethics committees, research in developing countries, the publication of research findings, and the ethical arguments about the use of animals in research (including a consideration of the moral status of animals).  The content will reflect the needs for students to develop argument skills and an ability to evaluate different and competing viewpoints.

name: Evidence Based Low Intensity Treatment for Common Mental Health Disorders
description:
This module aims to equip trainees as workers with a good understanding of the process of therapeutic support, and the basic skills and evidence based techniques to enable clients to improve their psychological well-being, and to minimize the negative impact of symptoms associated with anxiety and depression.  Trainees will be introduced to a range of low intensity interventions, including CBT based approaches to Introductory level.  These intervention skills will enable the trainees to operate as workers in a setting with high demand.

The focus in this module is on promoting collaborative engagement between workers and their clients towards to self-help, including self-management of prescribed medication.
The importance of recognising the thresholds for 'stepping up' and referring on is highlighted with the emphasis on the conceptual and practical means for supporting these decisions.

name: Evidence Based Medicine and Research Methods
Explosion Science, Prevention and Protection
description: This module aims to give students a full understanding into the phenomenon of explosions, what effects and consequences can be expected, how to deliver a sound basis of safety in plant and equipment design and how to ensure compliance with the appropriate regulations.The module will include an overview of the explosion prevention and protection methods, the design parameters, design methods and the benefits and limitations of each technique. The role of CFD within explosion safety will also be considered.

name: Extended Inspection/Audit
description: None

name: Fermentation and Cell Culture
description: This module allows students to understand the principles of the large scale industrial production of a range of molecules, both pharmaceuticals and chemicals, by fermentation and cell culture. The module comprises one week of EBL teaching sessions.\nMaterial covered will include: choice of production system based on product (bacterial, yeast, eukaryotic cell); benefits and weaknesses of each system; the way in which each system can be used industrially at a variety of scales; and analytical techniques for monitoring upstream bioprocesses.\nThe enquiry-based learning module design will allow students to construct their own learning path through the module material and complete a portfolio of coursework that will be assessed to determine whether learning outcomes have been met.

name: Field Archaeology
description: This module reviews current archaeological project design and fieldwork method and their importance for understanding archaeological interpretation. The first part consists of lectures on the methodological basis of field archaeology, and seminars and classes involving coursework exercises on project design, organisation, field practice and investigative methods. The second part involves practical experience and learning in a fieldwork environment, including training and participation in project organisation, data gathering and recording tasks. Students will be tasked with responsible fieldwork roles and will take part in on-site project reviews.

name: Final Year Independent Study Module in Modern Languages
Finance and Core Skills
description:
The module covers writing skills, and oral presentations and teamwork. The module also deals with the usage of the Internet and the library for information gathering. Students undertake a range of exercises designed to improve their communication skills and their abilities to collect data and carry out a critical analysis on specific research topics related to management and engineering.  Students are also introduced to how they can ensure they avoid plagiarism. 

This module provides an introduction to the issue of Financial and Economic decision-making in the modern business environment.  It also gives key skills of business analysis in relation to published financial reports and forward-planning, but also addresses the conflicts and paradoxes which exist for managers making economic business decisions in a modern market economy environment.

name: Financial Decision-Making in the Business Environment
Food Control
description: An Introduction to Food Control in the EU, using the UK as the main example. The module will focus on how the member states try and ensure consumers can access safe food. The main food hygiene legislation will be reviewed and put in the context of premises inspection and enforcement including imported food. Approaches taken by other member states and important trading partners such as the USA, Australia and Canada will be compared to the UK. Problems such as fraud in the food industry will be considered, as will key issues and events which demonstrate learning points for enforcement.

name: Food Inspection
description: The module covers the identification and examination of the common foods and food sources and judgment on their fitness for human consumption. This module will include:the judgment of fitness,gross post-mortem evidence of pathological conditions of common food animals, including fish and shellfish and products of animal origin,the role of food production methods in the distribution and prevalence of common zoonoses,spoilage,product recall and traceability,import and export of foodstuffs,healthmarking,appropriate legal responses to fit, unfit and unsaleable food.\n

name: Food Standards
description: The module will cover: Legislation relating to composition and labelling, chemical safety, marketing standards, allergens and additives legislation;Food adulteration and authenticity, the role of the Public Analyst and the limits of common techniques used;Foof composition meaning the major food groups and the legal composition of foods such as chocolate, bread, meat products and dairy products.The module is externally accredited by the Charted Institute of Environmental Health and follows the syllabus set by them.

name: Forensic Psychotherapy and Forensic Issues
description: Understanding InstitutionsPrinciples of Counselling Victims in Forensic SettingsPrinciples of Counselling Offenders in Forensic SettingsPractical Workshops on Counselling SkillsEthical Issues in Therapy\tCognitive Behavioural TherapyTherapeutic Relationship IssuesConsultancy Issues and ApproachesReflective Practice in a practitioner¿s work.

name: Foundation Mathematics
description: This course is a foundation Mathematics course for students who have not specialised in Mathematics as an undergraduate. This module aims to provide students with knowledge and understanding of fundamental areas of Mathematics such as algebra, calculus and trigonometry. After completing the module, students will have a better understanding of the Mathematics that is taught during other MSc modules such as Theoretical Meteorology.     Topics covered are as follows:  Week 1: Algebra  Week 2: Introduction to differentiation Week 3: Indices and logarithms Week 4: Further differentiation; introduction to integration Week 5: Trigonometry Week 6: Further differentiation Week 7: Matrices Week 8: Further integration Week 9: Permutations and combinations Week 10: Partial differentiation Emphasis will be placed on meteorological examples throughout the course, providing the students with the knowledge to understand mathematical forms of meteorological processes and with the skills to quantify meteorological elements/components.

name: Foundations in Critical Thinking
description: Lectures discuss current research techniques and develop critical approaches to reading and evaluating research articles.  The module include small group discussions where students target critique of specific research approaches.

name: Foundations of Medical Science and Practice 1: Cell Science, Endocrinology, Neurones  and Society
Foundations of Medical Science and Practice 2: Health Behaviours, Musculoskeletal, Respiratory and Digestive Systems
Foundations of Medical Science and Practice 3: Immunology, Health Care Provision, Cardiovascular and Renal Science
Foundations of Medical Science and Practice 4: Brain, Decision Making, Reproduction and Cancer
From Bench to Market: the Development of Pharmaceutical Drug Products
Frontiers in Biomedicine for Engineering and Physical Sciences
description: This module will focus on introducing the three healthcare challenges and providing underpinning knowledge required for approaching research projects in these in: Rebuilding the ageing and diseased body; Understanding cardiovascular disease; Improving trauma and emergency medicine.  The seminars will highlight the state-of-the-art in research and outline key problems where physical sciences may be applied.  Underpinning areas covered will include:  The cardiovascular and respiratory systems; The immune system; The neuromuscular system; Hard tissues - tooth and bone; Regenerative medicine and stem cell technology.

name: Fuel Cell Technologies (Ren Energy)
description: Fuel cells are a modern technology to convert chemical energy (fuels) into electricity and heat at very high efficiencies. Apart from water (and CO2, depending on fuel type) there are no harmful emissions from the process.  The module will cover Fuel Cell technologies and their science, including  • basic science of fuel cells  • applications of fuel cells and hydrogen • low & high temperature fuel cells,  • fuels for fuel cells • fuel cell systems • environmental analysis, market introduction, economy, and policy framework.

name: Functional Grammar
description: This module offers advanced studies in a specialist area of Applied English Linguistics: Functional Grammar.  The principles of systemic functional grammar and analysis of text from a systemic perspective are introduced, as a means of revealing the meaning, communicative functionality and rhetorical purposes of language, and various applications of this approach to linguistics are considered.

name: Functional Materials
description: The module will introduce the important role played by functional materials in a wide range of application areas including energy, communications and transport.  Materials to be studied will encompass a selection from ferroelectric, piezoelectric and dielectric ceramics; ionic and electronic conducting ceramics; semiconductors; magnetic, superconducting and magnetostrictive materials.The important underlying scientific concepts for each material and application area will be elucidated.  A number of key technologically important applications such as fuel cells, solar cells and optical and magnetic data storage media will be studied in detail.  The transport area will include the role of magnets and superconductors in magnetic levitation (maglev), and magnets, magnetostrictives and piezoelectrics for automobile applications.  Functional ceramic materials will be introduced for a range of communication and environmental monitoring applications.  In each case fabrication and processing routes appropriate for each group of materials in the particular application area or device will be introduced and the important links between processing, microstructure and properties will be quantified.  The range of applications will require detailed exploration of thin film, thick film, bulk and fibre processing routes, and exploration of specialised fabrication routes for magnetic, superconductor and functional ceramic materials.

name: Game Theory
description: The main emphasis of the module will be on the discussion and description of solution concepts appropriate for various types of economic problems. This module aims to provide the theoretical background necessary to understand game theoretic models and how these models are applied as a tool to solve problems in economics. These are becoming increasingly common in many areas, such as Industrial Organization, Political Economy, International Trade and Environmental Economics.

name: Gender and Development
description: The module aims to introduce students to the gender dimensions of development theory, policy and practice.  Students will learn how to use feminist theories to analyse contemporary processes of capitalist development.  They will analyse how gender issues permeate all aspects of development policy and will learn how to critically assess these policies.  The course also aims to enable students to apply these theoretical and analytical tools to a gendered analysis of contemporary development practices.

name: Gender in Byzantium II
description: The course deals with the construction of the 'normative' gender as male in Byzantium, and with how this impacted upon the social construction of maleness and femaleness in written and visual sources both from the Byzantine period and in modern scholarship.  Through deconstruction of texts and artifacts, the course assesses the evidence for the roles of real men and real women in different areas of Byzantine society over time.  In the Spring term, the emphasis is on using the skills acquired in term one to re-evaluate existing paradigms.By the end of term two, the student will have developed a deeper understanding of gender theory, will have more advanced critical approach to the material, and will be able to generate theoretically and empirically sound new responses to the material.

name: General Nuclear Power Technology
description: This module covers in detail the physics of reactor operation, reactor poisons and the control and measurement systems designed for optimum and safe operation.  An introduction to the many facets of decommissioning of redundant plant is covered with introductory financial appraisal, covering the economics of operation, cash flow, balance sheets and profit/loss accounting.

name: Global Entrepreneurship
description: The Global Entrepreneurship module is about entrepreneurs, innovators, and the things (products, services and processes) they create.\n\nEntrepreneurship is not confined to the context of new ventures or start-ups. For example, entrepreneurship can occur within large and mature organisations, and as often as not occurs within the non-profit sector. Similarly, innovation is not just about ideas, inventions and technology. The module takes a very broad view of innovation, and for example will look at process innovations, and organisational innovations as well as new technology, products and services.

name: Global Environmental Issues (distance learning)
Groundwater Organic Contaminant Pollution and Remediation
description: Pollution of groundwater by organic contaminants remains a key driver of exceedingly expensive contaminated land and groundwater investigation and remediation efforts. This module seeks to provide the organic contaminant hydrogeological knowledge base that will underpin a student's potential future professional activity in this field. The module will cover contaminant source terms, contextual toxicology and environmental standards and legislation; organic contaminant phase partitioning to air, water, solids; conceptual models of contaminant migration; processes of sorption, chemical reaction, biodegradation; and, NAPL multi-phase flow. These will be illustrated by contaminant case studies throughout. Student learning will be underpinned by set calculation problem sheets. These theoretical aspects will underpin more applied aspects, probably including industry-led sessions.   Remediation will predominantly focus on organic contaminants, but also may include some discussion of related fields of inorganic and microbiological contamination. Remediation will cover a range of representative modern technologies and, depending on time groundwater protection initiatives and relevant waste disposal practice.

name: Group Poster Project
description: This project allows students to study in more depth topic from the MBChB curriculum, which they have not had time during the regular academic year to pursue.Students will forms small groups within their M group, research a topic, and then create, and present a poster on the topic to academics from the College.  Therefore, as well as allowing students to opportunity to work on a topic of interest, it also allows students to think about how to design a poster, and to have the experience of presenting this is a conference-like atmosphere.  Also important in this project is the requirement for the students to work together on this project, thus fostering team work skills that will be vital later.

name: Group Working in the Construction Industry
description: This module is formed of 2 parts:1.\tGroup Project (10 credits):  In this project the students will work in groups to apply and develop further the knowledge gained in other modules, particularly CE5COMa Construction Management, to (i) develop a Management Plan and Contract Strategy Report for the procurement of a construction project, and (ii)  prepare a Team Working Report to include discussion of the way the group worked on the project and evaluation of its effectiveness. 2.\tStrategic Management (10 credits):  This component of the module provides a framework for understanding, evaluating and designing plans for strategic management within Civil Engineering construction.  A social-constructionist perspective underpins the content and delivery of the material; and links micro and macro level analysis of business, economics and strategic management within construction.  A topical perspective is taken, for example the impact and strategic response to the credit crisis and subsequent economic downturn.\n

name: Guided Reading for Dissertation
description: The Guided Reading module is designed to lay the foundation for the 15,000 word dissertation and to establish the student's ability in research and critical enquiry. The essay will take the form of a literature review (including a brief but clear proposal of the dissertation project), testing the student's ability to conduct extensive research and to condense and synthesise that material into a coherent piece of work that would potentially function as an ideal preparation for a written dissertation.

name: Guided project in editing and production
description: The skills learnt through the guided editing project will also be applied to the audio-visual dissertation. The schedule for training and preparation can vary from year to year, but typically it breaks down into the following:Students will have been introduced to the equipment and software being used in creation of the guided editing projects during their first semester training sessions. The second semester will begin with students sharing their selected topics/questions for the videos and arranging their shooting plan, shot list, interviewees, etc. Students will also be invited to monthly workshops (January – May) where they will be given guidance on the creative and critical aspects of short filmmaking, and opportunities to discuss and develop their projects with their peers.

name: Health, Disease and Therapeutics 2-1
description:
Delivered across semesters 1 and 2 of the second year, this module will provide essential knowledge of the structure and function of the kidney highlighting its significance in terms of homeostasis and as a major excretory organ of products of metabolism, including drugs. Renal tract anatomy and normal physiology will be covered in lectures, small group teaching and anatomy prosection sessions. A series of lectures and small group sessions will introduce the concepts of acute and chronic renal dysfunction and, using patient scenarios, will further explore the consequences and management of renal dysfunction.
Emphasis will be placed on understanding kidney function in relation to the systems (cell metabolism, membrane potentials, neurological function, endocrine system) taught in year one and other systems covered in HDT 2:1 (haemopoiesis). This module will be taught in parallel to the HDT 2:2 module to facilitate student understanding of the interactions between the renal and cardiovascular systems and in particular the way that drugs used to treat one system which either intentionally or secondarily impact on the function of other systems (eg diuretics or renin-angiotensin system blockade).

The normal physiological changes related to age, pregnancy and breastfeeding will also be explored in relation to the significance for  altered pharmacodynamics  (the way that drugs effect the body) and pharmacokinetics (how the body deals with drugs).
Following on from the introduction to the immune system in year one students will acquire a basic understanding of immunology, applying this to the principles of vaccination and diagnostics as a grounding for further exploration of these topics in relation to health and disease such as immune disorders, HIV, therapeutic immunosuppression and transplantation in year 3.
Students will be introduced to haemopoiesis and anaemias in lectures and small group teaching sessions and the way renal, gastrointestinal, central nervous and immune system functions interact with red cell production and oxygen delivery to tissues.

Following an introduction to the identification and practical management of adverse drug reactions and interactions, students will continue to link apply this knowledge with therapeutics, science and professional modules in years 2, 3 and 4.
Assessment for this module includes written examinations using a combination of multiple choice and short answer questions. Coursework will include a group presentation of a patient case, linked to therapeutic management of disease. Students will also submit a webfolio account together with personal reflection on a short interview with a patient on dialysis, or a patient taking medicines from any of the 'special therapeutic groups'. Students will work in groups on an immunology based project leading to a assessed presentation.
All modules are integrative. Students will develop an appreciation of how knowledge gained through this module may be applied to other second year modules specifically The Professional Pharmacist ,Health, Disease and Therapeutics', Chemistry for Pharmacists  and Science of Medicines. This application of knowledge will be further tested throughout the course progression.

name: Health, Disease and Therapeutics 3-2
description:
This third year clinical module covers areas of health, disease and therapeutics related to  patients with mental health conditions, with cancer diagnoses and patients with HIV  and introduces the care and treatment of patients approaching the end of life. Students will be introduced to technical aspects of producing radiopharmaceutical materials for diagnosis and treatment.
The module will integrate knowledge from earlier modules, particularly pharmacology, pharmaceutics and elements of professional pharmacy, and evaluate and apply it to the specific context of these patient groups.  The principles of management of therapeutics will also have wider application in fourth year modules.
The impact of substance misuse, including misuse of prescription drugs will also be studied.
Using the clinical contexts covered in this module as a focus, students will explore the significant developments in pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics, and the future of personalised medicine.
Students will benefit from the expertise of specialists working and researching in these fields both from within the University of Birmingham and associated local institutions such as Hospice and Prison and NHS partners. Teaching will include face to face lectures supported with small group work and linked where appropriate to placement opportunities through the Professional Pharmacist module 3. Independent learning will be facilitated through integrated problems through the virtual learning environment.
Communication  skills such as those required for dealing confidently in end of life care will be explored through multimedia learning tasks using group work with other student healthcare professionals in an interprofessional environment.
Assessment will focus on the application of knowledge through written examination using a variety of applied written tasks.

name: Healthcare Ethics and Law Research Project
description: This module affords the opportunity for students to produce a substantial piece of assessed work on a subject of their own choice (guided by their supervisor).  The main requirement is that students write about some overtly ethical and/or legal aspect of health care.  Students will be encouraged to use the research skills that they have acquired during each of the taught modules.  Ethical and Legal research has traditionally been undertaken using conceptual analysis methodology.  Increasingly, qualitative research methodologies are being used to gain new areas of ethical and legal data.  The programme seeks to provide students with an opportunity to be trained and utilise this new range of methodologies as they apply to biomedical ethics and law.\nTherefore, students may choose to undertake a piece of empirical bioethics research for their dissertation.

name: Heart Failure Management in Primary Care
description:
To provide accredited certification and validation of competencies for health care professionals involved in the management of people with heart failure in the community.
The course has been produced to offer a systematic understanding of heart failure and a knowledge of how to apply this knowledge to practice; a critical awareness of current management issues and new insights into the management of heart failure.
It will also provide skills to enable autonomous practice in dealing with more complex problems and unpredictable situations and the ability to critically evaluate current research in the heart failure arena.  An independent learning process will allow students to continue to advance their knowledge and understanding of heart failure.
The course is in line with the approaches set out in the NICE guidelines for Heart Failure and the Quality and Outcome Framework indicators for good practice.
The programme is based on principles of adult education and self directed learning, with the learner needs paramount, involving both interactive and participative education, where students will contribute to discussion in facilitated group work.

name: Higher cognitive functions in children, adults and non-human animals
History Dissertation
description: A substantial and sustained investigation of an historical problem relating to the relevant historical period in the light of current knowledge and current interpretations and of an analysis of the available primary source materials.  The findings of this investigation are then presented in an extended form with full argumentation and scholarly apparatus, so that the identity and value of the sources on one hand and the quality and structure of the argument on the other can be clearly understood by the reader.

name: History of Medicine Research Project
description: The module involves the organisation, research and writing up of an original piece of research in  the form of a 10,000 word dissertation. The teaching involves students attending seminars on identifying research questions, researching in archives, conducting interviews and writing up the research in a scholarly and even publishable form. Group meetings will be used to introduce students to issues that will be applicable to all of research projects, regardless of subject matter. These include a session on doing research, introduction to archives and referencing in academic writing. Students will also meet with their supervisors at least 5 times to discuss research findings, identify gaps in the research and discuss alternative ways in which the research may be written up and presented. A seminar will also address the practical issues of writing up research findings, but students will also meet with supervisors, who will be prepared to comment on individual students' written work.

name: History of Medicine Research Project Design
Home Office approved animal licence course
description: Modules 1-4 of the HO course covers ethical, legal and practical aspects of the Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 and its local application. Students are taught the principles of animal handling, husbandry and surgery. Successful completion will lead to the award of a PIL (personal licence to conduct animal experiments)

name: Immediate Life Support
description: The ILS course has been developed to train healthcare personnel to a higher level than that offered by Basic Life Support training, and to bridge the gap between 'community' BLS and 'in-hospital' ALS.  The ILS course includes cardiopulmonary resuscitation, simple airway management and safe defibrillation (manual and/or AED), and initial management of the acutely ill patient. The course is run over one day and consists of lectures and practical stations. The manual is forwarded two weeks before the start of the course.  Candidates are advised to study this thoroughly. Assessment on the course is continuous in nature and copies of the assessment forms should be forwarded to candidates with their copies of the manual.All students must successfully complete this module within 12months of graduation.  Where students have taken the ILS course in an earlier programme year, the ILS course must be repeated in the final year.

name: Independent Project
description: The technical content depends on the project chosen, but many projects contain elements of literature review, fieldwork, laboratory analysis, and modelling.  Students give a short oral presentation of their project aims and methodology, and produce a written project report.

name: Independent Research Project in Nuclear Decommissioning and Waste Management
description: This module provides students with experience of working in a nuclear industrial department, and/or the School of Physics & Astronomy nuclear laboratory and carrying out an individual research project. The technical content depends on the project chosen, but the project will draw upon expertise gained in the earlier modules and allowing students to develop further their knowledge and understanding of particular topics. Students give a short oral presentation of their project and produce a written project report.

name: Individual Investigative Research Project
description:
The dissertation project is supported by a dissertation workshop where students receive assistance with their choice of project and a refresher on literature studies and formal referencing. A major part of the learning though is achieved through individual practical work and through the individual study of source materials and current journals. The individual study is guided by the dissertation supervisor and the dis-sertation project module leader. Aspects of the structure of the module delivery depend on the mode of attendance on the MSc programme and on whether the student undertakes an internship before the start of the taught part of the MSc programme.
Dissertation Project as part of Full-Time Study without an Internship:
The dissertation project is undertaken during a period of six months following the taught part of the MSc programme and may be undertaken either in industry or in an academic environment.
Dissertation Project as part of Full-Time Study with an Internship:
An initial study of the project background may be undertaken during an internship with a typical duration of 2-3 months, before the start of the MSc programme. This must be focused on a general understanding of the requirements of the parti¬cular branch of railway engineering or the railway industry, in order not to compromise the integrity of the individual investigative research project. The studies leading to the dissertation project are then undertaken during a period of six months that follows on from the taught part of the MSc programme. The investigative project may be undertaken either in industry or in an academic environment, to suit the objectives of the project. The course team recommends this format for students without prior involvement in the railway industry.
Dissertation Project as part of Part-Time Study without an Internship:
The dissertation project is normally completed during the two summer periods of the taught part of the programme and, where necessary, a third year may be devoted part-time to the dissertation project. In most cases, part-time students undertake their individual investigative project in industry, working for their employer. In some cases, students can work on a University based project.
Dissertation Project as part of Part-Time Study with an Internship:
Where a postgraduate has just taken up employment in the railway industry, an initial study of the back-ground to the individual investigative project background may be undertaken during an internship with a typical duration of 2-3 months, before the start of the MSc programme, before the start of the MSc programme. This must be focused on a gene¬ral understanding of the requirements of the parti¬cular branch of railway engineering or the railway in¬dustry, in order not to compromise the integrity of the individual investigative research project. The studies leading to the dissertation project are then normally completed during the two summer periods of the taught part of the programme and, where necessary, a third year may be devoted part-time to these studies. In most cases, part-time students undertake their individual investigative project in industry, working for their employer. In some cases, students may work on a University based project.

name: Individual Project
description: The module will involve carrying out independent study on a chosen research topic.

name: Individual Research Project
description: This module will involve the following:Carrying out and independent study on a chosen research topic and demonstrating the ability to produce original and innovative work.  The project will involve a literature review, collation of data, analysis, presentation of results, discussion and conclusions.

name: Industrial Placement
description: This module provides an opportunity for students to gain an experience of working in a company or public body, to understand how individual and corporate responsibility operates.  This module allows students to develop informal and formal communication skills through participating in technical meetings, preparing reports and making presentations.

name: Industrial Placement Project
description: The aim is to give the student an experience of working in an industrial environment, working on a project that is intended to be a problem solving exercise in which the student tackles a research or production problem, or a set of related problems, in which the student's skills in analysing and solving the problem are tested.

name: Infrastructure Development Planning
description:
This model will develop boarder skills and knowledge of the planning process associated with infrastructure projects with emphasis on ground related projects.  Key areas covered include:
Building Information Modelling related to ground works, H&S issues, earthworks, planning processes, novel materials and general ground works management.

Students will work in groups deliver design concept for planning consideration for an infrastructure build (focussed on the ground).  Teams will be made up of students from different programme offering a unique chance to work across discipline and through this develop teamwork skills. Thus this module will provide experience of working in multi-discipline teams on a significant infrastructure project.

name: Innovation and Professional Practice in Sport
Integrated  Pharmacy Practice
description:
This 60 credit module requires students to integrate and apply existing knowledge from Science of Medicines, Chemistry for Pharmacists, Professional Pharmacist, and Health, Disease and Therapeutics modules in previous years.

Some material will continue to be delivered through face to face lectures, there will be increased use of student directed learning tasks to underpin and support the delivery of more advanced pharmacy services including legal, ethical and regulatory processes governing prescribing, and to provide any necessary update on legal and regulatory issues covered in previous modules. 
Professional accountability will be examined including the recognition of ethical dilemmas and the application of the principles of clinical governance and audit. This module in particular acknowledges the students' increasing engagement with healthcare users and providers, embracing an enquiry based approach to learning. 
Students will collaboratively study complex patient case scenarios in groups producing therapeutic management plans and demonstrating their ability to communicate appropriate advice with patients, carers and other healthcare professionals. Students will also be required to demonstrate clinical decision making skills uniprofessionally. Modern dispensing (including tests of mathematical competence) will also be integrated into the learning experience.
Students will engage with theories of the psychology of prescribing, external influences on prescribing decisions and the importance of relationships with other healthcare professionals and patients.
Students will cover physiology, pathology, pharmacology and therapeutics related to the eyes, skin, ear nose and throat. Physiology required to support therapeutic interventions in emergency and intensive medicine will also be covered. Teaching in specialist areas will be supported by face to face lectures delivered by visiting clinical experts, together with materials delivered in workshops. Clinical examination and consultation skills to support future prescribing will be taught and practised using the clinical skills teaching facilities and the simulated patients of the Interactive Skills Unit within the university.Students will be assessed on their ability to integrate knowledge, including law and regulatory updates, and theoretical knowledge underpinning prescribing in practice using their professional skills through OSCE examinations, and written examinations.Critical appraisal of service delivery (audit) and ability to review a therapeutic area will be assessed through coursework.

name: Integrated Project
description: This module will allow students to experience different perspectives relating to the development of a new/refurbish infrastructure, taking the concept from conceptualisation through to final structure/civil engineering design. This module will run over two semesters with semester 1 dedicated to conceptual design working in groups, to produce design concepts for building developments.  The second semester students will then take conceptual design to produce details structure and civil engineering design details.

name: Integrative Capstone Module
description: The Integrative Capstone Module (ICM) exposes students to general management and leadership challenges, and the application of solutions that apply approaches from all the first year modules on the MSc. Real business issues are multifaceted, and so the ICM module shows students how to integrate the core subjects in holistic analysis of business problems.\n\nIn all organisations, the person who has to adopt this general business perspective is the leader … the chief executive. The module will therefore place a heavy emphasis on understanding the role of the chief executive and leadership generally.

name: Intermetallics, Metal Matrix Composites and Ceramic Matrix Composites
International Accounting and Finance
description: All managers, whatever their specialisation have to interpret and apply financial information in their decision making. This requirement does not mean that all managers have to become accountants, but it does mean that managers have to understand the vernacular of accounting and financial management. Managers cannot discuss the cost and finance implications of activity without an appreciation of the processes, information sources, and methods of presentation of financial information. Managers cannot direct accountants unless they know what to ask for.In essence, the module aims to give students an appreciation of the perspective and tools available to accounting and finance professionals, and perhaps most importantly the limitations and caveats to the financial information that they can provide.

name: International Business
description: The International Business module will develop student's knowledge of the global economic and business environment and use this knowledge to inform the development of strategy for managing in dynamic global markets and contexts. The module will also explore how global environmental changes affect the ways in which companies respond tactically, both within regions and countries, and across borders. The module will look at the theoretical prescription, but also will be firmly immersed in real practice of global business management. Specific areas discussed in the International Business module are: firm internationalisation (both in terms of imperatives and processual responses), emerging markets and overseas investment. Disciplines such as trade theory and international economics, international finance, organisational theory and business strategy are also addressed in the module.

name: International Marketing
description:
The International Marketing module provides an introduction to the nature of marketing and explains how the marketing function fits within the global organisation overall. The module also looks at how actors outside the core marketing function have a role in, and engage in marketing activity.

The module aims to provide a critical and systematic understanding of theory and practice in marketing. Insights into the relationship between marketing and strategy, marketing and the customer, marketing and operations and marketing and the brand will emerge from service, manufacturing, technological and consumer product perspectives. The module will trace the development and application of marketing theory embracing the experiences of FMCG approaches, through to global business to business and marketing relationships and by critically identifying theoretical synergies which underpin marketing decision making.

The module will show students the broad scope of marketing activity and will establish an understanding of the core concepts underlying the field.

name: International Marketing Strategy
description: The International Marketing Strategy module seeks to extend the depth of knowledge about the development of global marketing strategies, and their implementation. On completion of the module students will understand the processes adopted by marketing professionals: analysis, development of global marketing strategies, and critically, the ways in which these strategies are implemented, and refined in response to tactical / short term imperatives.\n\nThe module will help students develop their ability to: choose the most effective analytic strategies, assess implementation and managerial implications; and critically evaluate strategic marketing analysis methods with respect to their validity and relevance in a range of global marketplaces. The module will also explore the impact of marketing decisions upon the long-term evolution of markets; and market structures in terms of customers, competitors and market channels.

name: International and European Legal Responses to Terrorism
Introduction to Bilingualism and Special Needs
description: The issues concerning bilingual learners who have special needs and/or special educational needs are addressed in this module, in particular assessment, differentiation and practice.  Perceptions of disability are explored across multicultural and multilingual professional and parental groups and is focused on a collaborative approach to meeting this group of learners' educational needs.

name: Introduction to Bilingualism in Education
description: This module introduces students to issues and content surrounding working with emerging bilingual learners in educational contexts.  The main areas covered include the development of first and second language, with particular attention to English, curriculum, language assessment, literacy and working collaboratively.  The module would be of interest to mainstream, subject and EAL specialists teachers, psychologists, and speech/language therapists.  It is offered by distance and is usually taken with 11 05675, Bilingualism and Special Needs, and a Special Study (11 05473 or 11 05543) in the field.

name: Introduction to Biomedical Science
description: None

name: Introduction to Clinical Practice in Anaesthesia
description: The module is designed to introduce students, some of whom will not previously have worked in the health service, to the layout and function of the hospital in general and the operating department in particular. They will be introduced to the members of the operating department team, the roles they fulfil and their interactions with each other and with personnel in wards etc.The module will also introduce them to:the basic equipment of the operating department and to major safety issues for patients and themselvesmedical law and ethics with particular reference to the operative and peri-operative periodbasic anatomy, physiology and pharmacologydisease processes and common medical conditionsbasic principles underpinning surgical managementphysical examination and the rationale for / interpretation of simple investigationshistorical perspective on the development of anaesthesiascientific principles underpinning the administration of general, local and regional anaesthesiathe pharmacology of anaesthetic drugs and the induction and maintenance of anaesthesia and on recovery from anaestheticIn addition, students are taught the clinical skills of IV cannulation, infusion and drug administration, airway assessment and basic life support and will develop / refine the communication and basic practical skills required for the role.In addition, students are taught the clinical skills of IV cannulation, infusion and drug administration, airway assessment and basic life support and will develop / refine the communication and basic practical skills required for the role.

name: Introduction to Development Projects
description: This is an introductory course in the planning and financial analysis of public sector investment projects.  The emphasis is on small scale revenue-generating projects in the context of developing the transitional countries.  Topics covered include the project cycle, planning based upon logical framework, financial forecasts and discounted methods of project valuation.

name: Introduction to Food Law, Safety and Risk Assessment
description: None

name: Introduction to Health Economics
description: This module is designed to introduce the basic principles of health economics and equip students with the basic knowledge needed to interpret and appraise applied studies in health economics. It covers a range of issues, which can be followed up in greater detail in assignments and option modules. The course covers issues including health and health care systems, methods of economic evaluation, setting priorities using health economics and the interface between health economics and health policy

name: Introduction to High-Temperature Fuel Cells and Electrolysers (HTFCE)
description: Fundamentals of high temperature fuel cells (HTFC) applied to solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC), molten carbonate fuel cells (MCFC), intermediate temperature SOFC (IT-SOFC), and solid oxide electrolysers (SOE).\nTheory of the electrochemical and thermo-dynamical fundamentals of high temperature fuel cells and electrolysis. Materials used for the components (electrolytes, catalysts, electrodes, interconnects etc.) of the different cells: materials properties, high temperature conduction mechanisms, requirements for the individual components. Manufacturing, stacking, and degradation mechanisms. System components, design, and fuels. Basics of electrochemical characterisation and modelling.\nApplication of the fuel cell technology to electrolysis; electrolysis of water and CO2; co-electrolysis and synthetic fuels; power-to-gas applications in energy storage. Technology outlook, future markets and main development challenges and trends.

name: Introduction to Immunology
description: The module presents a coherent overview of the major tissue, cellular and molecular components of both the innate and adaptive immune system, and their role in the induction of immune responses and as effector mechanisms that resolve infection. Abnormal immune responses are also covered, with reference to human disease. The majority of lecture content will be made available as a series of podcast lectures before the programme commences, allowing students to proceed with outline material at their own pace. This learning will be enhanced with a few face-to-face lectures followed by an extensive series of small group teaching sessions to provide further tuition and clarification of understanding.

name: Introduction to Leadership and Management for Health
description: This module provides an introduction to management for students from a range of professional and academic backgrounds.  Its aim is to examine the main components of management in a way that is accessible to students with different levels of experience of working in organisations.  Using health care organisations as a focus it explores the key elements of managing self, managing teams and managing organisations to enable students to develop a critical perspective on organisation.  It focuses on the use of theory and research to build an understanding of management and leadership in organisations.

name: Introduction to Learning and Teaching in Higher Education for Doctoral Researchers
description: This module is intended to equip postgraduate teaching assistants (PGTAs) with the core knowledge and abilities needed to support both their current teaching role and their ongoing professional development as higher education teachers.  Participants take relevant courses from CLAD?s open programmes to introduce key concepts and knowledge of learning and teaching practice.  The remainder of the module is designed to be as flexible as possible, allowing participants to tailor their studies to their own teaching responsibilities and interests ? the emphasis is therefore on self-directed study, supported by peer- and tutor-led workshops as well as a range of other learning support (e.g. one-to-one tutorials, e-learning resources).

name: Introduction to Low-temperature Fuel Cells and Electrolysers (LTFCE)
description: Fundamentals of low temperature fuel cells (LTFC) applied to alkaline fuel cells (AFC), phosphoric acid fuel cells (PAFC), Polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFC), high and intermediate temperature PEFC (HT/IT-PEFC) and direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC). Fundamentals of low temperature electrolysis (LTE) with respect to alkaline and polymer electrolyte electrolysis.\nTheory of the electrochemical and thermo-dynamical fundamentals of low temperature fuel cells. Materials used for the components (electrolytes, catalysts, electrodes, bipolar plates etc.) of the different cells: materials properties, conduction mechanisms, requirements for the individual components. Manufacturing, stacking, and degradation mechanisms. System components, design, and fuels. Basics of electrochemical characterisation and modelling. Application of fuel cell principles to electrolysis. Technology outlook, future markets and main development challenges and trends.

name: Introduction to Materials
description: The module is intended to introduce Materials Science to students with a first degree in physical science or engineering other than Materials.  It will introduce the relationship between processing, microstructure and properties for the main classes of materials: metals, polymers, ceramics and composites.  The understanding of materials microstructures will be underpinned by knowledge of crystal structures and phase diagrams.  The relationship between material microstructures and common physical and mechanical properites of materials will be introduced.

name: Introduction to Research Methods for Bioethics
description:
This module has two aims. First to enable students to developed more advanced skills of philosophical argument and critical reasoning than they can be expected to have developed during their MBChB learning to date. Second to provide students with sufficient knowledge of modern bioethical research methods and skills to be able to make a reasoned and justified decision about which method (qualitative or purely analytical) is most appropriate for their dissertation. 
Students will be introduced to different means of mounting a robust philosophical argument. They will be provided with the tools for critical analysis including how to read and critique ethics and law papers/materials, and for developing the skills necessary to complete the assessements for the programme as a whole.

Students will be introduced to a variety of qualitative research methods, as well as to theoretical and practical issues in combining ethical analysis and qualitative data. They will be shown how to critically appraise current empirical bioethics research, and to plan and carry out their own independent research project.  The integration of ethics and qualitative data gathering will enable students in the healthcare ethics and law stream to gain some experience of empirical research, and will introduce students to a new and developing area that is at the cutting edge of modern bioethics, as well as ensuring that they understand how to read and write effectively using traditional philosophical methods.

name: Introduction to Trauma Science
description: This module will provide students with the opportunity to acquire a basic understanding of Trauma Science, ranging from epidemiology to current uses of prosthetics and rehabilitation protocols. The diagnosis of trauma will be explored with a focus on its types, causes and risk factors. Possible underlying strategies for managing patients with different types of trauma will also be discussed according to evidence-based current practices.

name: Introductory Practitioner Course in Cognitive Behaviour Therapy
description: The IPC in the Cognitive Behavioural Approach aims to equip participants with some Cognitive behavioural methods that they would be expected to use in their existing clinical work within their current role.  It is therefore not a therapy training course and participants should not expect to be able to finish the course and be competent CB therapists.  The course can be used as a foundation for those who wish to subsequently gain formal therapy training in CBT.  The IPC is module 2 of the Postgraduate Diploma in CBT.\n

name: Jesus Christ and the Holy Trinity
description: This module is in two parts. Part One introduces students to the Person of Jesus Christ as He is presented in the teachings of the Roman Catholic Church.  This involves an examination of the historical, geographical and political contexts in which the New Testament narratives are set; a review of what the NT teaches about Jesus and how the Church¿s doctrine developed during the Patristic and Medieval periods, including the Councils of Nicea 1, Constantinople 1, Ephesus and Chalcedon, leading to some contemporary ideas about Jesus Christ; a consideration of Jesus Christ as Saviour and Redeemer, examining some of the more popular historical models of redemption.  Part Two introduces students of the doctrine of God, One and Three, through a study of the development of the teachings of the Catholic Church, in the Scriptures, the Church Fathers, the major Church Councils, and the writings of some contemporary theologians, and equips them to teach and preach to others about God and His love for His creation.\n

name: LC  Roots of Inequality: Race, Gender and the Legacies of Colonialism in the Global North
LC  Roots of Inequality: Race, Gender and the Legacies of Colonialism in the Global South
LC + I  Golf Industry Experience Placement
description: The module provides students with an opportunity to engage with their chosen industry by working within it (normally in a paid capacity) over their summer vacation(s). This also fulfils the requirement for PGA membership. They will be expected to work with a PGA Professional for a minimum of 240 hours in order to gain experience within the golf industry and explore and apply the academic modules they have engaged with in an applied manner (e.g. business, coaching, club fitting, and applied sports science).\nThe module allows them to experience the industry first hand and also make contacts and develop skills of graduateness and broader life skills (e.g. CV development, interviews, placement negotiation, communication, teamwork, problem-solving, independent living). \n

name: LC A History of Art in 20 Objects A
LC A History of Art in 20 Objects B
LC Academic and Professional Skills B
LC Advanced Custom Fitting and equipment Technology
LC Algebra & Combinatorics
description:
Combinatorics is the study of discrete (often finite) structures that arise not only in areas of pure mathematics, but in other areas of science, for example computer science, statistical physics and genetics.  From ancient beginnings, this subject truly rose to prominence from the mid-20th century, when scientific discoveries (most notably of DNA) showed that combinatorics is key to understanding the world around us, whilst many of the great advances in computing were built on combinatorial foundations. The combinatorics half of this module starts by looking at naïve set theory, introducing the notions of partitions, equivalence relations and the notion of countable and uncountable infinite sets.  Sophisticated counting techniques are developed before an introduction to the field of graph theory, which provides a mathematical framework for the study of both real-world and virtual networks.

One of the most powerful techniques of pure mathematics is that of abstraction, which allows deep relationships between apparently unrelated areas to become apparent.  Abstract algebra is a powerful example of this technique, abstracting notions of symmetry and the properties of arithmetic to reveal algebraic structures such as groups, rings and fields.  Despite their very abstract nature, these ideas have significant real world applications, for example in communication theory and internet security.  Using familiar examples of the natural numbers, real numbers and polynomials as motivation, the axioms for groups, rings and fields are introduced and basic properties of these structures are explored.  Elementary number theory, the Euclidean algorithm, and prime numbers are discussed.  

Underlying themes throughout this module are techniques of proof and the importance of mathematical writing

name: LC Around the World with Anthropology
LC Art of Persuasion A: Propaganda and Public Discourse
LC Art of Persuasion B: Philosophical Texts
LC BISS Film and Media
description: This module is designed for delivery as part of the Birmingham International Summer School. It will provide students with an introduction to the academic study of film and media within the university environment, as well as the cultural, historical and social contexts of film and media in the UK. It will combine traditional in-class teaching with field trips, external visits and practical production sessions.

name: LC Beginners Catalan Language B
description: The three weekly hours are distributed between communicative language and grammar classes (2 hours per week) and a parallel translation hour to develop comprehension skills and to provide an introduction to Catalan culture by using historical, literary and cultural texts. Direct training in basic translation and language skills will be taught across these three hours. Students will also have the opportunity to achieve an extra qualification to increase their employability by taking the International Catalan Certificate issued by the Institut Ramon Llull and held at the University of Birmingham.

name: LC Between the National and the Global:  Peninsular Spanish History, 1936 to the Present Day A
LC Between the National and the Global: Peninsular Spanish History, 1936 to the Present Day B
LC C Programming
description:
The course will also aim to stimulate students into thinking like programmers and provide an understanding of programming techniques that reaches beyond familiarity and basic fluency with the C programming language. 

More specifically, this course introduces students to the principles of programming using a procedure-oriented approach, providing students with the programming skills necessary to continue the study of computer science.
In this course, the basic concepts and grammars of the C programming language, and the function block programming method, are taught. Programming case studies help the students to understand programming techniques.  Detailed teaching contents cover data types,  operators and expressions,  control flow,  looping, arrays,  functions and program structure,  pointers, elementary functions,  structures,  input and output, and file access,  etc. 

Students are required to complete programs that encompass the various topics learned in the lectures. These tasks will increase in difficulty as the course progresses. The tasks will emphasize good programming technique, style, and structure.

Hands-on Programming Labs are organized to practice and consolidate what is covered in lectures.

name: LC Cardiovascular and Respiratory Sciences: Fundamental Principles
LC Chaos and Non-linear Systems A
LC Chaos and Non-linear Systems B
LC Chaos in Discrete and Continuous Systems
description: This module provides a mathematical introduction to the phenomena of chaos in non-linear systems. The first half of the module looks at the effects of non-linearity in mechanical systems described by differential equations, and discrete systems described by iterated maps. The logistic map is examined in detail, and the period-doubling route to chaos described. The concept of fractals, and their occurrence in chaotic systems is developed. The second half of the module covers some of these concepts in more detail. The origin of period-doubling and universality in the logistic map is identified. The phase space description of dynamical systems is refined by classifying their fixed points using matrix techniques. Finally, the phenomena of limit cycles, strange attractors and bifurcations are discussed.

name: LC Cities in Transition
description: This module introduces students to some of the key processes of socio-economic change shaping the fortunes of cities in Britain, Europe and North America.  In so doing, it highlights the role they play in shaping urban policy and planning priorities in cities.   The module draws on relevant international case studies of socio-economic change in major cities, including Barcelona, Manchester, Toronto, Berlin and Detroit.  Situating these changes in the context of globalisation, urban fragmentation and other recent intellectual developments in urban studies, this module exposes students to debates around how the physical fabric of contemporary cities is being remodelled and re-shaped by a range of different forces, processes and actors.  And it explores how major processes of change influence different kinds of cities and the diverse groups within urban society.  Here, then, is an early opportunity for students an early opportunity to consider how planners and other policy makers might respond to these new urban challenges.

name: LC Classics in the 20th and 21st Centuries
LC Climate Justice and Theorising Sustainability
description: This module explores notions of climate justice and how theories of sustainability are constantly changing and contested. It will first look at why climate justice is needed and how it relates to different groups, such as youth, marginalised groups etc before turning to consider what voices are heard/excluded and the mechanisms behind this. Particular attention will be paid to how climate action develops and how this is mediated by governments and multinational organisations, especially in relation to greenwashing. Various case study groups/locations will be examined to demonstrate the unequal power relations that exist within this area. The module then moves on the discuss how theories around sustainability are developed, what dominant discourses have developed and how these are contested. Again, attention will be paid to which voices gain prominence and the reasons behind this. Detailed attention will be paid to climate change deniers and how such theories are funded, spread and understood by the general public.

name: LC Cognitive Psychology
description: The module offers a comprehensive coverage of key areas of cognitive psychology, with a focus on perception, attention, memory and language. Students will learn the fundamental theories in cognitive psychology. In addition, the module follows a straight research-led teaching approach and will thus include knowledge about the latest advancements in the field.

name: LC Communication Skills and Data Analysis
LC Communication and Assessment in the Context of Mental Health & Deafness
description: This module aims to introduce students to basic considerations required for effective communication and interaction with D/deaf people. This will include not only British Sign Language but also non-verbal and written communication.
