Seminars begin with philosophical and conceptual questions concerning the problems of defining 'terrorism,' the concept of violence and its relationship with concepts of injustice, and the role of violence as an `instrument¿ in politics. These are followed by a series of discussions on the nature and scope of rightful resistance in contexts of acute political oppression, the debate on whether 'terrorism' is ever justified, the problem of interrogational torture in response to terrorist 'emergencies', and the legal and moral arguments for targeted killing of known terrorists. Some Key QuestionsWhat is `terrorism¿? Is it distinct from other uses of violence such as 'freedom fighting' or conventional war?Is the use of terrorism ever morally permissible or excusable?What, if any, political values can legitimate the use of violence and under what circumstances?What is the relationship between violence and political power?Under what circumstances are armed resistance and revolution permissible?Is interrogational torture by democratic states ever justified or excusable in response to terrorist threats?Is the targeted killing of terrorists an acceptable security measure from an ethical or legal point of view?

name: LM Theory and Practice of Leadership
LM Theory of Finance
description: This module is designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of financial markets, theories of asset pricing and the basic elements of a firm's pay-out policy and capital structure. It will begin by presenting the main mathematical methods used in modelling financial relationships.  There will be an examination of asset pricing under certainty, which forms the basis for determining the prices of fixed income securities.  The focus of the module will then switch to individual decision making under uncertainty, which provides the foundation for modern portfolio theory and determining the prices of risky assets.  Alternative asset pricing theories will be investigated, including the capital asset pricing model, arbitrage pricing theory and state preference theory.

name: LM Theory, Methods and Practice
description: This module builds on learning undertaken in the Social Work Skills, Values and Approaches module and explores the theories and methods that underpin social work practice. There will be a particular focus on incorporating and learning from the perspectives of service users and carers in undertaking processes of assessment and in the planning and delivery of social work support and intervention.

name: LM Theory, Methods and Practice Placement 1 (Step Up to Social Work)
LM Thermal Energy - conversion, storage and applications
LM Thinking Otherwise: Decolonial Approaches to Contemporary Thought and Culture
description: This module offers students the opportunity to build on their critical skills accumulated over the course of their university studies by engaging with contemporary ideas that have been challenging the exclusive ways in which cultures and societies have been understood since the advent of modernity. With a focus on the experiences of peripheral and semi-peripheral societies in the Portuguese-speaking world, students will assess key contemporary changes in terms of the organisation of culture, attitudes towards the environment, economy, as well as diversity in terms of gender, sexuality, race, religion and abilities that have been changing the world. Through the further study of key theoretical formulations in fields such as decolonial studies, postcolonial studies, cultural studies, comparative literature, ecocriticism, gender studies, critical race theory and disability studies, students will be able to critically analyse the impact and the transformative potential of critical thinking and culture in the 21st century.  All primary and secondary sources, as well as lecture slides and classes are in English.

name: LM Topics in Global Justice
description: This module will focus on applications of the dominant contemporary moral theories to significant issues in global ethics and politics. The topics to be approached on the basis of these theories are a selection of the following debates: world poverty and the obligations of the affluent; justice and the global economic order; global distributive justice; structural injustice; human rights theory; human development and care ethics; climate change; cosmopolitanism vs priority for compatriots; immigration and freedom of movement; just war theory; terrorism, humanitarian intervention; global gender justice; issues around a global 'democratic deficit'.

name: LM Topics in Money and Banking
description: none

name: LM Tourette's Syndrome
description: Tourette syndrome (TS) is a neurodevelopmental condition characterised by multiple tics and frequently associated with behavioural symptoms. This module covers the epidemiology, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, and treatment of TS. Both clinical and neurobiological data are reviewed. The focus of the module includes a variety of TS-related conditions (OCD, ADHD and other developmental disorders) which affect diagnosis, presentation, and management. The sessions include clinical scenarios and challenges posed by TS in both childhood and adulthood.

name: LM Towns, tombs, and temples: the archaeology of ancient Egypt
description: This module offers an introduction to ancient Egyptian history from Predynastic times to the periods of Ptolemaic and Roman rule through the archaeological record. While popular visions of ancient Egypt have traditionally been dominated by elite culture, in this module we will diversify our approach by paying attention to other non-monumental aspects of material culture as well. Each weekly seminar session will focus on one key archaeological site, where we will explore the deep history of the site, the main landmarks and artefacts associated with it, and its wider implications, including an overview of past and current fieldwork. These sites will serve as case studies to illustrate a number of current debates in Egyptian archaeology, such as the alleged existence of a middle class, the recurring description of Egypt as a 'civilisation without cities', or to what extent non-royal tombs may be seen as a reflection of personal identity.

name: LM Transferable skills (Clin Psych)
description: Topics will typically include working with organisations, working in teams, disseminating research, writing skills (including for the broader public), presentation skills, CV preparation, and interview skills.

name: LM Transforming healthcare and service design
LM Translating for Business DL
description: This module aims to provide students with solid training in translating in their chosen language pair. It will focus on translating texts for businesses and organisations, across a range of sectors (e.g. consumer goods, retail, charities and cultural institutions), with particular emphasis on general or technical texts for a general readership (consumers, the public, non-specialist readers). Typical genres covered will be brochures, product descriptions, press releases, instructions and webpages.  The material introduces key concepts and skills (client interaction, information mining, translating using appropriate strategies, use of corpora and parallel texts and revising/editing/quality assurance. The following tools are introduced: general IT resources, online dictionaries, search engines, termbases, aligned texts and corpus tools. Students  will also have the opportunity to focus on practical translation work, consolidating  the topics covered in the module. Students will have the opportunity to practise translation in both directions but will choose one target language for the end-of-module assessment.\nThere will also be an 'open' route for this module, to allow students to join the MA by distance if they are not working in one of the language pairings we offer. Students on this route will complete the same assessment (see details below), but the translation will not itself be assessed, only the commentary.

name: LM Translation Technology DL
description: This module is designed to provide students with hands-on experience of a range of technologies applied to the study and practice of translation. Students will learn how to use the tools most commonly required by employers, such as translation memory and terminology management tools, and critically assess the technological requirements for different translation projects. They will also gain a sophisticated understanding of how translation tools work and how they have impacted translation, both as a discipline and as a practice.

name: LM Translation and Language Pedagogy
description: This module explains the curricular design process for translator training and discussed in depth the main pedagogical approaches and methods currently employed in contexts as varied as: language teaching targeted specifically at trainee translators; translation teaching in modern languages degree programmes; translation used as a learning and assessment tool in the teaching of general and specialized language. Students will be encouraged to critically assess the theoretical and practical issues involved in the use of these translation pedagogies and their application in their own translation or language teaching teaching. The module consists of eight units:1) Introduction to Translation Pedagogy2) Translator Training: from Market Needs to Teaching Resources3) Translator Training: from Teaching Activities to Course Evaluation4) Language Teaching for Trainee Translators: Approach, Design, Procedure5) Translation Teaching for Language Learners: Approach6) Translation Teaching for Language Learners: Design and Procedure7) Language Teaching and Translation: Approach8) Language Teaching and Translation: Design and Procedure Unit 1 gives an overview of the diverse educational contexts where translator and/or interpreter skills are taught, i.e. undergraduate and postgraduate programmes that aim to prepare professional translators; dedicated translation modules that form part of the curricular design of modern languages degree programmes; language modules at undergraduate and graduate level where translation is used as an effective means of developing communicative and intercultural competences alongside other learning and assessment tools.Unit 2 deals with the most general aspects of curricular design in translator training, i.e. market needs, aims and objectives, student needs, course content, teaching resources.Unit 3 deals with more specific aspects of curricular design in translator training, i.e. teaching activities, assessment tasks, course evaluation.Unit 4 analyses the methods employed in language teaching for trainee translators, using a three-level model, where method is theoretically related to approach, it is organizationally determined by design and is practically realised in procedure.Unit 5 and 6 examine the approach, design and procedure adopted in dedicated translation modules that form part of the education of modern languages students.Unit 7 and 8 examine the approach, design and procedure adopted by language teaching methods that use translation as an additional learning and assessment tool.

name: LM Translation in a Professional Context
LM Translational Cognitive Neuroscience
description: This module will provide a comprehensive introduction into the fundamental physical principles that underlie various brain imaging techniques and how they can be used to study human behaviour and brain structure/function in both health and disease. This module will also provide insight in to what causes neurological and psychiatric disorders, and how translational neuroimaging research can be used to develop intervention strategies and improve long-term prognosis and treatments in mental health.

name: LM Tudor Terrors: inner worlds, hidden worlds, new worlds DL
LM Turning the Pages: Manuscript and Print, Past and Present
description: This module explores medieval and early modern books from the perspectives of art history, political and socio-cultural history, conservation and digital humanities. It introduces students to the ways in which manuscripts were made and what we can learn from them about the past as material objects. It will examine the social and political value that these often lavishly illustrated productions had for aristocratic patrons like the Burgundian dukes. It will consider the role of images in books in relation to the texts, as beyond simple 'illustration'. Through consideration of inventories and original books themselves, it will also look at how manuscripts and printed books functioned in the everyday lives of ordinary people, as repositories of prayer, important dates, and mnemonic images. The module will also examine the fate of medieval and early modern books in the nineteenth century, and the policies/politics of libraries in the twentieth and twenty-first. The module will draw closely on the collections in the Cadbury Research Library and encourage students to engage with the numerous online archives available through institutions such as the British Library, John Rylands Library, and the Bibliothèque nationale. Students will therefore not only gain a familiarity with pre-modern sources, but will also be encouraged to engage critically with questions relating to changing notions of use, conservation, research and access.

name: LM U21 Advanced International Study
description: This module brings together expertise from the universities of Birmingham, Delhi and Melbourne to deliver an advanced and internationally comparative analysis of the interactions between government and society on major areas of public policy.  The module offers University of Birmingham masters students an option to study with masters students from these other institutions, taught by a team of specialists from the participating universities, and focused on develop an advanced and in-depth understanding of government and society in these countries.  It will enhance the learning experience, and increase students' transferable skills (e.g. by being able to work effectively in a multi-cultural and interdisciplinary context and in teams composed of different nationalities).

name: LM US Foreign and Defence Policy
description: This course is intended to provide a comprehensive understanding of the factors, influences and actors which have shaped and are shaping American foreign and security policy, especially in the post-WWII period.  No previous experience of American politics is required for this course as lectures in the early sessions will provide much of the basic knowledge required by beginners to the topic.

name: LM Ultracold Atoms and Quantum Gases
LM Understanding Medieval Documents
description: This module will introduce students to the study of medieval documents in their original, unedited forms. The first five weeks of the course will introduce the students to some of the basic formulae found in administrative documents. The second half of the course (weeks 6-10) will introduce them to the basics of palaeography (common abbreviations; different hands). The focus of the course would be on documents in Latin and Middle English documents, but it would be possible to vary the content according to student demand and staff availability.

name: LM Understanding School Improvement
description: This module will provide you with a rigorous, theoretically and evidence informed, view of effects of teaching and school organisation on students' learning. It will enable you to judge the extent to which claims for preferring one approach to another can currently be justified by available evidence whilst also providing a basis for developing your own practise and supporting the development of others and the institution in which you work. The module review effects of teaching on a range of outcomes including attainment, inclusion and aspirations.

name: LM Understanding and Developing Leadership Practice
LM Understanding the Common and Diverse Needs of Autistic Adults and Young People
LM Universal midwifery care across the childbearing continuum
description: This module aligns to NMC (2019) Standards of Proficiency for Midwives  Domain 3  and will introduce students to key concepts, policy and practice related to universal midwifery care.  Exploring how universal care impacts on the life course of women, other childbearing people and newborn infants and how working in partnership can optimise positive outcomes, to include identifying and preventing complications, learners will examine the homogeneity and diversity of women and other childbearing people's lived experiences and the resources and opportunities available to them, to include the impact of inequalities and the role of the midwife in enhancing population health. Learners will develop knowledge and understanding of anatomy, physiology, genetics, genomics and medicines related to childbearing, the sexual and reproductive health of adolescent girls and women, fetal development, neonatal adaptation and infant feeding. Opportunities to continue to develop academic study, leadership, research and teamwork skills will be provided through the use of Enquiry Based Learning.

name: LM Urban Design And Property Development
LM Urban Economics and Real Estate
description: This module provides an important bridge and specialism of real estate and urban economics, to studies in urban and regional planning. International in focus, this module brings the discipline of economics (including finance) to the subject focus of urban studies and real estate. Particular attention is given to the wider social and environmental concerns for economics in urban areas, as well as the practice and policy issues arising globally in real estate development.

name: LM Urban Environments in the Global South
description: Is garbage always 'bad'? Are parks 'good'? Are sewers political? This course will explore the social, political, and economic dimensions - processes, structures, and actors - that shape urban environments in the global South. To do this, we will draw on urban political ecology as a conceptual approach, and engage with the scholarship in South Asian and African urbanism, and post-colonial studies. Urban political ecologists understand cities to be (re)produced through a dialectical relationship between society and the biophysical environment. These processes often result in highly unequitable urban environments. In this module, we will explore socio-natural dynamics across resource and environmental service domains, as well as examining key actors and contemporary policy debates.

name: LM Urban Poverty + Policy
description: The course aims to introduce the central issues and policies in relation to processes of urbanization and urban development in the south. In particular it aims to: 1. Address the nature of urban growth and development in the south 2. Outline the dimensions of urban poverty 3. Analyse the range of policy options available to confront urban poverty 4. Critically assess the above range of options and the role of international agencies and national governments.

name: LM Urban Property Development
description: This 20 credit module provides an introduction to property development processes in urban areas and the roles played by the private and public sector actors. It examines complexities of urban property markets across a range of sectors and the financial considerations behind development decisions.The starting point for this module is the need for planners in the public and private sectors to have a sound grasp of property development and its commercial underpinnings. The overall aim is to enable students to develop an understanding of the property development process and to develop skills in generating creative solutions to the challenge of achieving viable, sustainable development in urban areas.\n

name: LM Urbanity and wellbeing
description: The module will provide opportunities to explore conceptual approaches to wellbeing within urban contexts both in the UK and internationally and implement them in empirical research or policy analysis. There are three key sections of the module: 1) Geographies of wellbeing that includes the impact of physical environment and pollution, 'healthy cities', wellbeing metrics, vulnerability and social exclusion; 2) Cultural diversity, wellbeing, and art; 3) Urban design, planning and wellbeing including participatory design and special imaginaries of wellbeing. The module has been created within the European University for Well-Being – EUniWell and has been planned based on consultations with GEES students.

name: LM Using Enabling Practice with Autistic Adults and Young People
LM Using Literature to Teach English Language
LM Values, Assessment and Communication in AMHP Practice  - Refresher
description: The module explores the skills and understanding required in the assessment and in the implementation of Anti-Discriminatory Practice within Approved Mental Health Professional practice. Consideration is given to specific issues arising in AMHP assessment work, such as assessing women, children, older people, people with learning disabilities and members of black communities, and applying a strengths model of assessment within an AMHP context.  \n

name: LM Values, Assessment and Communication in Approved Mental Health Professional Practice
description:
The module enables candidates working towards accreditation as an Approved Mental Health Professional to submit work for assessment, demonstrating their skills and understanding in assessment and in the implementation of Anti-Discriminatory Practice within Approved Mental Health Professional practice. 

Syllabus

Consideration of specific issues arising in AMHP assessment work with women, children, older people, people with learning disabilities and members of black communities.

Making a reality of Anti-Discriminatory Practice in the context of compulsion.

Application of a strengths model of assessment within an AMHP context.

The practicalities of conducting assessments  - using the Mental Health Act Manual and available consultation, checking and lodging the medical recommendations, completing the application itself.

Cultural and functional difference and the assessment of mental health needs.

name: LM Varieties of Politics: The Comparative Politics of Parties, Institutions and Regimes
LM Virtual and Mixed Reality Design and Technologies
LM Water Resources Studies and Further Topics
LM Water and Health
description: The module considers the main health hazards associated with water used as a food or ingredient, including the typical control methods used in the UK to ensure safety of supply.  Recreational use of water in public swimming pools will also be considered.

name: LM Wellbeing in Education Based Settings
description: This module offers an introduction to the theory and research behind wellbeing in education-based settings. The module will cover examine interventions in schools, in higher education, and in broader educational contexts (e.g. sport). It will explore the broader policy context(s) and interface between education policy and practice through exploring: the changing roles of teachers; professional responsibilities and expectations in different education contexts; identification of need and help-seeking behaviours of pupils; the support structures in education institutions; wellbeing and harm prevention; mental health and wellbeing strategies; and the range of interventions within different settings. The module will have an interdisciplinary and international focus.

name: LM Where There Is Discord: Making Thatcher's Britain (Masters): A
LM Where There Is Discord: Making Thatcher's Britain (Masters): B
LM Who Do You Think You Are? Family Histories and History through Families (Masters): A
LM Who Do You Think You Are? Family Histories and History through Families (Masters): B
LM Wind Engineering and Bluff Body Aerodynamics
LM Working in a Multi-Agency and Multidisciplinary Context
description: This module will explore characteristics of multi-disciplinary and multi-agency working within adult care services and strategies for managing the difficulties that can arise.    Whilst addressing all elements of the common framework of knowledge and skills, the module addresses particularly those elements concerning inter-professional, multi-agency working, networking, community based services and accountability.\n

name: LM Workplace-based Learning in Genomic Medicine
description: This module is structured around the completion of a portfolio of workplace-based learning relevant to genomic medicine. Following an initial introductory day at Birmingham to explain the requirements of the module, the students will first prepare a proposal, identifying one or more suitable case studies within their workplace and a suitable local supervisor. The module leads will discuss the suitability of the proposal for write-up as a portfolio of study, including guidance on information governance (virtually or in person). Once agreed, the students will undertake the work-based practice (which should extend significantly beyond their normal role, e.g. attending additional clinics and MDT meetings) and record their activities and their reflections in the Portfolio. There will be University support during the module and guidance for portfolio write-up. Beyond the initial introductory day, timing is flexible and largely defined by the student, although student presentations will be grouped to allow several students to make their final presentations on the same day.

name: LM Writing Early Modern History: Sources and Approaches DL
LM Writing the History of Warfare
description: This module addresses general questions relating to the historiography of warfare and considers how the subject has evolved from ancient times to the present. The principal schools of military history are considered together with those individuals who have made a major contribution to the evolution of the discipline.This module is designed to be more general and reflective than other War Studies modules, to aid independent thinking and reflection by students on the subject they have studied for three years at university.

name: LM Written Dissertation in Film and Television
description: The dissertation is an original enquiry into a closely defined aspect of Film or Television theory and/or practice.   It will provide training and experience that will prepare the student for either PhD research or professional work in the television and production industry.

name: Language and Communication in Deaf and Hearing Impaired Pupils (Distance Education)
description: None

name: Language, Discourse and Society
description: This module provides an introduction to sociolinguistics, the study of the interrelationship between language and society. Specifically, it is concerned with sociolinguistics and its relevnace to language learning and teaching. Topics include multilingualism (code-switching, bilingualism, politics of language), discourses and identities (with specific reference to ethnicity and gender), literacy in its social context.\n

name: Law
description: 1.  Introduction to the court structure in England and Wales.2a.  Basic contract law.  What is a contract?  What happens when there is a breach of contract?2b.  Working through problem questions relating to contract law.3a.  Introduction to the law of negligence.  How does the tort of negligence work?  Defences to claims of negligence.3b.  Working through problems questions relating to the tort of negligence.4.  An introduction to the law of patents.

name: Leadership and collaboration to support colleagues, other professionals, pupils with special educational needs
description:
This module focuses on four aspects of the SENCO's role in leading and collaborating with colleagues, support professionals, pupils with special educational needs and/or disabilities, and their families. 

Providing professional direction to the work of others 
Providing professional direction to the work of a range of colleagues is considered within this aspect of the module. This includes: leading policy and strategic school-wide developments pertaining to SEN and/or disability issues; the identification and promotion of best practice; ensuring compliance with statutory responsibilities; supporting staff to achieve positive working relations with pupils with SEN and/ or disabilities and their parents/carers.

Leadership and development of staff
This aspect of the module focuses on the role of the SENCO in identifying and providing appropriately differentiated professional development opportunities for staff (e.g. for newly qualified teachers, teaching assistants and other adults in education support roles). It also examines the use of professional standards (e.g. for teachers and higher level teaching assistants) as a means to developing staff knowledge, skills and understanding in relation to SEN and/or disability. The purpose and value of a range of staff development approaches will also be discussed, including coaching, mentoring, and the identification and coordination of appropriate internal/external opportunities for training. This discussion will be informed by research evidence related to school based professional development and impact factors.

Working collaboratively with external agencies
The capacity to assume responsibility (leading, developing, and supporting) for accessing key sources of external support and expertise (e.g. local authority learning/impairment specific services; special school outreach; social/health service professionals; voluntary organisations) is a key part of the SENCO's role. This aspect of the module examines the concept and practice of multi-agency and partnership working (e.g. through the use of the common assessment framework and 'team around the child' approaches; through systematic collaboration with Connexions or other professionals advising/supporting transfer and transition for pupils with SEN and/or disabilities). It also discusses the interpretation and use of specialist information (e.g. advice provided in reports by educational psychologists or speech and language therapists).

Working in partnership with pupils and families
Ensuring pupils with SEN and/or disabilities - regardless of their level of need - are involved in key aspects of the provision made for them. This aspect of the module identifies ways in which SENCOs can support this kind of participation (e.g. through individual education planning; involvement in annual reviews; decision-making about the use of 'withdrawal' approaches to teaching or the way that of other services such as occupational therapy, physiotherapy or speech, language and communication therapy are accessed by pupils).

Communicating effectively with parents/carers, taking account of their views and providing them with timely and relevant information is also a critical part of the SENCO's role. This aspect of the module introduces concepts of both participation and partnership, providing opportunities for critical appraisal with reference to theory and practice.

name: Leadership for School Improvement
description: Leadership and teamwork have been consistently identified in research studies and OFSTED reports as among the key factors that contribute to school improvement.  This module will focus on the qualities and skills that will enable the participants to play a more effective part – as members of management teams – in the leadership of their school or area of responsibility.  The module will also examine the needs, demands, and aspirations of the various stake holders in the participants' own schools; the culture in their schools; the vision for the future development of their schools; and planning and managing change.

name: Leadership in Public Services
description:
This module introduces students to:
The development and dynamics of management and governance of public services
The role of the state in society
Contemporary issues in the delivery of services delivered by governments

name: Legal Aspects
description:
The module aims to give students a systematic understanding of how the legal process has influenced and continues to influence the development of occupational health both nationally and internationally. Factors contributing to the shaping of legal aspects of occupational health practice are also discussed.
The module brings together from all other modules the role of the regulatory process within occupational health.  The participants in this module will gain a comprehensive understanding of relevant legislation within the UK and EU framework.
The module includes: Review of how law making, regulatory and legal processes have influenced the evolution of occupational health practice and their current relevance for the practitioner; State involvement in Occupational Health and Safety including Health and Safety risks and the English legal system; Development and implementation of risk management systems, the role of the HSE and local authority inspectors; Employment law including discrimination, DDA and performance at work.
The students will learn on how legislation relevant to occupational health is applied and interpreted including the implications for non-compliance.

name: Li International Work Placement B (Singapore)
description:
The IWP B module is a continuation of IWP A and is an integral component  of the International Business Programmes, comprising an internship of at least 15 weeks and either a 4000 word International Work Essay (BSc International Business) or two 2000 word International Work Essays - one in English and the same essay written in the foreign language - (BSc International Business with Language), for which students will be very carefully prepared during the second year of their programme. The module may be substituted by International Study B which will be followed by the vast majority of students.
This Level I 60 credit module provides an opportunity to: improve the student's understanding of different approaches to business management; to live in a different society and culture; and (where applicable) to develop foreign language proficiency. The aim is to highlight differences in culture, business practice and socio-political economic factors impacting on business.
If the student chooses to work abroad, their placement will be vetted by the Year Abroad Co-ordinator, SIM, or AIESEC. The student will normally be expected to arrange a placement through Birmingham or SIM.

name: Liberal Arts and Natural Sciences Independent Research Project
description: The Independent Research Project challenges students to develop a focused engagement with interdisciplinarity. Students identify a significant topic or problem rooted in interdisciplinary study. They test its viability in consultation with a supervisor (appointed to guide and advise on their progress) and define its parameters in consultation with the supervisor and with reference to current scholarship and knowledge. Students move on to design and test an appropriate methodology, and conclude by producing a substantial portfolio of independent research.The findings are presented in:(1) a research paper (10,000 words) comprising: (i) the identification and description of a significant research problem which benefits from interdisciplinary approaches; (ii) a review of the state of relevant current scholarship, evidence, and the disciplinary boundaries, approaches, and methodologies involved in tackling this problem; and (iii) a piece of sustained analysis addressing the research topic or problem, with full scholarly apparatus as appropriate to the disciplines;(2) an academic poster articulating the methodologies identified and adopted, outlining any challenges addressed, summarizing the development of the argument, and mediating the key conclusions derived.

name: Liberal Arts and Sciences Independent Research Project
description: The Independent Research Project challenges students to develop a focused engagement with interdisciplinarity, and to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of a range of relevant approaches across disciplinary boundaries. Students identify a significant topic or problem rooted in interdisciplinary study. They test its viability in consultation with a supervisor (appointed to guide and advise on their progress) and define its parameters in consultation with the supervisor and with reference to current scholarship and knowledge. Students move on to design and test an appropriate methodology, and conclude by producing a substantial portfolio of independent research demonstrating advanced analytical and conceptual skills.The findings are presented in:(1) a research paper (15,000 words) comprising: (i) the identification and description of a significant research problem which benefits from interdisciplinary approaches; (ii) a review of the state of relevant current scholarship, evidence, and the disciplinary boundaries, approaches, and methodologies involved in tackling this problem; (iii) a piece of sustained analysis addressing the research topic or problem, with full scholarly apparatus as appropriate to the disciplines; (iv) synoptic scoping work addressing how and why the conclusions drawn are interesting and reflecting on their potential for wider significance; (v) integrated analysis of challenges and opportunities identified as a result of the programme of research.(2) an academic poster articulating the methodologies identified and adopted, outlining any challenges addressed, summarizing the development of the argument, mediating the key conclusions derived, and identifying any challenges or risks associated with future progress in the topic.

name: Long-term Conditions and Support Care for Children
Loss and Renewal (Integrated Case Based Learning 5)
MSc CBT Dissertation (Literature Review)
description: The aims of this module are for students to carry out and write-up a substantial literature review in an area of/ or closely related to cognitive behavioural theory and/or CBT practice. This will entail demonstration of a comprehensive, systematic and critical awareness of the theory and practice of CBT within their chosen clinical area. This systematic understanding will be demonstrated through critical awareness of current problems and issues regarding application of theory and models, and new insights and initiatives relating to clinical practice. The module is designed to provide 40 credits of the required 60 credit dissertation component of a taught Master's degree.

name: MSc Dissert Mar 19 (MIB DLW)
description: The dissertation module is an opportunity for students to carry out an independent - though supervised - applied research project. The work will usually apply subject knowledge from one specialist subject area, and so will be an opportunity for students to demonstrate comprehensive and thorough understanding of that subject area. The supervisor is typically a scholar in the chosen subject discipline. Normally dissertations are 'applied' and use primary data, but "desk based" projects are possible with the prior agreement of the supervisor.The purpose of the dissertation module is to develop students' ability to apply their business knowledge and skills to address a business problem. To quote the Association of MBAs: '[Students] will develop knowledge of the core business areas … and learn how to apply such knowledge effectively in a business environment. This is facilitated in particular on the Dissertation module'.Whilst being practical and applied, the dissertation is above all else, a critical work.

name: Management of Change
description: The Management of Change module will introduce students to organisational change and its significance for organisations. Students will be exposed to the multiple perspectives, models and analytical frameworks for analysing organisational change, and how change can be managed. Success in the management of change is perhaps best achieved by understanding how NOT to change an organisation. Therefore the module will spend some time exploring and critically evaluating examples of failures to manage change effectively. The module will discuss and analyse the role of senior managers and 'change agents'. The module will also introduce students to the conflicts, and dilemmas encountered by middle managers in implementing change.

name: Management of Gynaecology in the Community
description:
This module is aimed at general practitioners and practice nurses working in the community required to develop competencies in the management of gynaecological disorders to an advanced level.
The module will provide accredited certification and validation of competencies including skills to enable autonomous practice in dealing with more complex problems and the ability to critically evaluate current research in the field of gynaecology. 
The module will comprise:
1. Pre contact reading demonstrating how evidence based practice is implemented effectively in practice and preparation of community based cases, 
2. Three days contact time involving lectures and seminars and interactive, facilitated sessions to discuss the key theoretical and clinical aspects of gynaecology management.  Students will contribute to discussion, analysis and application of the theoretical perspectives that underpin practice involving critical evaluation of current research.
3.  A minimum of 10 5 sessions within community and/or hospital based clinics to provide opportunities for experience in required practical competencies and to allow students to acquire and demonstrate skills. 
4. Course work, written and practical assessments.

name: Managing Global Operations
description: The Managing Global Operations module provides a general introduction to Operations and Process Management across extended international networks. The module explains how the Operations function fits within the organisation overall. The module also explores how actors outside the core Operations function have a role in, and engage in the management of processes.\nThe module will show students the wide organisational scope of Operations Management activity and will establish an understanding of the core concepts underlying the discipline. The module is introductory in nature, and while focussed primarily on large, global organisations, also looks at small organisations and even the management of  individual "human" processes. The module is intended as an introduction to operations management in both service and manufacturing organisations. Its intention is to provide the building blocks of those basic principles which are broadly applicable to most organisations. The module will introduce the basic principles of the "lean" operation, and show how managers can adopt lean principles in practice.

name: Managing Global Service
description: The Managing Global Service (MGS) module is concerned with improving organisations to make them better for customers and service providers. The module will develop students' understanding of the concepts, tools and techniques relating to process design and delivery. The module will develop students' understanding of the concepts, tools and techniques relating to process design and delivery, including the analysis of process design from the customer's perspective.\n\nThe module is integrative in approach and so uses analytical lenses from marketing, organisational behaviour, strategy and behavioural psychology. Case, and other illustrative material in the module comes from both profit and non-profit sectors, worldwide.

name: Managing Public Money
description: The aim of this module is to highlight the importance of effective financial management in public sector organisations and define the concepts behind public economics. It will also concentrate on the changing role of finance and how that affects the support of new developments in public services. Students will gain key skills required to ensure the effective management of public money and explore real-world scenarios that can be applied directly to their professional lives.

name: Managing in a Political Environment
description: This module focuses on the importance of political leadership in public service management. The module introduces students to the main theoretical perspectives on political leadership and the role of officers/civil servants, and how these have developed and relate to the dynamics of the management and governance of public services. The module includes research on international perspectives about political leadership. Students will study the roles of public sector managers in supporting political leadership, including the provision of expert advice, and the skills needed to manage the interface between political and managerial leadership.

name: Managing in the Information Age
description: This module focuses on the changes in managing public services as new ICT and knowledge management practices are adopted across public services.\nThe module introduces students to the main theoretical perspectives on information management as it is applied within the public sector. Students analyse how ICT has been adopted and relate to the dynamics of the management and governance of public services. The module includes research on international perspectives about information management within public services, and the increasing importance of  digital and social media within public organisations.\nStudents critically review developments in the gathering, processing and dissemination of data through computer systems. They also examine the managerial and organisational issues associated with ICTs and the emerging e-governance agenda.

name: Many Particle and Quantum Field Theory
Marketing
description: The marketing module provides an introduction to the nature of marketing and explains how the marketing function fits within the firm overall. The module also looks at how actors outside the core marketing function have a role in, and engage in marketing activity.The module aims to provide a critical and systematic understanding of theory and practice in marketing. Insights into the relationship between marketing and strategy, marketing and the customer, marketing and operations and marketing and the brand will emerge from service, manufacturing, technological and consumer product perspectives. The module will trace the development and application of marketing theory embracing the experiences of FMCG approaches, through to business to business and marketing relationships and by critically identifying theoretical synergies which underpin marketing decision making.The module will show students the broad scope of marketing activity and will establish an understanding of the core concepts underlying the field.

name: Marketing Strategy
description: The Marketing Strategy module seeks to extend the depth of knowledge about the development of marketing strategies, and their implementation. On completion of the module students will understand the processes adopted by marketing professionals: analysis, development of marketing strategies, and critically, the ways in which these strategies are implemented, and refined in response to tactical / short term imperatives.The module will help students develop their ability to: choose the most effective analytic strategies, assess implementation and managerial implications; and critically evaluate strategic marketing analysis methods with respect to their validity and relevance in a range of marketplaces. The module will also explore the impact of marketing decisions upon the long-term evolution of markets; and market structures in terms of customers, competitors and market channels.

name: Materials Characterisation
description: The module will introduce a range of techniques for characterising materials.  These comprise microscopy (optical and electron), non-destructive testing, x-ray diffraction, calorimetry, surface analysis and various techniques for measuring electrical and magnetic properties.

name: Materials for Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Technologies
description: The aim of the module is to provide an insight into the critical role materials science plays in a range of hydrogen and fuel cell technologies. The following will be included: 1.\tMaterials in the Hydrogen Energy Economy - overview; 2.\tMethods of Hydrogen Production; 3.\tHydrogen Storage; 4.\tPEM Fuel Cells; 5.\tSolid Oxide Fuel Cells; 6.\tDesign of integrated hydrogen and fuel cell energy systems.

name: Materials for Sustainable Environmental Technologies (MSET)
description: This module will relate to the materials issues related to sustainable environmental technologies.  The module will be based on the concept of a Hydrogen Economy and the production of the hydrogen will be from clean energy sources such as wind or solar.  The materials issues relating to these will be described and discussed.  The hydrogen will be produced largely by electrolysis and materials issues relating to this technology will be considered.  Hydrogen from biomass will also be examined.  Materials for hydrogen storage and transmission will be discussed.  Fuel cells will be considered in depth and more general issues such as energy efficiency will be discussed, focusing on soft and hard magnets.  The energy content of materials will also form a part of this module.

name: Measurement Techniques
description:
This module will introduce the wide range of characterisation methods that are available witin Chemical Engineering and Metallurgy and Materials. The module concentrates on techniques that students have not been exposed to at undergraduate level and the main emphasis is on characterisation of the microstructure of a product. The module will consist of both lectures and practical laboratory demonstrations. The techniques to be covered will be:
Thermal Properties
Micromanipulation
Optical Microscopy and image analysis
Atomic force microscopy
Surface Plasmon Resonance
Indentation
Particle Image Velocimetry
Positron Emission Particle Tracking

name: Media and Popular Culture in Africa
description: The module offers students the opportunity to engage with popular texts and performances in contemporary African genres. Run as a series of seminars, each meeting will focus on discussion of a selected text or assemblage of materials (audio, video, performance transcription) with which the students will have familiarized themselves in advance. Special attention will be paid to emerging and locally-based genres such as neo-traditional poetry; improvised popular theatre; popular print culture; and television and video drama. Drawing on translations of recorded performance, this module will explore theories of improvisation and popular creativity in Africa today. Literary and performance genres will be related to contemporary social and political developments in Africa.

name: Medical and Surgical Management of Oral Disease
description: This module is designed specifically for distance learning to provide an update of the techniques available in contemporary dental practice for the assessment and management of patients with periodontitis, diseases of the oral cavity and systemic diseases of relevance to dentistry and to develop advanced assessment skills when managing patients requiring oral surgical procedures.Students will evaluate and reflect on evidence from the latest literature, evaluate the current research trends and understand how to apply this knowledge to specific clinical situations.In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: Medicine in Society: Psychiatry and Psychopathology in the Arts
description: This module will involve 75 hours of student study time in total.  Via the introductory lectures and small-group teaching, students will be introduced to current concepts, theories and controversies of the emerging field of Medical Humanities.  Building upon this, students will explore such topics as the description of psychopathology in autobiographical narratives; the representation of madness in fictional narrative and feature films; and the value of poetry, biography, letters and journals in medical education.  Students are expected to be competent independent learners.  They will identify an area of particular interest for independent in-depth study which will be assessed by a 3,000 word essay.  Individual supervisions will be available for students who need guidance in terms of direction and defining topics for their essay.

name: Medicine in Society: The Neurobiology of Mental Illness
description: This module will involve 75 hours of student study time in total.  Via the introductory lectures and small-group teaching, students will be introduced to current concepts, theories and controversies in our understanding of the neurobiology of mental illnesses.  Students are expected to be competent independent learners.  They will identify an area of particular interest for independent in-depth study which will be assessed by a 3,000 word essay.  Individual supervisions will be available for students who need guidance in terms of direction and defining topics for their essay.

name: Medicine in Society: The Neurobiology of Psychological Processes
description: This module will involve 75 hours of student study time in total.  Via the introductory lectures and small-group teaching, students will be introduced to current concepts, theories and controversies in our understanding of the biological basis of processes of the mind and behaviour.  Building upon their core knowledge of the neurosciences, students will explore such topics as perception, emotion, aggression, stress, sex, sleep, learning, memory and language.  Students are expected to be competent independent learners.  They will identify an area of particular interest for independent in-depth study which will be assessed by a 3,000 word essay.  Individual supervisions will be available for students who need guidance in terms of direction and defining topics for their essay.

name: Mental Health Care in the Community
description:
This module is provided as a CPD module for GP's, Practice Nurses, Primary Care Mental Health Workers and GP trainees who have an interest in developing an enhanced understanding of mental health care in the community. Where relevant and with the agreement of the programme concerned, it may also be taken as an optional module by existing MSc programmes within the College.

Current research indicates that approximately 1:4 individuals will experience a problem, at some point in their lives, regarding their mental health. Recent national policies have highlighted the capacity issues for Primary Care organisations in dealing with common mental health problems. Research also indicates that 1:3 patients within primary care will have a psychological component to their health related problems. As Primary Care organisations play a pivotal part in the commissioning of mental health care effectively addressing mental health issues will enhance the overall care for patients.

A key component of the module is to address relevant knowledge and skills to enhance access to and effectiveness of primary care services and mental health care delivery through considering both evidence-based and practice based innovative approaches. This module will focus upon issues directly relevant to mental health within primary care clinical practice, using a bio-psychosocial framework to enable module participants to develop knowledge and skills in evidence-based interventions, mental health diagnosis, assessment and screening, pharmacological and psychological treatment interventions, including cognitive-behavioural approaches, collaborative case management and community engagement. 

The module will cover the following themes;  
Mental health in older patients
Mental health in younger patients
Managing uncertainty in mental health

name: Metabolic Perspectives in Exercise and Nutrition
Mind, Brain and Models
description: The module intends to give the students the skills to implement computational models capturing the properties of neural and cognitive functions.  Lectures will provide an overview of computational/mathematical modelling in neuroscience, psychophysics and psychology with emphasis on the area of expertise of the lecturers.  Topics will be organised from low level processing of information at the neural level (i.e., integrate and fire neurons) to high-level cognitive phenomena (i.e., attention and action planning).  Matlab programming will be used to implement the models discussed in the lectures.

name: Molecular Mechanisms in Immune Cell Differentiation and Function
Moral Behaviour and Doping in Sport & Exercise
Multi-Sensory Impairment:  Communications (Distance Education)
description: An account of normal communicative development forms the basis for discussion of the assessment and development of communication in learners with multi-sensory impairments.  Strategies for promoting interaction and for responding to challenging behaviour are considered.

name: Multi-Sensory Impairment:  Education and Provision (Distance Education)
description: Interdisciplinary working and work with families are examined, together with a range of curricular and teaching approaches appropriate for learners with multi-sensory impairments.  The influence of approaches and services developed in other countries is considered, and current provision in the UK is explored with discussion of the factors affecting the development of policy and services.

name: Multi-Sensory Impairment:  Sensory Impairment (Distance Education)
description: The processes of sight and hearing are described to provide a context for accounts of functional sensory assessment and the interpretation of clinical assessment results.  The use of assessment information to change practice is explored in terms of developing optimal environments for learning.

name: Multi-Sensory Impairment: Causes and Implications (Distance Education)
description: The developmental implications of multi-sensory impairment are considered in the context of early normal development.  Approaches to developmental assessment are explored and the range of needs associated with the disability are examined, together with some of the major causes of multi-sensory impairment.

name: Musculoskeletal Trauma & Rehabilitation
description: This module will provide the students with the opportunity to acquire a detailed understanding of the pathogenesis, natural history, assessment and management of the complications and also reconstruction of acute musculoskeletal injuries as well as conditions requiring rehabilitation, the methods available and the various settings where rehabilitation may take place.The module will aim to develop skills that the students need in order to provide state-of-the-art assessment, management and dealing with complications of musculoskeletal injuries and identify the skills required to research, plan, provide and justify the appropriate rehabilitation programme for a variety of trauma-inflicted patients. The students will also be taught the skills necessary to develop a coherent and individually-tailored management to specific patients.  This will be based on up-to-date clinical research and evidence-based practice.  They will also develop skills in the interpretation of research data, allowing them to critically appraise published data to allow them to make accurately informed clinical decisions.In order to see how the students' skills are translated into clinical practice, they will be provided with the opportunity to observe management of musculoskeletal injuries at UHB.

name: Net Shape Manufacturing
description: Rapid manufacturing is designated for manufacturing components from their CAD files directly without using a mould or a die.  It includes: direct laser fabrication, selective laser sintering, rapid prototyping, 3D printing, laminate manufacturing and net shape HIPping.This course will introduce the state-of-art of various rapid manufacturing techniques, including the mechanism of individual techniques, their pros and cons, their applications and limitations.  During the course, students will be asked to design their own components and create CAD files of those components and manufacture them using DTM laser Sintersation in the IRC.

name: Non Communicable Diseases in International Health
description: This module will involve 75 hours of student study time in total.  Using the teaching sessions for the transfer of information  and contextualisation, students will be introduced to international aspects of non-communicable diseases and conditions, as well as risk factors and social  determinants. Topics may cover a wide range of issues, such as maternal health, malnutrition, cardiovascular disease, obesity and the effects of war. Students  will consider interventions for disease control and/or mitigation of ill effects and  are expected to be competent independent learners.\n

name: Nonlinear Programming I and Heuristic Optimisation
Nuclear Physics Laboratory for Nuclear Engineers
Numerical Methods & Programming
description: Many problems arising in mathematics cannot be solved exactly.  In such cases, one approach is to use numerical methods implemented on a computer to find approximate but nevertheless usefully accurate solutions. This module introduces the basic techniques of such numerical methods, involving one or more computer packages, and uses these to illustrate and explore mathematics graphically and numerically, perform numerical routines, and run simulations involving random numbers.  At the same time, it the basic ideas of computer programming are introduced such as writing simple programmes, the process of debugging code and the sources and effects of errors in the use of floating point numbers.

name: Occupational Ergonomics
description: The Occupational Ergonomics module aims to impart the principles and practice of ergonomics within the occupational context.  The students will gain an understanding of the role of ergonomics within occupational health and an understanding of the philosophy and practice of ergonomics in the workplace.  The modules covers different tools for assessing ergonomic risks and includes a visit to a workplace where students assess ergonomic risks arising from different manual handling activities.  Workplace case studies will also be discussed providing opportunities to discuss practical solutions.\nThe module links with module 'Principles of Occupational Hygiene' where other occupational hazards are discussed and 'The Effect of Work on Health' which focuses on the two way relationship between work and health.

name: Occupational Exposure and Risk Assessment
description: The module aims to give students a comprehensive understanding of methodologies and techniques used in occupational hygiene to measure, assess and control exposures to workplace hazards.  The module covers approaches to workplace risk assessment for physical, chemical and biological hazards and decision making on the extent of risk. The module also covers strategies for collecting occupational exposure data and methods for selecting and evaluating the effectiveness of organisation, engineering and personal protective equipment.  Practical exercises involve using various occupational hygiene instruments to collect exposure data and to assess ventilation control systems.

name: Occupational Health Dissertation
description: On successful completion of the ESRM module, MSc Occupational Health students will be required to develop a research proposal for their dissertation. The project may involve data collection, analysis of available data or systematic review of published literature.\nThe dissertation proposal will be presented to department staff and must be approved by the module lead. On approval a supervisor is assigned for each student who will oversee the developed of the research work from approval (December) to submission in July, in the following year.  Students must obtain any ethical approval required by their study from the relevant bodies.

name: Occupational Health and Safety
description: The aim of the module is to provide students with knowledge and understanding of key occupational health and safety matters, including the ability to critically evaluate key concepts and models and also to achieve a level of technical competence in preparation for enforcement/advisory roles on graduation.

name: Occupational Mental Health
description: This module aims to give the student a systemic understanding and critical awareness of the interaction between mental and occupational health.  The module provides information which feeds in to the module on the effects of work on health.\nThe module is designed to improve understanding of approaches to the assessment and management mental health risks.  Key topics discussed include; the influence of psychosocial and other factors on the mental health of workers; Organisational and individual based approaches to assessment and intervention; Selection and management issues relating to workers with mental health problems; Specific problems; bullying and harassment, workplace violence, alcohol and drug abuse, post-traumatic stress disorder.  Examples of individual (cases) and organisational scenarios are used for group discussions.

name: Occupational Toxicology
description: This module is an introduction to the conceptual framework of Toxicology including toxicokinetics, types of toxic response and factors affecting the assessment of toxicological properties of hazardous substances.\nStudents will learn how to interpret toxicological data (animal and human) and how these data are used to; establish occupational exposure limits (OELs) and for classify toxic substances. Toxicological aspects of specific diseases (carcinogenicity, reproductive toxicology and neurotoxicology) will also be discussed.

name: Operations Management
description: The Operations Management module provides a general introduction to Operations and Process Management and explains how the Operations function fits within the organisation overall. The module also explores how actors outside the core Operations function have a role in, and engage in the management of processes.\n\nThe module will show students the wide organisational scope of Operations Management activity and will establish an understanding of the core concepts underlying the discipline. The module is introductory in nature, and while focussed primarily on large organisations, also looks at small organisations and even the management of individual 'human' processes. The module is intended as an introduction to operations management in both service and manufacturing organisations. Its intention is to provide the building blocks of those principles, which are broadly applicable to most organisations. The module will introduce the principles of the 'lean' operation, and show how managers can adopt lean principles in practice.

name: Operative techniques I (Aesthetic Dentistry & Endodontics)
description:
This module is designed specifically for online education to develop in-depth understanding of the principles of aesthetics with regard to dentistry and their application to restorative procedures.
Students will receive detailed guidance on contemporary, evidence-based, restorative techniques before carrying out simulated and clinical practical exercises involving the assessment and restoration of primary and secondary carious lesions and failing direct restorations.
Students will develop advanced practical skills using the latest direct conservative aesthetic techniques.
Students will also carry out simulated (and clinical where available) practical endodontic exercises using contemporary materials, equipment and techniques.

In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: Operative techniques II (Fixed and removable prosthodontics)
description: This module is specially designed for distance learning to provide advanced training in contemporary indirect restorative techniques and the replacement of missing teeth using fixed and removable prostheses.Students will achieve high-level understanding of the theoretic principles underlying the assessment and planning for advanced restorative clinical cases and be able to apply these to cultivate management philosophies that maximise preservation of biological tissues.In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: Organisational Behaviour and Human Resource Management
description: The Organisational Behaviour and Human Resource Management (OB &HRM) module has two components: the first, and shorter component will explore the way that people behave and interact in organisations. This section of the module aims to critically develop student knowledge in the fundamental theoretical and practical issues to do with the management of organisations. The student will understand how organisations are structured, how they function and how people behave in organisations. This introductory material will provide the behavioural aspects underpinning HRM, which constitutes the second and larger section of the module. The aim of the HRM component is to provide an introduction to the main HR functions and to place them in the context of important new HR developments - academic and professional - that have occurred in the last decade. The coverage is mainly concerned with large national and multinational firms and will include the analysis of both the strategic and operational problems of delivering successful HRM policies in an International context.

name: Organisational Behaviour and Human Resource Management in a Global Context
description: The Organisational Behaviour and Human Resource Management in a Global Context (OB & HRM) module has two components: the first, and shorter component will explore the way that people behave and interact in organisations. This section of the module aims to critically develop student knowledge in the theoretical and practical issues relating to the management of organisations. The student will understand how organisations are structured, how they function and how people behave in organisations. This introductory material will provide the behavioural aspects underpinning HRM, which constitutes the second and larger section of the module. The aim of the HRM component is to provide an introduction to the main HR functions and to place them in the context of important new HR developments - academic and professional - that have occurred in the last decade. The coverage is mainly concerned with large national and multinational firms and will include the analysis of both the strategic and operational problems of delivering successful HRM policies in an International context.

name: PTNR Research Project
description: This module provides students with experience of working in a nuclear industrial department, and/or the School of Physics & Astronomy nuclear laboratory and carrying out an individual research project, drawing upon the expertise developed in the earlier modules.  It also provides experience of presenting work both orally and in a major written report.

name: Partnership and Collaboration
description: This module focuses on the importance of partnership and collaboration in modern public management and effective service delivery. The module introduces students to the main theoretical perspectives on partnership, and how these have developed and relate to the dynamics of collaboration in the public sector. Students look at the increasing importance of inter-organisational collaboration and the skills required for the successful development and maintenance of effective partnerships.

name: Performance Management
description: This module focuses on the importance of performance management in public service delivery. The module introduces students to the main theoretical perspectives that underpin performance management, and how these have developed and relate to the dynamics of public services delivery. Students will study the types and use of data to support performance management, and the practical skills and knowledge necessary for effective performance management. The module will also introduce different approaches to performance management across a range of countries.

name: Petroleum Geoscience Review
description:
Focussing on a review of a hydrocarbon producing region of the world, the student will prepare a 4000 word professional standard report (80%) covering:
1. Geological History
2. Hydrocarbon history
3. Exploration and Production history, and
4. Economic and geopolitical contexts

A 20 minute presentation (20%) covering the key points.

Module is largely self-directed with one key member of staff acting as contact point. One fixed progress review at week 8.
Resources should include scientific literature and industry/company reports which must be integrated into an original, coherent synthesis of the subject.
Where possible, students should also highlight the role that micropalaeontology has played in the hydrocarbon development of the region.

name: Philosophy of Mental Health (Distance Learning)
description: The module provides an overview of contemporary debates in philosophy and mental health. In each seminar a new issue will be investigated, but there will be three interrelated threads throughout the module. One is about the nature of psychiatry. The second is about the sense in which psychiatric disorders are disorders of the self. The third is about how we should respond to people with psychiatric disorders, considered from a wide range of perspectives, including interpersonal, clinical, ethical, legal and public health policy. These themes will be addressed by reference to different aspects of psychiatry (e.g. classification, diagnosis, aetiology, research, treatment), different psychiatric disorders (e.g. addiction, anorexia, dementia, dissociation, schizophrenia, personality disorders, psychopathy), and different disciplinary frameworks. The course will also have a practical element involving structured, outcome-focused deliberation about difficult cases highlighting these threads and their inter-relations.Topics to be addressed may include:•\tIs mental illness a myth?•\tCritique of the medical model by the anti-psychiatry movement and discussion of 'eliminativism' about psychiatry•\tGenes and environment: causes, explanations, interventions•\tPatient perspectives: narratives, emotions, needs, and values•\tHow do cognitive, volitional, and emotional deficits impact on the construction and preservation of the self, autonomy, and decision-making capacity?•\tThe nature of delusions•\tThe nature of disorders of agency•\tHow do psychiatric disorders impact on moral and legal responsibility?

name: Physical Climatology and Climate Change
description: The understanding of the variability of the climate system and its inherent changes in time will be a major component to address any questions of natural or anthropogenic climate change. This module will help students to become familiar with the underlying physical concepts as well as with its applications to attribute and detect anthropogenic climate change. The module will cover the basic physical rules, their application in the climate system, basics of the observed atmosphere and ocean general circulation, its 3-dimensional features, and will focus on main modes of large scale variability (e.g. NAO, PNA, ENSO, etc.). The variability on different time scales will be addressed as well as anthropogenic climate change including an impact assessment and an introduction into actual political and social processes related to it.

name: Physical Metallurgy (Titanium and Nickel)
description: This module looks at the applications of nickel and titanium alloys in aero-engines and the land-based gas turbine. The basic operation is first considered: thermodynamics, adiabatic heating in the compressor, efficiency and the need for high temperature resistant materials. For nickel-based alloys, temperature resistance and oxidation resistance in Ni and Ni/Cr alloys are described. Other main topics covered are: developing high temperature strength through second-phase particles; slip in the A3B system, involving disordering/re-ordering; the investment casting process; living with high gas temperatures and lifing issues with creep and fatigue; powder discs and the role of shot-peening. For titanium alloys - phase diagrams and the main classifications of the alloys; Widmanstatten structures; higher strength alloys; defects in Ti alloys, and Ti alloy development, will be included. The potential for inter-metallics and MMCs is also be described.

name: Placement
description:
This is optional 10 credit module in the PGCARMS.  It will provide UoB doctoral researchers with short term placement opportunities.  These may be part of a UoB research project or they may involve industrial or 3rd sector partners outside of the University.

Each placement will consist of 50 contact hours over a one to six month period and candidates will be required to produce at least one clear written output as a minimum (e.g. a project report or a journal article) at the end of this period. 

The module candidates will also be required to complete a 500 word self-reflective patchwork text assignment. 

These placements are an invaluable opportunity for Birmingham DRs to increase their employability and develop/hone transferable and, where placed on a research project, research skills in a practical setting.

name: Player and participant development
description:
This develops the theory and practice in an applied setting of the areas sports¿ knowledge (e.g. sociology, biomechanics, psychology) involved in the coaching and participation process.
The sociological aspect of this module is intended to develop the existing knowledge levels of those interested in issues that surround sports participation. Using sociological and coaching theories the module will look at current comparative, political and social trends in sport by different social groups (in particular young people), the factors that influence participation, and the concepts that underpin successful coaching practice and sports organisation. The module will examine participation, drop out and issues of sports 'membership', and will analyse these concepts from the viewpoint of participants, coaches and sports administrators.
