The module also looks at the theory and application of sport science in assisting and improving coaching methodology. Theoretical areas covered include motor learning, biomechanics and psychology.
The academic literature and theories in these areas will be discussed in relation to current coaching practices. The concepts and theories will be studied in relation to their use in different sports specific coaching situations e.g. individual / group coaching; elite / amateur / recreational.

name: Plays and Poems of Shakespeare A
description: This module, looking at Shakespeare's work in detail up to 1600, is designed to help you critically interrogate the early plays of Shakespeare, and to give you essential skills for discussing any play in depth. It will explore 'page' issues (how to read an edition; what quartos and folios are; book paratext; scansion; close-reading); stage issues (Shakespeare's theatre and its history; Shakespeare's actors and acting; performance paratext; music); and writing issues (Shakespeare's chronology and sequencing; Shakespeare's development of themes).

name: Plays and Poems of Shakespeare B
description: This module, looking at Shakespeare's work in detail from 1601 to 1613, is designed to help you critically interrogate seventeenth-century Shakespeare, and to develop skills for discussing plays and poems in depth. It will explore 'page' issues (how to read an edition; what quartos and folios are; book paratext; scansion; close-reading); stage issues (Shakespeare's theatre and its history; Shakespeare's actors and acting; performance paratext; music); and writing issues (Shakespeare's chronology and sequencing; Shakespeare's development of themes).

name: Policy, Regulation & Management
description: This module is designed to equip students with knowledge and understanding of the policy and regulation framework for decommissioning and waste management and how this impacts on programme management in the nuclear sector. The module will focus predominantly on UK government policy and regulatory guidance and regulatory framework but will also review international practice and case studies. The module syllabus will include: role of public engagement and accountability in the regulation framework; principles of programme management associated with proposals for waste disposal and decommissioning/remediation; project appraisal and appraisal methods; project financing.  Case studies and site visits will be used throughout the module to demonstrate good (or bad) practice and issues arising from implementation of legislation and policy.

name: Politics in a Changing World
description: This module will introduce students to the main issues and debates in contemporary international and global affairs. The module will compromise three sections. The first section will consider conceptual debates and theoretical approaches surrounding the study of international and global politics, the development of the nation-state and its changing role in a globalised world, and the concept of international order. The second section will consider patterns and dynamics of international and global conflict, modes of international cooperation and the role and impact of international organisations. The third section will consider the development of global political debates, the challenges they pose to states, and the international responses to them.

name: Polymer Science and Soft Matter
description: This module is an introduction to modern advanced topics in polymer science and soft matter. It includes: Preparatory reading on polymer structure, properties and processing; Polymer synthesis. Step-growth and free radical polymerisation. The glass transition temperature and spherulites. DSC and FT-ir. `Rough guides¿ to the techniques. Factors affecting Tg, miscibility and crystallisation. TPE and thermally-reversible cross-links. Thermodynamics of mixing applied to polymer blends. Flory-Huggins theory of miscibility. Principles of cyclic polymers. In situ polymerisation, crystallisation and blending. Case study of blending and instrumental techniques. Thermodynamics of melting applied to thermotropic liquid crystal polymers. Examples of thermotropic, mouldable polyesters. Lyotropic liquid crystal polymers. Summary of block copolymer features and morphologies.Case studies on a variety of advanced topics such as: block copolymers, dendrimers, polymer brushes and surfaces, liquid crystalline polymers, cyclic polymers, polymers for displays, OLEDs and functional polymers, supercritical fluid processing, polymer optical fibres and sensors, biodegradable polymers and polymers for drug delivery, polymer tribology, crystallisation, physical ageing and structure development, polymer blends. Laboratory work with examples of the use of characterisation techniques including: microscopy (optical, SEM, TEM, AFM), FTIR, DSC, TGA, NMR, neutron scattering, SAXD and WAXD, SCF processing, reactive blending, specialised mechanical testing, tribological testing.

name: Postgraduate Research Skills: Historical Studies
description: This module will provide an introduction to generic skills training for Historical Studies postgraduates. It will introduce a range of research, library and generic skills that will be applicable to the student's dissertation and research experience, as well as subject/discipline specific training in the second half of the semester. The module is team-taught with contributions from across the departments of the School of Historical Studies helping expose the student to the community of research experience within the School.

name: Practical & Applied Studies B
description: This module will equip students with practical, professional and employability skills required for a career in the field. The module also gives students the opportunity to apply their knowledge and understanding from lectures to case studies and real life situations. The module consists of 4 components: materials and analysis laboratory studies; computational and numerical analysis; case study exercise; site visit. All components except for the site visit are assessed through coursework. \nMaterials and analysis laboratory practical classes will equip students with a basic understanding and experience of a range of solid state and liquid phase analysis methods, including X-ray diffraction, X-ray Fluorescence Spectroscopy, optical microscopy and elemental analysis.Computational and numerical analysis enables students to apply their knowledge and understanding of hydrogeological risk assessment and groundwater modelling to problem-solving exercises and to case studies. The case study exercise allows students the opportunity to apply aspects of their knowledge and understanding of decommissioning, waste and environmental management (module 3), processing, storage & disposal of nuclear wastes (Module 4) and policy, regulation & management (Module 5). In a one-day workshop, the case study scenario is presented to the students and they work in students to develop a brief initial plan for their proposed solution, which is presented to the group at the end of the day. After the workshop, students will individually prepare a detailed technical written report proposing their solution to the scenario. During the module the students will gain significant experience of data analysis and presentation, commercial and business awareness and will develop their professional report writing and presentation skills.

name: Practical Applications of Molecular Biotechnology
description: This continuously assessed practical module will focus on techniques used in  molecular  biotechnology.  Students will have an opportunity to learn how to map a promoter by Southern analysis and how to assemble and use fermenters for batch and continuous culture experiments to study how bacteria respond to environmental stress.

name: Practical Epidemiology and Statistics
description: This module builds on concepts introduced in Epidemiology Statistics and Research Methods to reinforce the ideas and enable students to focus on their critical application to novel practical situations. Students will develop skills in critical appraisal of published work in health care related areas, and build on material introduced in Epidemiology, Statistics and Research Methods to develop more practical understanding of epidemiological and statistical methods used in the analysis of epidemiological studies.

name: Practical In Vivo Research Skills
description: The module is designed to hone the students¿ practical skills and to develop a critical sense of observation within the scientific context. Students will apply the theoretical understanding gained in the in vivo approaches module to the experimental context. They will work through a series of established protocols for physiological experiments on themselves before moving on to experiments on whole living organs derived from animals.

name: Practical Skills for Toxicologists Part A
description: This module is aimed at improving the communication, data handling, team working and laboratory skills of students and is embedded throughout the taught 28629 semester 1 modules of the MSc Toxicology. Students are taught to develop their research, communication, and presentation skills which they develop independently by undertaking exercises in literature searching/information retrieval and communication of their findings in written reports. Students also learn how to design experiments and to apply statistical analysis to toxicological data. There are also more specialised IT skills including data handling workshops (excretion balance workshop, P450 workshop, enzyme kinetics workshop) and practical classes (CYP 2D6 PCR genotyping practical class and sequence analysis workshop).

name: Practical Skills for Toxicologists Part B
description: This module is aimed at improving the communication, data handling, team working and laboratory skills of students and is embedded throughout the taught 28628 semester 1 module of the MSc Toxicology. Students are taught to develop their research, communication, and presentation skills which they develop independently by undertaking exercises in literature searching/information retrieval and communication of their findings in written reports and summarising a scientific paper in the form of a graphical abstract. Students also learn how to design experiments and to apply statistical analysis to toxicological data. There are also more specialised IT skills including data handling workshops (cytochrome P450 data handing workshop) and practical classes (Aspirin practical and HPLC data analysis workshop)

name: Practice Assessment 1
description: Reflective Diary AssessmentBe able to reflect on your learning and practice is an important skill.  Throughout your time on the course you are expected to keep a diary which should consider what you are learning and how this might inform your current practice (or how it might have informed your past practice), your research, and your understanding of forensic psychology and crime in our society.  You should discuss with the course director the exact format of your assignment so that it can be tailored to your current circumstances.

name: Practice Portfolio
description: At the end of the PG Dip HIPT programme, each trainee will submit a portfolio of evidence to be formally assessed by the course tutors. The Practice Portfolio provides an opportunity for trainees to demonstrate the integration of their work based learning, in-service training, and programme training. The portfolio is the primary means by which a trainee demonstrates that they have met the criteria laid down by the BABCP for successful completion of a Level 2 accredited CBT training course.\n\nIt is marked on a pass/fail basis and is not graded. The portfolio does not count towards the mark that is awarded upon completion of the Diploma, although must be passed to complete the course. Upon submission, if any required evidence is missing, the Portfolio will be returned to the trainee and they will need to re-submit with the relevant material added. This may include accruing additional hours of supervision or clinical practice.

name: Presentation and Communication Skills/Team Skills Development
description: Presentation and Communication Skills: This module will develop oral and written communication skills - Planning a research thesis; Writing a scientific paper; Illustrations and tables; Grammar, punctuation and editorial style; References; Abstracts; Summarising reports; Effective poster presentations; Effective oral presentations - preparation, achieving focus, organising the presentation, using language effectively, achieving speaking excellence, visual aids.\n\nTeam Skills Development:  The development of team and interpersonal skills by participation in activities to encourage strategic, time, and project planning and management.  The course is undertaken in a residential environment to facilitate the development of the team ethos, where the team are given progressively challenging scenarios which require team member participation through planning, delegation, team working and problem resolution for the achievement of the task.  The tasks are under the responsibility of a facilitator (from the Centre for outdoor pursuits, and from School staff/nominees for the management games/challenges) and teams are each guided by an appointed mentor for the course duration.  Teams participate in a debriefing after each half-day of the programme, for the recognition of achievements, and for the recognition of skills and attributes to transfer forward to future challenges.

name: Primary and Early Years School Studies 2
Primary and Early Years School Studies 3
Primary and Early Years School Studies 3 (Subject Specialism)
description: University based seminars and school based practical experience offer opportunities for the student to develop their understanding and practice of teaching. One of the major experiences is the planning and evaluation of learning experiences for small groups, supported by the exploration the place of core subjects within national frameworks and initiatives with a particular emphasis on one area of subject specialism.

name: Principles and Practice of CBT
description: This module will focus on delivering a systematic knowledge of the fundamental principles and practice of CBT.  Students will be encouraged to develop a critical understanding of the theoretical and research evidence for cognitive behavioural models of therapy and an ability to evaluate the evidence. The module aims to enable students to have an understanding of how scientific principles inform CBT clinical practice. This module will focus on core clinical competencies (skills) necessary for undertaking CBT. It covers cognitive and behavioural theory, maintenance and developmental conceptualisations of cases and the core aspects of the cognitive and behavioural processes of therapy. Clinical workshops will address the most up-to-date evidence for the effectiveness of CBT and provide direct training in applying CBT. The workshops will consist of information giving, role-play, experiential exercises, and video and case demonstrations.

name: Principles and Practices of Occupational Health
description: The module is the first module in the programme for the MSc/PGDip Occupational Health.  Within the module, a firm foundation will be provided upon which students may build their understanding and professional practice.  The module will include fundamental definitions and terminology relevant to occupational health including information sources and literature searches.  The role and function of occupational health services will be discussed together with the multidisciplinary approach to problem solving.  The history and development of occupational health will be discussed as well as the current challenges for occupational health professionals.  An important element of the module is the student practical experience in conducting a workplace visit which forms the basis of the module assignment. A framework for risk assessment and management is also introduced which demonstrates how different components of occupational health are integrated and the decision making processes.

name: Principles of Business
description: The modern PGA Professional often develops and maintains multiple income streams; however, retailing is generally a key aspect of the golf business and many PGA professionals earn a large proportion of their income through the sale of golf related goods and services. However, for all businesses, the golf business environment is changing. Golf businesses are coming under increasing pressure from competitors, shifting social habits, the economy and changing shopping behaviour. Only the best golf businesses will continue to prosper. This module will provide students with the tools to identify, analyse and interpret key features of the modern golf business environment. It is expected that students will broaden their understanding of the underlying principles of business and develop their own business skills to enable them to maximise future opportunities.

name: Principles of Communication Systems
description: In the first part of module, students should become familiar with analysis and synthesis of digital communication systems by means of the statistical theory that is the core of any information exchange and specifically digital data. They should gain an understanding of the fundamental principles of communication that will be used in all communication related courses.The second part of the module covers the principles of RF and microwave engineering that underpin the design of analogue front end elements of communication systems. Computer simulation of microwave circuits is also introduced.The third part of the module provides an opportunity to learn about communication system simulations using industry standard simulation software, through a structured assignment.

name: Principles of Health Technology Assessment
description: The module introduces students to the principles of health technology assessment (HTA) and its place in healthcare decision making. The aim of the module is to provide students with an understanding of: what technologies are; the rationale underpinning the need for HTA; the history of the development of HTA; organisations, systems and approaches to HTA; and the differing perspectives of the role and use of HTA. The module takes students on a journey from the regulation of technologies, through the mechanisms underpinning the evidence based approach to their adoption by healthcare systems on clinical and cost-effectiveness grounds to the influence of HTA on the continued development of new technologies.  These stages of HTA are illustrated throughout by reference to real world examples.

name: Prior Leadership Learning
description: APEL module

name: Probability and Statistics
description: This module introduces students to the concepts and practice of probability and statistics.  The  module covers the topics of basic probability and probability rules, discrete and continuous probability, probability distributions; statistical data analysis, and reliability analysis.

name: Process Systems and Principles of Process Control
Processing, Storage & Disposal of Nuclear Waste
description: This module seeks to provide the theoretical and applied knowledge base that will underpin a student's potential future professional activity in this field. The module syllabus will include: waste forms and classification; waste processing and treatment;  encapsulation methods and technologies; waste management and storage; geological disposal. These topics will be illustrated by case studies throughout and student learning will be underpinned by problem-solving exercises based on these case studies.

name: Professional Experience Elective
description:
Students will select a clinical or professional speciality in which they have a particular interest and produce personal learning outcomes, agreed with their tutor.
The placement is timetabled as one day per week for eight weeks, however students may, if for example students wanted to carry out experience abroad, arrange a block of time outside term time in order fulfil this component.
Students will be expected to observe/ shadow a pharmacist and other healthcare professionals working in that area. 
Where possible, students should take the opportunity to embrace active involvement: hands on learning of practical skills / patient examination / supervised real-time decision making etc. 
The focus of the module is that students explore, in detail, the training, the daily life and the clinical / multi-professional context of the particular branch of pharmacy.
Students will determine their own agenda with support / input from supervisors. The main learning approaches will be observation and discussion.
Students will also share their experience by presenting a short case study/presentation session to the third year pharmacy students which will be assessed by a member of the academic staff. Students will also provide a reflective account of their experiences, which will be related back to their initial personal learning outcomes.

name: Professional Experience Placements 2
description:
Pharmacy students will have the opportunity to further develop understanding of their professional identity in the healthcare team during longer periods in different work environments performing work based tasks and guided reflection. Experiences will include structured activities working alongside other qualified healthcare professionals.
Students will be supported in their development by academic staff and practitioners working in partnership with pharmacy professionals and patients in both community and hospital environments.
Students will demonstrate and record their achievements in their professional ePortfolios linking professional experience with all other modules and building on this in each subsequent year.
Although limited in extent, placements play a vital role in the professional development of pharmacy students. Pharmacy practice takes place in a wide range of settings, reflected in the diversity of experience provided to students in this component. 
Although, for each student, individual experiences in this required component may be measured in days rather than weeks, the overall commitment of our placement partners over the whole year and across cohorts is substantial and every care will be taken to ensure the quality and safety of learning experiences and compliance with the Code of Practice for placement learning.
For each placement, detailed information about learning tasks will be provided to students and their supervisors, along with clear guidance with regard to what they can and cannot expect of each other. From the perspective of the placement, this will largely be about supervision and feedback rather than teaching, but any required training (e.g. on the use of equipment in practice) will be specified. Supervisors will be involved in assessing student performance (and their reflection on performance) as satisfactory / unsatisfactory, but the overall assessment of the component is managed by the programme team. In hospital settings, students will be supervised by teacher / practitioner academics. In other settings, academics from the programme team will take a more active role in supporting supervisors.

name: Professional Issues in Psychological Therapy
description: This module is for students to build on their prior health-care professional skills, with a systematic understanding of the guidelines and principles that underpin the practice of efficient, effective and ethical psychological therapy and, specifically, the standards that are required of a Cognitive Behaviour Therapist.  The module will include both recent research data on the delivery of Cognitive Behaviour Therapy in demanding clinical settings and how a clinician's level of personal organisation can influence service efficiency, and a focus on the students developing a critical self-awareness of the role of ethical issues in delivering such therapy services.

name: Professional Placement for Environmental Scientists
description: This module provides students with the opportunity to develop professional environmental science skills through the application of the academic and practical skills attained on campus to the work place. Through a placement scheme students will work for an organisation learning a) the day to day responsibilities of working in that job through shadowing b) practical experience of being involved in a project and c) the correct way to disseminate their results to the appropriate persons within the organisation. This will provide the basis for critical reflection on the links between theory as learnt at university and practice in a work situation. In addition students will gain valuable experience of work outside the university through their placements that will help equip them for their future careers.  Students will also undertake a number of workshops that will enable them to develop their career development skills.

name: Professional Standards and Practice
description:
This required component is focused on a viva voce examination providing the opportunity for students to talk about and reflect on the work they have undertaken for the two dissertation elements as well as their broader portfolio of work from across the programme. It therefore also provides an opportunity or the programme leaders to probe candidates with regard to their understanding of and compliance with professional standards in academic study and practice.
The assessment does not affect the recorded performance in any of the individual credited modules, but it does give a further opportunity for professional excellence to be demonstrated and rewarded.
In the unlikely event of questions of probity arising through the examination which had not been clear through the original process of distance submission (e.g. the extent to which presented material was the independent work of the candidate) the matter would be dealt with in line with the University's code of practice on misconduct.

In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: Professional Writing, Training and Presentation
description: Student to identify a topic related to their professional experience that they feel competent and confident enough to develop a training workshop presentation.  This may have been at the request of an individual or agency that acknowledges their expertise in a particular area of knowledge.  It would be professionally irresponsible to accept an invitation on a topic unfamiliar to them.  The invitation should be passed to the  supervisor or a professional colleague who has recognised expertise that matches the invitation. Student to Identify the Scope and Purpose Write down the scope and purpose of the training workshop and its learning objectives.  It is important to impart the skills and tools required to match the learning objectives for the participants. The scope and purpose of the training is based on an analysis and identification of need in relation to the proposed participants.  For example, are those attending trainees or experts in their field?  This will indicate the level at which the training will be carried out.   Needs identification may also identify gaps in the knowledge base (for example, few professionals throughout Central and Eastern Europe have come across 'attachment theory').  What are you hoping to achieve in terms of learning outcomes for the participants?  For example, is it to standardize their working practices or train them to train others?

name: Professional contexts and the strategic role of the special educational needs coordinator (SENCO): policy and procedures
description:
This module focuses on four key aspects of the SENCO's role in schools, local authorities and wider education communities. First, it examines important features of the professional context in which they work (knowledge and understanding). Second, it identifies strategic dimensions of the SENCO's role (critical appreciation). Third, it considers the use of appropriate tools, for collecting, analysing and applying data with a view to improving the learning of pupils with SEN and/or disabilities. Fourth, it examines the role that a range of school based professionals have to play in supporting pupils with SEN and/or disabilities, including 'designated' support staff who work with this group of pupils.
Professional context
The module reviews the statutory and regulatory framework for inclusive and special education, outlining and analysing legislation and policy at local and national levels. It also summarises current and pending laws and associated guidance on disability equality. 
Strategic development of SEN policy and procedure
This aspect of the module seeks to support SENCOs to carry out their strategic roles effectively, with particular reference to senior leaders in schools and school governing bodies. It helps SENCOs to play in a key role in policy development and school improvement planning (e.g. through the use of institutional self-evaluation (e.g. the 'Self Evaluation Framework' used by schools, local authorities, other educational organisations and Ofsted). It also identifies procedures designed to ensure the effectiveness of provision for pupils with SEN and/or disabilities.  Effectiveness is also considered from a financial perspective. SENCOs are introduced to local authority and other 'value for money' evidence tools and how these can be used to make the best use of available resources to plan, evaluate and improve provision for pupils with SEN and/or disabilities.  The last part of this aspect of the module focuses on the use of policy and research evidence to improve outcomes for pupils with SEN and/or disabilities. It also addresses barriers to participation and learning, identifying how these can reduced or removed through the use of active policies and procedures, and how technology can support teaching and learning (e.g. in relation to physical, sensory and communication impairments).
Using tools for collecting, analysing and using data
Established and emergent tools for collecting, analysing and using data (e.g. national RAISEonline; a range of local authority and school data sets) will be outlined and critically appraised in relation to national, local and school specific contexts. The use of data to raise expectations, and to improve the learning of pupils with SEN and/or disabilities, for example, through effective target setting, will be discussed with reference research evidence. 
Deploying staff and managing resources
Staff deployment and the management of resources will be discussed in relation to national policy initiatives and significant research evidence. Particular attention will be given to: appropriate task delegation; the effective/flexible deployment of teaching assistants, higher level teaching assistants and other support staff, making use of particular strengths and expertise of individuals.

name: Professional experience placements 1
description:
Over the first year pharmacy students will have the opportunity to develop an understanding of their professional identity in the healthcare team in different work environments through direct observation of practice,  work based tasks and guided reflection.
Students will be supported in their development by academic staff and practitioners working in partnership with pharmacy professionals and patients. Students will demonstrate and record their achievements in their professional ePortfolios linking professional experience with all other modules and building on this in each subsequent year.
Although limited in extent, placements play a vital role in the professional development of pharmacy students. Pharmacy practice takes place in a wide range of settings, reflected in the diversity of experience provided to students in this component.
Although, for each student, individual experiences in this required component may be measured in days rather than weeks, the overall commitment of our placement partners over the whole year and across cohorts is substantial and every care will be taken to ensure the quality and safety of learning experiences and compliance with the Code of Practice for placement learning.
For each placement, detailed information about learning tasks will be provided to students and their supervisors, along with clear guidance with regard to what they can and cannot expect of each other. From the perspective of the placement, this will largely be about supervision and feedback rather than teaching, but any required training (e.g. on the use of equipment in practice) will be specified. Supervisors will be involved in assessing student performance (and their reflection on performance) as satisfactory / unsatisfactory, but the overall assessment of the component is managed by the programme team. In hospital settings, students will be supervised by teacher / practitioner academics. In other settings, academics from the programme team will take a more active role in supporting supervisors.

name: Professional experience placements 3
description:
Pharmacy students will have the opportunity to further develop understanding of their professional identity in the wider healthcare team performing work based tasks and guided reflection  to include an experience planned and organised by the student to meet their own defined learning outcomes. Experiences will include structured activities in clinical practice environments.
Students will be supported in their development by academic staff and practitioners working in partnership with pharmacy professionals and patients. Students will demonstrate and record their achievements in their professional ePortfolios linking professional experience with all other modules and building on this in each subsequent year.
Although limited in extent, placements play a vital role in the professional development of pharmacy students. Pharmacy practice takes place in a wide range of settings, reflected in the diversity of experience provided to students in this component.
Although, for each student, individual experiences in this required component may be measured in days rather than weeks, the overall commitment of our placement partners over the whole year and across cohorts is substantial and every care will be taken to ensure the quality and safety of learning experiences and compliance with the Code of Practice for placement learning.
For each placement, detailed information about learning tasks will be provided to students and their supervisors, along with clear guidance with regard to what they can and cannot expect of each other. From the perspective of the placement, this will largely be about supervision and feedback rather than teaching, but any required training (e.g. on the use of equipment in practice) will be specified. Supervisors will be involved in assessing student performance (and their reflection on performance) as satisfactory / unsatisfactory, but the overall assessment of the component is managed by the programme team. In hospital settings, students will be supervised by teacher / practitioner academics. In other settings, academics from the programme team will take a more active role in supporting supervisors.

name: Professional experience placements 4
description:
Pharmacy students will have the opportunity to demonstrate self-direction and further develop understanding of their professional identity in the wider healthcare team. Students will be expected to attend hospital based ward rounds (or equivalent) attached to clinical teams taking part in reflective discussion with the clinical leader to resolve and discuss clinical issues. These experiences will be less structured than visits in previous years.
Students will be supported in their development by academic staff and practitioners working in partnership with pharmacy professionals and patients. Students will demonstrate and record their achievements in their professional ePortfolios linking professional experience with all other modules and building on this in each subsequent year.
Although limited in extent, placements play a vital role in the professional development of pharmacy students. Pharmacy practice takes place in a wide range of settings, reflected in the diversity of experience provided to students in this component.Although, for each student, individual experiences in this required component may be measured in days rather than weeks, the overall commitment of our placement partners over the whole year and across cohorts is substantial and every care will be taken to ensure the quality and safety of learning experiences and compliance with the Code of Practice for placement learning.
For each placement, detailed information about learning tasks will be provided to students and their supervisors, along with clear guidance with regard to what they can and cannot expect of each other. From the perspective of the placement, this will largely be about supervision and feedback rather than teaching, but any required training (e.g. on the use of equipment in practice) will be specified. Supervisors will be involved in assessing student performance (and their reflection on performance) as satisfactory / unsatisfactory, but the overall assessment of the component is managed by the programme team. In hospital settings, students will be supervised by teacher / practitioner academics. In other settings, academics from the programme team will take a more active role in supporting supervisors.

name: Professionalism and the Foundations of Dental Practice
Programme Management
description: This module introduces students to the history of programme management and to the theoretical concepts which underpin it. Students will examine the  role of programme management in the implementation of strategy and in the implementation of significant change programmes in public services around the world. The module will include theoretical and critical perspectives on different approaches to programme management, and students will also be introduced to the practical issues of managing programmes and projects.

name: Programme and Project Management
description: This module introduces students to the history of programme management and to the theoretical concepts which underpin it. Students will examine the role of programme management in the implementation of strategy and in the implementation of significant change programmes in public services around the world. The module will include theoretical and critical perspectives on different approaches to programme management, and students will also be introduced to the practical issues of managing programmes and projects.

name: Project (CompSci - MSc)
description: This module enables the student to demonstrate professional competence in a substantial software-related task and to apply material learned in other components of the degree programme.  Projects are chosen from staff suggestions or are developed from the student's original idea stages of the software life-cycle.

name: Project - Advanced MSc
description: Each student undertakes a piece of research work that is expected to be based on a previously completed mini-project under the supervision of a research-active member of academic staff. Students should demonstrate an ability to define aims, objectives and plans; manage their project and time; use the results of systematic literature searches and communicate in writing and verbally. There is no requirement for the main project to include development of a program. The project may be completed in industry in the form of a work placement.

name: Project - Conversion MSc
description: Projects are normally undertaken individually with supervision from a member of the School's teaching staff. The projects are varied in their aims and cover most areas of Computer Science. Project allocation/selection normally takes place near Easter and may be chosen from a list of topics put forward by the School/Industry or be developed from the student's original idea

name: Project - Masters 40
description: Successful completion of this module is required for students wishing to apply for exemptions from BCS registration.The final year project enables the student to demonstrate competence as a computing professional and to apply material learnt in other components of the degree programme. Projects are chosen from staff suggestions or are developed from the student's original idea.The project is an opportunity for the student to demonstrate problem solving skills. It must include a substantial piece of scientific or engineering work.The project cannot consist of only a literature review.The aims of this module are to:Allow students to carry out a substantial problem solving task of their own choosing, in any area of Computer Science including Artificial Intelligence, Robotics, Software Engineering, Theory, Human-Computer Interaction, Mobile, Security, or Natural Computation.Allow students to demonstrate their ability in one or more of the following skills: programming, software or hardware development, mathematical proof, empirical investigation, or some other scientific or engineering method, as applied to Computer Science.Allow students to demonstrate their competence as computing professionals, and to apply what they have learnt in the other components of their degree programme.Facilitate independent work on a substantial individual project, including prioritisation of different components of the project, as well as prioritising the project as a whole against other work.

name: Project Management & Research Governance
description: This first module within the Masters in Research (MRes Health Research) Programme module provides an essential overview of the practical aspects involved within project management and research governance.  The content of the Module will reflect research focused around Randomised Control Trials (RCT¿s) activity and will be explored through five specific themes surrounding Research Governance: i.\tIntroduction to the Science and Principles of Research Governanceii.\tEthics in research, iii.\tInformation & Documentationiv.\tProject Management, Finance and Intellectual Propertyv.\tHealth & Safety and Employment within ResearchStudents will initially consider the development of knowledge in relation to cultural and ethical dimensions of research, and critically consider the theory and practice of Good Clinical Practice (GCP) and explore the systems involved in securing ethical approval for research and the regulations arising from the Research Governance Framework. This module will also critically review the essentials involved in effective project management including pre-project planning, developing realistic time frames and effective time management. The module will utilise an Enquiry Based Learning (EBL) format centred upon a series of cases critically considering the responsibilities of research participants, researchers, investigators, sponsors, and universities in performing high quality quantitative/ qualitative research within organizations providing care.Students will be introduced to critical reading of research literature, the ethical review process, European & UK Law, regulatory authority inspection, informed consent, pharmaco-vigilance, archiving, data capture, protection and monitoring, intellectual property, advocacy, human rights, conflicts of interest, risk assessment and safe guarding participants in research, publication and authorship.Throughout the module worked case studies will be drawn from existing adult and child research trials

name: Project for Natural Sciences students (ES20) LH
description: none

name: Project in Applied Mathematics
description: Students may only take one lev

name: Project in Education for Health Professionals
description: This module puts into practice the learning from previous modules. They will draw upon relevant literature (probably from their work in 'Reviewing Education for Health Professionals') and research design (probably based on their assignment for 'Researching Education for Health Professionals') to conduct a small research project into the education of health professionals. This will require: formulation of research questions; modifying the research design if appropriate; obtaining ethical and research governance approvals if necessary; gathering and analysing data; and drawing pertinent conclusions.  In addition, they will need to become familiar with the author guidelines for a relevant academic journal.

name: Project in Mathematical Science
description: None

name: Promoting Mental Health, Recovery and Well Being
description: The focus of this module is the promotion of mental health through a philosophy of well being and recovery. Students on the module will explore the concept of inclusion and how environmental and social factors contribute to mental well-being.  \nIn addition the module incorporates cognitive behavioural therapy interventions with a focus on its utilization in promoting mental health recovery with service users who have long term mental health problems. There will be the opportunity to learn through lectures, group work, seminars, directed study and develop knowledge and skills during a seven week clinical placement which will be in the community or in a residential setting.\n

name: Psychological Medicine Research Project
description: This module aims to equip students with skills needed to conduct a piece of research suitable for publication within a relevant journal. Students will experience data collection, management and analysis, prior to to writing up in the form of an academic paper or dissertation. Students will have selected a project supervisor in consultation with the module co-ordinator.  They will have met with their supervisor to develop a research proposal for the project (in the area of Psychological Medicine) to be carried out in Semester 2. This module relates to the conduction and delivery of the research project.  If necessary, ethical approval for the proposed project will be obtained.  Students may receive further specialist research training in their chosen area of research if appropriate.  Students will work under close supervision and have tutorials with their supervisor on a regular basis. These will identify problems with data collection, monitor progress and support data management and delivery, enabling the student to fully engage with the researcg process from concept to completion. In semester 2 students will present an academic poster of their research findings or experience and will also submit their project write up either as a dissertation or paper written in the style of an appropriate journal.

name: Psychological Medicine Research Project Design
description: The module aims to equip students with the skills needed to concieve and design a feasible research project in the area of Psychological Medicine. Students will select a project supervisor in consultation with the module co-ordinator.  They will meet with their supervisor to develop a research proposal for the project (in the area of Psychological Medicine) to be carried out in Semester 2.  They will meet in seminar groups to discuss project ideas and development.  If necessary, ethical approval for the proposed project will be obtained and scoping work (e.g. familiarisation with local policy and practice) undertaken.  At the end of Semester 1, each student will give a 10-minute oral presentation of the research proposal to the group. They will also submit a written research proposal.  Students will work under close supervision and have tutorials with their supervisor on a regular basis.

name: Psychological Research in Clinical Settings 1
description:
Sample topics:


	Research in a Professional Context: the rewards and challenges of applied research.
	The Status of Psychological Knowledge: epistemology and ontology.
	Aims & Objectives: framing a research question.
	Constructing a Research Proposal.
	User involvement.
	Writing a Literature Review.
	Seeking Ethical Approval for Applied Research.
	Audit and Research for Service Planning.
	Intervention Research & RCTs.

name: Psychological Research in Clinical Settings 2
description: \tNeuropsychological Research and Psychometric Testing\tQualitative Research: interviewing\tQualitative Research: methods of textual analysis\tQualitative Research: ethnography and action research\tQualitative Research: writing and reflecting\tOutcome Research/Critical Review/Meta-Analysis\tQuestionnaire Design, Survey Methods, Correlational Research Designs\tAnalysing Survey Data\tSingle Case Experiments: data analysis\tSingle Case Design: structured observational research

name: Psychological Theories and the Understanding of Crime
description: Theories of Crime, Measurement of Crime, Theories of Personality Disorders and Crime, Theories of Anger and Violence, Theories of Sex Offending, Psychopathy and Crime, Addictions and Crime, Mental Disorder and Crime

name: Psychological Therapy Foundation Course
description:
This is an APL only module, and the APL process is automatic. 

This module is level H because the criteria for automatic APL consist of a level H relevant degree or professional qualification as stated in section 14.  
To APL this module students should have either a:  
1)	degree in an appropriate subject e.g. psychology/social care, OR a prior professional qualification from a typical NHS core mental health profession ( mental health nursing, occupational therapy, social work, medicine, psychology) PLUS 2 years full time equivalent relevant clinical experience of therapeutic interventions  in general/mental health or social care. 
2)	
Individualistic decisions will be made about the suitability of particular applicants based upon the type of professional qualification, and the type of clinical experience they've had when considering appropriate students for APL.

name: Psychology Study Abroad Module
description: Students should take and pass the equivalent of 120 credits in subjects related to Psychology at an approved institution in another country.

name: Psychology and the Court System
description: Psychology and the Civil Process, The Mental Health Act, Proceedings under the Children Act, The Treatment of Victims in the Legal Process, Stalking and the Criminal Process, Criminal Case Review Commission, Vulnerable Witnesses in Court, Expert Testimony in the Civil courts, Restorative Justice, The Parole Board

name: Psychology in Professional Practice
description: This module aims to introduce the concept of the reflective practitioner as a positive and successful model underpinning professional practice and to offer compatible approaches and techniques for students to use in order to ensure their work is based upon sound theoretical principles and is informed by evidence-based research.  Core skills of consultation and interviewing, collecting evidence and reviewing data are introduced in the context of work with professionals.  Latterly these skills are introduced in the context of work with individual pupils.  Professional and ethical issues and legislative requirements that affect professional practice are explored from both theoretical and practical perspectives, ensuring that students are competent and confident to undertake fieldwork placements.  Anti-oppressive practice and the role of power and positioning are discussed in relation to vulnerable children and families.  Supervision and professional learning are both introduced within sessions and are then worked on within tutorials and workshops.\nIn addition, This module is concerned to ensure that trainees rapidly develop a secure working knowledge of the policy and legislative infra-structure within which they will conduct their practice as educational psychologists.  The module also aims to ensure that they understand the 'core business', culture and practices of settings in which they will work.  While the primary focus is upon the educational context, and upon early years and school settings in particular, this module also aims to ensure that trainees have a secure appreciation of the role, responsibilities, structure and operational practices of other public sector services and voluntary agencies.Content addresses educational legislation; school and classroom ecology, curriculum, pedagogy and assessment requirements (Foundation Curriculum, Key Stage 1-4, and Post-16 education and training); schools' pastoral remit, PSHE and Citizenship Education, discipline and behaviour management in schools; anti-bullying and child-protection policy and procedures; staffing; schools' links with external agencies from Education, Health, Social Services and the voluntary sector; services to parents and families; and multi-agency teams.Related practical work aims to give trainees experience of working in schools as psychologists, so that, in part, contextual learning is incidental, as trainees work alongside classroom teachers, teaching assistants, SENCOs, Connexions Personal Advisors and others, whilst undertaking observational and other psychologically-based tasks relating to other Year 1 modules.

name: Psychology, Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice
description: Overview of the Practice of Criminal Justice, Legislation, Psychology of Sentencing and Theories of Punishment, Police Techniques of Investigation and Cognitive Interviewing, Witness Identification, Theories of Offender Profiling, Offender Profiling In Practice, Interviewing Children and Vulnerable Adults, Law and Mentally Disordered Offenders, Expert Evidence.\t

name: Public Economic Management
description: The motivating idea for the PEMF programme is that it is possible for working public sector economists to improve and update their analytic and practical skills by learning techniques of analysing current economic management problems facing government, and acquiring additional economic and financial data and the means to analyse it.  Students on the programme acquire computer skills and work with real databases, from the international and national sources.  The analytical techniques acquired are applied through practical exercises and interpretation of results.  Public Economic Management provides an overview of issues and analytical techniques, working inwards from the maro to the sectoral and local level.

name: Public Management and Governance in a Changing World
description:
This module focuses on how public management and governance has been evolving and how it might be expected to develop into the future under different models and in different countries. The module introduces students to both theoretical perspectives on the dynamics of change and empirical experience of public management and governance in international contexts.
The content is arranged into eight key themes as follows:
1. The Nature of Change in Public Management and Governance
2. The Roots of Public Management and Governance
3. The Rise of the New Public Management
4. The Advent of Network Governance
5. Towards Public Value
6. The Regulatory State
7. A Trusted and Ethical Public Service?
8. Public Management and Governance into the Future

name: Public Policy and Evidence (Blended Learning)
description: This module provides participants with an overview of social science research methods, focusing particularly on the role and process of research in the contemporary public policy context. The role of research and evidence both in policy-making and in evaluating the impacts of policies is explored. In addition to providing enhanced knowledge and understanding about research in the social sciences, and in public policy in particular, the module offers a vital foundation for the dissertations that each participant prepares as part of their Masters Degree.  The module examines the philosophical basis of social science research, including the methodology that underpins research decisions, as well as the ethical and confidentiality responsibilities that lie with all social researchers.  Quantitative and qualitative research traditions are explored in the module, particularly their respective values and limits in relation to different types of research problem. The module also covers commonly-used techniques and tools for gathering evidence, data analysis; finally, the role of research  in public policy development, implementation and evaluation is discussed.

name: Qualitative Research Methods
description: This module aims to introduce the student to the basic principles of qualitative research, its role and purpose, as well as its limitations, with a view to enabling the student to design their own qualitative study, analyse and interpret qualitative data and critically assess qualitative work performed by others.\n\nThrough a series of theoretical and practical lectures and workshops, students will be introduced to a variety of qualitative research methods and the analysis process for qualitative data, which have been developed and used within health and medical research.  In addition to taught elements of the module and required readings, students will be encouraged to learn through applying qualitative thinking to their professional interest/ experience and through practical sessions encompassing all aspects of carrying out a research project (design, data collection and analysis). They will also be introduced to criteria for quality and rigour and approaches to critical appraisal as appropriate for different methodologies and traditions.

name: Quantum Mechanics and Optics and Waves
Radiation Physics
description: This module will give students a broad knowledge of medical physics as it applies to the clinical practice of radiotherapy.  Theoretical as well as practical aspects of handling and calculating radiation doses will be covered.  The course is modelled on the physics syllabus of the FRCR Part I examinations and will therefore provide suitable preparation for this professional examination.

name: Railway Systems Synthesis B
description: This unit has been created to encourage students to develop, through in-depth independent study, their understanding and know-how in the areas of the class-taught modules associated with Railway Systems Synthesis A as co-requisites. The submissions made as part of this unit allow the assessment of the particular know-how and understanding.Students registered for this module are provided with 4 assignment briefs, each of which relates to one of the 4 class-taught modules that are the co-requisites for this unit. Additional information and guidance are provided as appropriate. 3 h face to face tutorials are arranged for full-time students for each of the 4 assignments, about 3 weeks after the respective class-taught unit. Part-time students may opt to attend the tutorial or may elect instead to use the telephone / e-mail support offered by the module leader for all students. Successful performance in this module requires that students identify and analyse additional literature and interview derived material, as well as other sources con¬taining information relevant to the given topics.All sources used must be referenced using the Harvard method, as specified in the guideline produced by the University of Birmingham Information Service. Candidates may also provide a bibliography, if appropriate. Each piece of continuously assessed work should contain between 3000 and 4000 words, unless stated otherwise, supported with diagrams and figures and including a detailed analysis. It is an essential requirement that the analysis and its results are presented in an academically rigorous manner. The 4 pieces of continuously assessed work must cover the following areas related to railway systems engineering and integration:Assignment on the mechanical design aspects of railway rolling stock: A suggested topic with explanatory notes will be provided as part of the module Railway Rolling Stock Systems Design (TC), e.g., `Analyse the relationships between major subsystems and components of a railway vehicle¿. However, students may also agree a topic of their choice with the module leader of the module mentioned. In this case, a 200 word outline must be submitted to the programme director for approval.Assignment on the principles and applications of systems engineering: A suggested topic with explanatory notes will be provided as part of the module Systems Engineering and Integration for Dependability (TC), e.g., `Address the issues involved in applying human factors analysis that occur in the V-process¿. How¬ever, students may also agree a topic of their choice with the module leader of the module mentioned. In this case, a 200 word outline must be submitted to the programme director for approval.Assignment on the design of railway control systems: A suggested topic with explanatory notes will be provided as part of the module Train Control Systems Engineering (TC), e.g., `Calculate the capacity of a simple junction of two railway lines by creating an appropriate model¿. Since this is a mathematically focused topic, the word count is between 2000 and 3000 but this must be supported by substantive calculations. Students may also agree a topic of their choice with the module leader of the module mentioned. In this case, a 200 word outline must be sub¬mitted to the programme director for approval.Assignment on human factors in the railway industry: A suggested topic with explanatory notes will be provided as part of the module Ergonomics and Human Factors for Railways (TC), e.g., `Design a new passenger information kiosk¿. Since this is an application focused topic, the word count is limited to 2500 word.

name: Real & Complex Analysis
description:
This module starts by developing the theory of continuous and differentiable functions of one real variable introduced in Real Analysis and the Calculus.  It places the familiar techniques of differentiation, such as the Chain Rule, on a firm theoretical foundation and proves some of the key results of real analysis such as the Intermediate Value Theorem, the Mean Value Theorem and Taylor's Theorem.  The basic theory of integration on a closed bounded interval is also developed.

Differentiable functions of a single complex variable are then considered.  This study reveals a deep and fundamental theory whose development, by some of the giants of mathematics, such as Euler, Gauss, Riemann and Cauchy, began at the end of the 18th century.  This surprisingly elegant branch of mathematics, known as Complex Analysis, has many dramatic applications across mathematics, engineering and the physical sciences. It quickly provides us with powerful new techniques of integration and has far-reaching consequences in theoretical physics, electronics, fluid mechanics and thermodynamics. 

Underlying topological properties of Euclidean space common to both real and complex analysis are mentioned throughout the module.

name: Regenerating Urban Communities (for Geographers)
description: This module is designed to explore the experience of communities engaged in urban regeneration. There is an explicit focus on community involvement and the role it plays in relation to the regeneration of urban neighbourhoods. There is a focus on exploring the experience of community-based solutions and activities in relation to urban regeneration. It combines teaching, class discussion, visits and project work to enable students to experience at first hand the regeneration process at work from a community perspective.

name: Religion in Contemporary Global Politics I
description: TThis module provides students with an advanced level understanding of the theoretical and conceptual debates about the role of religion in contemporary global politics. Traditionally the study of political science and international relations has framed the understanding of religion within the context of secularisation and the nation-state. This interpretation is being increasingly contested by the impact of globalisation and the rise of anti-secular movements. The module will critically examine the secularisation thesis as applied to the 'West' (developed countries) and the 'East' (underdeveloped countries) and evaluate the impact of globalisation on collective religious identities.Following an introduction to the theoretical perspectives the course will focus on three particular themes:Religious NationalismWhat explains the rise of religious nationalism in South Asia (India, Pakistan and Afghanistan) and militant Islam Middle-East? How do we account for the decline of 'secular' nationalism in developing countries? Religious Identities and Mobilisation Are religious identities easier to politically mobilise than non-religious identities? How can we explain the success of the religious right in the US? Religious Transnationalism Religious identities play a significant role in the politics of transnational groups. How has globalisation impacted on religious transnationalism? The module concludes by reflecting on the wider implications for the study of politics and international relations of organised religious movements today.

name: Research Dissertation
description: The module will enable students to select an area of interest and develop a research question, identify an appropriate design to answer the research question, and to undertake and present the findings of the project orally and in writing. The selected research question will be appropriate to the aims of the individual student's programme.Opportunities for carrying out projects within existing staff research programmes will be provided.Each student will be allocated a supervisor for their project who will contribute an appropriate background of subject and/or methodological expertise.

name: Research Methodologies in the History of Medicine
description: This module is concerned with both training in historical method and methodological approaches (e.g. historiography) as well as approaching particular issues in the history of medicine. Students will explore a number of topics and seek to introduce themselves to different research techniques in the field, particularly withy a view to providing them with the necessary research skills. In doing so, they will focus on a number of concepts of health and disease, from, antiquity to the present day, stressing the relationship between practitioner and patient and healthcare systems through the ages.

name: Research Methods
description:
This module provides students with an introduction to research, the philosophy behind it, approaches, use of statistics and critical analysis of published work.
Students will learn the fundamental principles and ideas necessary for the instigation and successful completion of an independent (supervised) research project.  The principles will be applied to specific, relevant research areas.  
Lectures will be used to provide generic research skills, while problem-based learning will focus on specific research questions.

name: Research Methods (distance learning)
description: The module provides an introduction to research methods applied to biomedical, clinical and health sciences. The module will comprise a number of blocks including: critical appraisal of previous research and the development of a research question, research design, measurement approaches, sampling, statistical analysis, qualitative research and service evaluation. It is proposed that students may subsequently register for more advanced research training modules as appropriate.

name: Research Methods in International Business
description:
This module exposes students to the range of research strategies available in social research as well as specific methodologies, tools and techniques that can be applied within these strategies. While the content of the module will be good preparation for further academic research work, the primary aim of the module is pragmatic and practical. As such therefore, the module will address the practicalities of: finding data sources, interviewing, survey methods, etc, and critically, will expose students to the relative costs and benefits of these approaches.

The module will introduce students to a range of analytical techniques, and in particular, will explore the use of 'big data'.
The module will also be critical preparation for the main dissertation module.

name: Research Project (MSc Geotechnical Engineering and Management)
Research Project in Immunology and Immunotherapy
description: Students will carry out a detailed investigation, using laboratory techniques, of a cutting-edge research question relevant to immunology or immunotherapy. This project will involve working as part of a team within a research group, producing novel scientific data, analysing and interpreting this data, and carrying out onward experimental design. The research projects will be available across a broad range of cutting-edge immunology/immunotherapy research groups within the College of MDS. Some projects will also be available within a number of external commercial organisations, including University of Birmingham spin-out companies and biotechnology/pharmaceutical companies with an interest in immunotherapy.\nDuring the research project students will present a poster of their work to academics and peers.

name: Research Skills
description: The material covered falls into two areas. Information skills: retrieving and recording bibliographic information from manual and computerised sources. Transferable skills: intellectual property rights; time management; report writing; oral presentation.

name: Research Skills and Methods (Distance Learning)
description: The module consists of 11 sessions of core skills, worth 20 credits. 6 out of 11 sessions are taught by the College of Arts and Law as components of its generic research skills programme (these are 6 online courses). The other five sessions are taught by members of the School of Philosophy, Theology and Religion focusing on discipline specific topics. Some of these sessions will focus on core philosophical skills and others introduce students to more interdisciplinary research. All the 11 sessions will be delivered online.The discipline specific topics that will be addressed include at least some of the following: 1. Critical Thinking in philosophy2. Reading in philosophy3. Research skills (finding literature appropriate for PGT study in the school)4. Dissertation planning5. Presenting philosophical arguments in written work

name: Research Skills and Methods in African Studies
Research Skills and Methods in Philosophy
description: The module helps to guide each MA, MSc, and MRes student through the preparation of a research proposal for their dissertation. The discipline-specific topics that will be addressed may include some of the following: •\tCritical Thinking in philosophy  •\tReading in philosophy •\tResearch skills (finding literature appropriate for PGT study in the school)•\tDissertation planning •\tPresenting philosophical arguments in written work.

name: Research Skills and Training
description: A research project based module, designed to introduce students to project based training. Students are required to train under close supervision on a predefined topic in agreement with the supervisor. The training is designed to promote independent learning with supervision, reflection upon and analysis of results, and forward planning. Some of the projects also involve group training, thus development of team-based skills is an important aspect. The results of the training are communicated using a written report to the host research group/team and researcher team leader.

name: Research Skills for Team Science
description: This module introduces students to a variety of different research techniques across a broad spectrum of disciplines. The aim is not to be specific preparation for your own specific academic discipline and/or dissertation but instead a broader training to support future interdisciplinary work. It is delivered by a series of guest lecturers talking about a method that they use.  These sessions are supported by seminars which will critique existing interdisciplinary research, discuss the methods in more detail, and consider benefits, challenges, and skills involved in conducting team science effectively.

name: Research Study Methods
description: LM Research Study Methods (2nd year trainees only) Development of research questions and hypothesesSystematic review approachesResearch project planning, design, analysis and presentationStatistics revisionIntroduction to advanced inferential statistics: data management and multivariate analysis on SPSSIntroduction to qualitative methods: surveys, observational studies, and sampling

name: Research Systematic Literature Review
description: Sources of literature and coverageReviews in contextFormulating questionsSearching in a systematic waySorting source materialInclusion/Exclusion criteriaQuality assessmentData extraction and synthesisSummarising informationCritical appraisal

name: Research Taster
description:
The College of Medical and Dental Sciences is very research active.  Medical students should develop an understanding of the nature of the research undertaken.  During the research taster students select from a menu offered to their M group a research topic they would like to know more about.

The students then spend some time (approx. 2 hours) with an active researcher in that field, who discusses their research with them, allows them to view experiments being undertaken, (if appropriate) and provides the students with a paper authored by the research group to appraise.

Later on the students and the researcher meet again.  The students will discuss their appraisal of the paper with the researcher, and can ask questions about any areas they did not understand. 

Students are expected to produce a summary of the article which explains it in a way accessible to an educated person, who is not informed in this field.

name: Reviewing Education for Health Professionals
description: This is the first module in the PG Diploma in Education for Health Professionals. Its purpose is to enable you to access and assess existing information which is relevant to your educational setting.\nThere is no point in re-inventing the wheel, but there is an overwhelming quantity of published research and many sources of data relevant to education for health professionals. Therefore, in this module, you will gain practical knowledge of how to retrieve relevant literature and data. You will practice searching electronic databases, look at existing questionnaires and access organisation-specific data. You will also learn to use reference management software to organise retrieved literature and for writing papers. You will evaluate the different types of literature review.\n

name: Risk Management
description: The Risk Management module is the final taught module for the MSc Occupational Health.  The module links all the previous modules into the Risk Management framework.  This module provides the students with a comprehensive understanding of practical management of risks arising from the workplace and the decision making.  The module covers approaches to managing organisation and individual risk.\nThe module involves discussion of case scenarios (clinical and non-clinical) and a site visit to understand the requirements for developing an Occupational Health Service for a defined workforces and activities.

name: River Environmental Management Dissertation
description: The dissertation represents the culmination of the training received in the MSc.  It offers a chance to apply the theoretical and applied training gathered through the taught elements of the MSc to the analysis and solution of a river environmental management research problem identified by the student in consultation with the module leader and dissertation supervisor.

name: Rolling Stock and Infrastructure Interactions
description: The infrastructure portion of this module is designed to give students an in-depth technical knowledge of the rolling stock and infrastructure systems and an understanding of how to design and maintain them in order to minimise risk and maximise safety. Railway alignment design, gauging, and maintenance issues are discussed in detail, as are issues relating to the rolling contact behaviour of the wheel-rail interface and to rail vehicle dynamics, including the steering of wheelsets. Aerodynamics, body-shell design and crashworthiness issues, choice of materials, vehicle maintenance, and the design and behaviour suspensions are covered in some detail. Also addressed are the topics of station design, station systems and infrastructure power supply components. The module is managed by the Department of Civil Engineering of the University of Birmingham, with inputs and guest speakers from the railway industry.

name: Running a Clinical Business
description: This module is specifically designed for distance learning to enable students to develop clear understanding of the fundamental theoretical principles of dental business management.Students will be able to apply comprehensive educational guidelines to enable assessment, analysis and management of personal and business development and clinical governance in general dental practice, to compliment the clinical skills gained in the other five modules. In this respect, cost effectiveness of different restorative techniques will be addressed. Principles of advanced in-surgery infection control will be discussed.In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: Safety Management Systems
description: This course is primarily intended to provide students with an awareness of the issues associated with conducting technical safety activities within an organisational and regulatory environment. It also aims to develop skills at applying theoretical safety engineering knowledge in situations constrained by available staff competency, resources and organisational culture. This module is run by the HISE group at the University of York.

name: Science of Medicines 2
description:
This module will provide students with an understanding of the formulation principles and manufacturing methods used in the preparation of solid dosage forms and parenteral, ophthalmic, intranasal and inhaled formulations. The module will also address pharmaceutical packaging, sterilisation of parenteral and ophthalmic products, contamination control and assessment of product stability.
Material will be taught using a combination of large group lectures and small group workshops, along with the provision of online material.
