A team based learning exercise will take place in combination with HDT 2.2. The theoretical elements of the module will be supported through practical laboratory experiments and a pharmaceutical problem solving exercise.
Assessment will be through written examinations (MCQ, SAQ), practical laboratory experiment write-ups and completion of the pharmaceutical problem solving exercise.
All modules are integrative. Students will develop an appreciation of how knowledge gained through this module may be applied to other second year modules, specifically The Professional Pharmacist, Health, Disease and Therapeutics 2.1 and 2.2 and Chemistry for Pharmacists 2. This application of knowledge will be further tested throughout the course progression.

name: Science of Medicines 3
description:
This module will provide students with an understanding of the formulation principles and manufacturing methods used in the preparation of modified-release dosage forms (e.g. sustained-release tablets, transdermal patches, implants). The module will address the principles of drug delivery and nanomedicine. The use of different delivery systems to delivery therapeutic e.g. anticancer drugs and diagnostic molecules will be explored. The delivery of proteins and other macromolecules will also be discussed. The module will also highlight the principles of pharmacokinetics.

Material will be taught using a combination of large group lectures and small group workshops, along with the provision of online material.
Assessment will be through a written examination (MCQ, SAQ), written practical laboratory experiment write-ups and completion of the pharmaceutical problem solving exercise.

All modules are integrative. Students will develop an appreciation of how knowledge gained through this module may be applied to other first year modules, specifically The Professional Pharmacist and Health, Disease and Therapeutics 5 and 6. This application of knowledge will be further tested throughout the course progression.

name: Second Language Learning
description: The learning of a foreign language is considered from a number of angles: general theories of learning, learner variables, the nature of interlanguage, classroom input and interaction, 'focused' communicative tasks, and strategies for language-processing and learning.  Theory is related to practical issues through consideration of issues of course and materials design for learner autonomy and task-based learning.

name: Secondary School Studies 3
description: University based seminars, developing an understanding of the needs of learners within a subject discipline and secondary schools.  Reflection upon teaching placement (School Placement 2) in schools, continuing to learn to plan and evaluate teaching experiences to consider the role of learners.  University and school based seminars on whole school issues - e.g. equal opportunities, management of the teaching environment.

name: Secondary School Studies 4
description: University based seminars, developing an understanding of the needs of learners within main subject discipline or alternative subject and secondary schools.

name: Service Operations Management
description: The Service Operations Management module is about improving organisations to make them better for customers and service providers. The module will develop students' understanding of the concepts, tools and techniques relating to process design and delivery, including the analysis of process design from the customer's perspective.\n\nThe module is integrative in approach and uses analytical lenses from marketing, organisational behaviour, strategy and behavioural psychology. Case, and other illustrative material in the module comes from both profit and non-profit sectors.

name: Shakespeare's Legacy
description: This module considers the adaptation and appropriation of Shakespeare's plays, persona, and possessions from 1660 to the present day, paying particular attention to how changes and developments in theatre practice, aesthetic tastes, social concerns, political events, the heritage industry, and commercial markets have shaped the history of Shakespeare's 'afterlife'. The module looks at trends broadly chronologically, focusing on particular examples as it traces how the plays (and other Shakespeariana) were received and reinterpreted in light of different artistic, intellectual, and commercial movements from the late seventeenth to early twenty-first centuries. The distinction between 'adaptations', 'appropriations', 'translations', and 'versions' will be questioned, and students will be invited to consider the extent to which the different adaptations they read or see rely upon the original Shakespearian text for context and meaning.\n\n

name: Site Decommissioning & Environmental Management
description: This module seeks to provide the theoretical and applied knowledge base that will underpin a student's potential future professional activity in this field. The module syllabus will include: environmental impact of nuclear power; site monitoring strategies & methods; hazard identification & reduction; environmental impact/risk assessment; environmental principles applicable to site decommissioning; decommissioning strategies & technologies; remediation methods; hydrogeological risk assessment and groundwater modelling.   These topics will be illustrated by case studies throughout and student learning will be underpinned by problem-solving exercises based on these case studies.

name: Social and Economic Determinants of Global Health
description:
The module will involve 75 hours of student study time in total.  Using the lectures for information giving and small-group teaching for contextualisation, students will be introduced to aspects of healthcare organisation relating to different areas of international health, such as water and sanitation, population movement and children's health.  In addition, a bid is being submitted as part of the E3 initiative, for students to be introduced to the role of commerce in health care including training and support on developing an idea and making a pitch for further funding.


Students will be supported to develop an idea for commercial development.  Each will make a pitch for funding for their idea, which will be judged for their end of module assessment.

name: Sociology and Social Policy
description: Sociology and Social Policy

name: Software Workshop 1 (MSc)
description: This module introduces and develops object oriented design and programming skills. It introduces the Java programming language as an example of an object oriented programming language and develops software development skills through Java.

name: Sources and Research Techniques for the Study of West Midlands in the Modern Period
description:
The module will analyse sources drawn from the Boulton and Watt Collection in Birmingham City Archives. This collection comprises an unparalleled resource for historians of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. For the late modern period the module will make use of material from the University of Birmingham Special Collection in the main library such as the papers of the Chamberlain family; of the papers held by the Birmingham City Archives such as those of the Birmingham Women's Suffrage Society and other local sources such as the Fircroft Survey on Race Relations.
The field trip will visit an important site for the local history of the Midlands in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries such as Ironbridge.
Students will also be introduced to ways of analysing source material, including census returns, photographs, archaeological data and oral history.

name: Special Relativity and Probability and Random Processes
Sport and Physical Activity Policy
description: This module aims to develop students' critical understanding and thinking of policy making process in relation to sport and physical activity. It will examine major policy responses to social and health-related issues, and will explore how these have been deployed in sport and physical activity contexts. The module will also examine the major models and phases of the policy process, how evidence is gathered for policy making, how policy is enacted in practice, how research has impact on policy making, and the methods used to monitor and evaluate policy effectiveness in sport and physical activity.

name: Statistical Methods in Finance and Economics
description: This course is designed for students with limited or no prior finance or economic theory background. It emphasizes the understanding of quantitative methods, model evaluations, and the techniques for empirical studies in finance and economics. \nThis module starts with an introduction to general financial and economic concepts, then it will cover the basics and extension of ordinary least square methods, heteroscedasticity, autocorrelation, multicollinearity, model specifications, simultaneous equation models, binary and discrete choice models, qualitative and limited dependent variable models, time series analysis, panel data models, and nonparametric analysis with their applications in finance and Economics. Students will gain hands-on experience formulating and estimating models, interpreting results, and making forecasts.

name: Statistics for Health Economics I
description: This module focuses on core concepts in statistics in Semester 1, in preparation for more advanced statistical approaches for health economists in a later module.  Students will develop critical understanding of published research in health care related areas and be able to discuss and interpret quantitative results from such.Statistical subjects covered will include: types of data and data presentation, descriptive statistics, basic probability, distribution theory including the normal distribution and its properties, sampling theory, principles and techniques, inferential statistics, analysis of categorical and continuous data, non-parametric tests, correlation and regression.\n

name: Statistics for Health Economics II
description: This module builds on the previous module Statistics for Health Economics I, by covering more advanced statistical approaches required by health economists.  Students will develop critical understanding of published research in health care related areas and be able to discuss and interpret quantitative results from such.Statistical subjects covered will include: bivariate and multivariate regression analysis, Bayesian interpretation of probability and Bayesian updating\n

name: Strategic Management
description: This module concentrates on the importance of strategy and the role it plays in the development of effective public management. Students will also evaluate the variables that must be considered during the planning and implementation stages, including the importance of different stakeholder groups and how the use of data can inform and shape more effective strategic options.

name: Strategy
description:
The strategy module provides a general introduction of the basic concepts, principles, and major analytical approaches that are utilised in strategic management decision making.
Strategic Management has evolved as a discipline, from the rigid planning into a much more flexible process, more accurately described as strategic thinking. The global world of commerce is becoming more dynamic and complex, requiring managers to formulate and implement strategies based on consistent congruence between the firm and its environment. The module will focus initially on systematic external and internal analysis, and then cover formulation and implementation of corporate and business level strategies.
The module includes the discussion and analysis of organisational purpose, emphasising the influence of values and stakeholder expectations on decision making. The majority of the module is devoted to formal strategic audit and the formulation and implementation of long run strategies by business organisations in the context of both their particular competitive environments and the ever-changing, uncertain general environment of business.
The module will anchor the field of strategy in its historical and academic roots. In so doing we will provide a foundation for critical assessment of theoretical and empirical approaches to Strategy.

name: Summer School Advanced Experiential Learning
description:
This is optional 10 credit module in the PGCARMS.  It will provide UoB postgraduate researchers with opportunity to accredit advanced experiential learning gained through participation in a relevant summer school completed alongside their PhD studies.  These summer schools will, in most cases, be organised by external providers (e.g. professional bodies).

The module will consist of a minimum of100 hours learning through a combination of contact hours (e.g. lectures and practical workshops) and independent study.  Candidates will be required to produce at least one clear written output as a minimum (e.g. report or PowerPoint presentation) at the end of this period.

The module candidates will also be required to complete a 500 word self-reflective assignment linked to this module which will contribute towards the self-reflective portfolio all PGCARMS candidates must complete.

name: Supply and Demand (Integrated Case Based Learning 4)
Supporting Academic Writing Skills Development for Postgraduates
description: Supporting Academic Writing Skills Development is part of an introductory programme of short courses in higher education learning and teaching for postgraduates who have, or expect to have, a teaching, tutoring or laboratory-demonstrating role.\nThe course has been designed specifically for Specialist Study Skills PGTAs appointed by the College of Arts and Law.  The session explores features of what might be considered a 'good' essay across of range of humanities subjects, and ways in which tutors might best support undergraduates in the essay writing process. Participants will be given sample essays to compare as a way of familiarizing them with the kind of writing support they will need to give in their tutoring role.

name: Supporting Learning Through Assessment and Feedback
description:
The module offers participants the opportunity to critically review existing assessment and feedback methods on a module within their own discipline area and to develop a rationale for change that could be used as a basis for proposing a modification to a module within their own context.
 
Face to face sessions will examine some of the principles and literature around enhancing assessment and feedback and will include consideration of assessment as part of curriculum design, assessment for  learning, innovations around assessment and feedback methods, effective use of assessment criteria and developing high quality feedback. The sessions will also offer opportunities for formative peer review and feedback.
 
The assessment for the module will comprise two parts. The first is a fully justified rationale for change to an assessment process within a module with which the participant is familiar. This will include a critical review of existing formative and summative assessment and feedback methods, consideration of a range of alternatives and proposals for change that are informed by evidence from a range of stakeholders as well as peer feedback. The second is a fully worked assessment brief and accompanying marking criteria that could be rolled out to students if the proposed changes are implemented.
 
The module will be supported by a range of on-line resources and activities that will reinforce the face to face sessions.

name: Supportive and End of Life Care
description: The module is offered to students as part of the specialist negotiated pathway within the MSc Advancing Practice (Nursing). It is also offered as a CPD module. There is an increasing need for nurses working at advanced levels of practice with patients who are near the end of life or recently bereaved. The will prepare nurses to manage the complex decision-making, communication, therapeutic care and issues around emotional labour, ethics and leadership in regards to end of life care.This module is delivered in partnership with clinical experts based in the new Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham, Marie Curie, Birmingham St Mary's Hospice, Birmingham Community Trust.

name: Surface Engineering
description: This module is designed to introduce the principles of surface engineering and its application to the design and manufacturing of engineering components.  It covers design aspects of tribology, an introduction to a range of surface engineering technologies (including thermal, thermochemical, ion beam, energy beam, thermal spraying, PVD/CVD techniques), a review of applications of advanced surface engineering technologies, surface analysis and testing techniques, and surface system design.  Cost-effectiveness, fitness for purpose and environmental aspects of surface engineering are also discussed as appropriate throughout the course.

name: Sustainability in the Food Industry
description: Sustainability and the need to address environmental issues is a significant driver in the food industry. From "Farm to Fork" the Food Industry uses significant amounts of resources in agriculture, production, transport and other sectors; in addition, it generates many types of wastes. This module provides an overview of the main issues facing the food industry, including the economic, legislative and political contexts which influence the options available to industry to manage and minimise its environmental impact.

name: Sustainable Cities
description: This module examines how the concept of sustainable development and the implications of climate change shape the principles and practice of spatial planning in urban contexts.It begins by critically considering how our understanding of sustainability, including contemporary debates about climate change, peak oil and well-being, have reshaped thinking about planning approaches in recent years. It then explores what this means in practice across several dimensions of spatial planning, beginning with land use, urban form and transport issues. The module then goes on to consider social and economic aspects of sustainable development including debates about the new localism and transition cities. Though case studies and projects, students also develop skills in devising creative planning approaches that embed sustainability principles in urban development, particularly in regeneration contexts. The module also draws in a strong comparative element through a field trip to a major European city. This provides an opportunity to understand alternative approach to the challenge of sustainable urban development, and to reflect critically on contemporary practice in the UK.

name: Systemic Clinical Practice Skills (Level 1)
description: The acquisition of advanced, transferable, clinic abilities, including organisational methods and practical techniques is a vital part of applying a systemic approach to psychotherapy in clinical practice, across agency contexts.  This module will take students through the process of expressing and implementing systemic and narrative frameworks studied in other compulsory modules, in clinical practice.  It will provide direct supervision of clinical practice, and practical tuition in service construction & delivery, case note construction, case presentation and report writing.  The module covers all aspects of systemic psychotherapy using actual clinical practice to train students in preparation, consultation and documentation. Students will gain a detailed understanding of the process from service construction to referral to service delivery and audit, including themes such as improving client access and client participation.  It will consider the multiple historical and contemporary contexts within which clinical practice is given meaning.Teaching and Learning methods include clinical practicum, live and video supervision of students clinical work, live demonstrations by staff, DVDs, case discussion led by staff, case discussion led by students; simulations

name: Systemic Clinical Practice Skills (Level 2)
description: The acquisition of transferable, advanced clinic abilities, including organisational methods and practical techniques is a vital part of applying a systemic approach to psychotherapy in clinical practice, across agency contexts.  This module will build on Clinical practice skills module 1, and require and expect students to take greater initiative in managing the process of expressing and implementing systemic and narrative frameworks studied in other compulsory modules, in complex clinical practice.  It will provide direct supervision of clinical practice, and practical tuition in service construction & delivery, case note construction, case presentation and report writing.  The module covers all aspects of systemic psychotherapy using actual clinical practice to train students in managing and supervising the preparation, consultation, documentation of systemic psychotherapy and consultation.  Students will take greater initiative in managing the process from service construction to referral to service delivery and audit, including themes such as improving client access and client participation.  It will consider the multiple historical and contemporary contexts within which clinical practice is given meaning.Teaching and Learning methods include clinical practicum, live and video supervision of students clinical work, live demonstrations by staff, DVDs, case discussion led by staff, case discussion led by students; simulations

name: Systemic and Narrative Theory (Level 1)
description: Discourses powerfully shape a person's narrative and the life choices that emerge from this narrative.  This applies to therapists as well as the people who consult them.  This module is designed to create a teaching/learning context in which staff and students deconstruct a range of modern and post-modern discourses that are necessary to inspire, validate and support the systemic Approach, Methods and Techniques (AMT) to psychotherapy, consultation, supervision and training.  This module is reflexively related to the module's clinical practice skills 1, and research 1, and all three modules support and 'feed each other' in turn, and provide a platform for development in the second year of the course.  Lectures, workshops and seminars, PPD, video demonstrations, and simulations, introduce this range of discourses that guide practitioners in the moral and technical complexities of their day to day practice.   Teaching methods create contexts that encourage and enable students to interrogate these frameworks within multiple levels of context, and reflexively relate them to practice.  This reflexive process is intended to enable students to develop a critical appreciation of the different discourses involved in the construction of an ethical and effective professional practice.

name: Systemic and Narrative Theory (Level 2)
description: Discourses powerfully shape a person's narrative and the life choices that emerge from this narrative.  This applies to therapists as well as the people who consult them.  This module is designed to build on Systemic and Narrative Theory (Level 2), Emphasis will be on how students can position themselves so as to empower clients in the generation and amplification of a discourse of change. The further development of ethical postures will be supported through rigorous exploration of different ethical theories.  Lectures, workshops and seminars promote students' knowledge, ability and skills to integrate and interpret this range of discourses into their own style and agency practice at the levels of Approach, Method and Technique (AMT).  This module is reflexively related to the modules clinical practice skills 2, and research 2, and all three modules support and 'feed each other' in turn, and provide a platform for students to create a self-directed plan for their post course development.

name: Systems Engineering
description: Systems Failure; Systems Engineering; Supplier Development Strategies; Management of Change; Need for change, project team approach, operations strategy, choice of control system including Just-in-Time and Kanban; Implementation etc.

name: Systems Engineering and Integration for Dependability
description: In the context of the MSc programme in Railway Systems Engineering and Integration, dependability is defined as a combination of levels of reliability, punctuality, system robustness and safety that satisfies the needs of stakeholders. The unit on systems engineering and integration for dependability is designed to cover five broad areas: (i) Systems engineering approaches and management of the engineering process, (ii) Management engineering and project risk, (iii) Reliability and life-cycle engineering, (iv) Systems engineering tools and (v) Safety cases and human factors issues. Lectures cover hard and soft systems approaches, appropriate systems engineering tools, case studies and an in depth review of safety case theory and practice. Human factors, organisational systems and the management of risk in organisations are also addressed in the lectures. The module includes a visit to a systems house engaged on railway maintenance and track inspection.This unit is aimed at imparting to students the fundamental concepts underpinning the design and implementation of major railway engineering and operations projects. The module is also intended to provide students with the tools to assess the risks of major projects, both technical and financial, and to carry out thorough reliability analyses of technical and organisational systems.

name: Teaching Experience 1
description: Students observe lessons and teach on average half a normal teacher's timetable, providing relevant documentation for every lesson taught.  Discussions with tutors, mentors and teachers focus on pupils' learning and the experience of teaching.  This module is closely linked with the School Studies modules where the theoretical underpinning of the practice is discussed to enable the students to analyse the ideas in practice.  Much of the module depends upon student's individual work as a practitioner and reflecting upon practice.

name: Teaching Experience 2
description: This module explores the continuing reflective and analytical development of the student as they review teaching and learning.  This module is closely linked with the School Studies modules where the theoretical underpinning of the practice is discussed to enable the students to analyse the ideas in practice.  The contact time is to allow students to develop their theoretical framework and to develop pathways for future personal and professional development.

name: Teaching and Learning in Deaf Education (including teaching placement) (Distance Education)
description: This double module is based upon two periods of assessed teaching and upon the log books, recording activities and visits.  The module aims to develop skills in planning to meet the educational and developmental needs of hearing-impaired children, in teaching and in the evaluation of personal and observed teaching.

name: Teaching and Learning in EAL: Special Studies in Bilingualism in Education
description: This will be a special project module in which candidates will investigate an aspect of their professional work in light of their learning in the first two modules: 11 11528 Introduction to Bilingualism in Education. This module will set the foundation for later work in the programme of study. It opens with a discussion of second language development, examines issues in the classroom context and pedagogical approaches, and provides some grounding in key topics in assessment and literacy development for bilingual learners. The concluding unit addresses some of the concerns in collaborative working relationships. 11 11535 Academic Language and Learning for Bilingual Learners. This module addresses knoledge about language, classroom discourse and linguistic diversity in relation to the teaching of bilingual learners. It provides practitioners working with bilingual learners the knowledge and sills to develop 'language conscious' pedagogy in the curriculum and to develop 'whole school' approaches to policy and practice for bilingual learners.

name: Techniques for Fuel Cell Characterisation
description: The module aims to develop an understanding of the measurements techniques used in development and study of fuel cells. The course is sub-divided into two sections:a.         Electrochemical Techniques b.         Material Characterisation Techniques  The first section introduces the electrochemical techniques to understand catalyst performance, durability and electrochemically active surface (ECSA) area. Working principle and types of fuel cells; concept of power, relation between current and voltage and I-V curve; concepts like reversibility and other electrochemistry concepts relevant to fuel cells are also included.  Material characterisation discusses the principles and importance of techniques available (XRD, TGS, SEM, TEM, IR, NMR) to study composition and surface characteristics of various components (catalysts, supports, MEA, GDL) of fuel cells.

name: Textual Studies in Shakespeare
description: The course will be divided into three roughly equal areas of study:1.  Shakespeare in print, early modern print technology and print culture.  This segment will situate the Shakespeare text within the technology and textual culture in which it appeared and will pay particular attention to the printing of the 1623 Shakespeare Folio.2.  Quarto and Folio texts.  In this segment students will study the differences between different quarto and Folio texts of selected Shakespeare plays, and consider various explanations for those differences.3.  Textual theory and editorial practice.  The focus here is on the way modern editions process the texts on which they are based, and the theoretical issues surrounding these practices such as textual authority, authoriality, textual materialism.  Alternatives to critical editing, such as photofacsimiles and electronic editions, will be examined.Broader objectives of the course are to suggest ways in which textual study impinges on other aspects of Shakespeare study (particularly those to do with authorship), and to provide a foundation for further work that centres on or makes reference to textual study.

name: The Birmingham Project
description:
The Birmingham Project will deliver, to undergraduate students completing their first year, the opportunity to undertake an enquiry based, interdisciplinary project in collaboration with peers from other Schools and Colleges. The Project will be delivered intensively during the final two weeks of the summer term and will introduce students to project management and enhance their team-working skills.

Students will work in groups (6-8 students) facilitated and supported by a PGTA (overseen by an academic). Students will work together on an interdisciplinary project tackling a real world 'challenge' to deliver a concrete output such as an event,  prototype/plans or report.  

A challenge will be selected from an extensive list of outlines proposed by members of staff (often in association with external organisations such as charities, local government, businesses and cultural organisations). 

Students will be expected to apply a diverse set of relevant techniques, skills and approaches in response to the respective challenge. This will involve planning, undertaking and presenting the project and development of the associated output.  

Students will be assessed via both a group and individual assessment.

name: The Development of Deaf and Hearing Impaired Children
description: None

name: The Educational Management of Deaf and Hearing Impaired Pupils (Distance Education)
description: This module considers the history, current provision and future of the education of deaf children.  Particular consideration is given to enabling deaf children to access the National Curriculum, working with the families of deaf infants, teaching literacy, the different language and communication approaches to the education of deaf children and personal and social development.

name: The Effective Practitioner (MH)
description: In exploring issues such as values, mental health policy and the historic development of mental health services students explore the complexities of collaborative working with mental health service users and carers in effective care delivery.   In order for students to gain a broader understanding of interdisciplinary working service-users, carers and specialist mental health service providers are all involved in the module delivery.  In addition students will also develop an understanding of the evidence based interventions that optimise the health, safety, well-being and quality of life for people who have mental health problems.  This module will also explore the experiences and care of people who have dual diagnoses, learning disability and mental health.\nFive week placements will take place in both community and in-patient settings.\n

name: The History of Medical Institutions, 1700-1950
description: This module is concerned with tracing current themes in the history of these institutions, examining, for example, the architectural, financial and patient histories of various types of hospital and asylum in England, Europe, North America and the Caribbean from approximately 1700-1950. It will also introduce students to the records of these medical institutions and involves a walking tour of local hospitals so as to better appreciate their local distribution, architecture and place in the community.

name: The History of Shakespeare in Performance
description: This module will consider trends of acting and directing Shakespeare from the Restoration to the present day, and will exploit the Stratford archives to undertake studies of individual actors and directors from the eighteenth century onwards. Subjects of study might include Colley Cibber, David Garrick, Henry Irving and Ellen Terry, Laurence Olivier, Peter Brook, John Barton and Sam Mendes. There will be opportunities to analyse and interpret primary evidence and to consider the cultural context(s) of performance. Plays studied will include Richard III, Hamlet, Macbeth, Antony and Cleopatra, and A Midsummer Night's Dream.

name: The Informed and Informing Clinician
description:
Content in this module has been designed specifically for distance learning and will develop high level knowledge acquisition, I.T, photography and communication skills.
Approaches to the critical appraisal of dental literature are identified with relevance to evidence-based clinical practice. 
The use of the internet in evidence-based dentistry is introduced and applied to advanced general dental practice. 
Students will develop the key skills required to devise a research or audit project.
In addition, advanced clinically relevant oral biology practical exercises will inform the clinical cases to be carried out in subsequent modules.

In reference to Regulation Section 7 that specifies students should submit assignments within 12 months of completing teaching; it should be noted that due to the flexibility of this programme assessed pieces of work are submitted when opportunity arises for the student within their practicing clinic – this may continue into subsequent academic years and therefore be outside of the academic year module teaching took place.

name: The Life and Death of Stars
The Mind Detective: Understanding how the mind works by looking at what happens when it is damaged
description:
This module is dedicated to what we know about how the mind works by looking at how it breaks down in patients with brain damage due to stroke, head-injury or neurodegenerative disease.  Students will understand the logic and practice of neuropsychological assessment, look at detailed case studies from current topics in understanding the mind based on its breakdown and examine the intersection between neuropsychological research and clinical practice.

Lecture 1: The detective's rule book – Principles of neuropsychological assessment and approaches from different schools. 
Lecture 2: The case of visible language – Sign language, chimps and brain injury.  Is language the same no matter how its produced?
Lecture 3: The case of the mirror woman and the missing maps.  How do we know where things are in space?
Lecture 4: The case of the missing consciousness.  Is consciousness an ability or an emergent property?  What do disorders of consciousness tell us?
Lecture 5:  By their actions you will know them.  Is cognition action? – the case of speech and articulation.
Lecture 6: From research to the clinic – The secret history of IQ, clinical assessment and the modular mind.
Lecture 7: From research to the clinic – Assessment, rehabilitation and rehabilitation research.  Does knowing the problem provide the solution?  How do you know if your rehabilitation is working?
Lecture 8: From research to the clinic -- The not gold standard.  The logic of clinical trials, personalised medicine and neuropsychology.
Lecture 9: From research to the clinic – Frankenstein's toolkit.  New tools for manipulating the mind.  Can they help fix it?
Lecture 10: The case of the missing mind detective.  The new empire of the brain or who needs the mind?

name: The Planner in Contemporary Society
description: This module will consider the aims and objectives of urban and regional planning in contemporary society. In particular, they will explore the extent to which planning both reflects and informs the society in which it is practised, drawing on the major strands of planning theory from the past three decades. A primary objective is to enable the students to situate the 'planner' in a societal context as an actor in a complex, value-laden polity, rather than the 'neutral' public servant. A further element in the module will be to develop their reflexive skills in determining what sort of planner they see themselves as within the wider debates identified above. It will consider issues of the role of professionals, professional ethics, etc. It seeks to develop the practice of critical and analytical reflection on personal skill, knowledge assumptions and values associated with the student's existing or potential professional activities and knowledge.

name: The Professional Pharmacist 2
description:
This second year module will build on knowledge acquired during the first year and integrate and apply information from all other second year modules. In addition the material delivered in this module will be developed and may be applied and tested in later modules of study.
Students will develop their communication and clinical skills building on their first year to support a confident and capable approach to diagnostic testing and health screening particularly related to the cardiovascular and infection themes running through related second year therapeutics modules. Interprofessional communication will be encouraged through opportunities to work together  and learn about fellow health care professionals both on campus and during professional placement activities.
Knowledge and application of the Law relating to medicines is developed, focussing on licensing of medicinal products and supply. Students will approach this learning through applied and contextualised clinical, ethical and professional scenarios.
Mathematical skills will continue to be revisited in applied through clinical dispensing classes.
Building on the foundations of Evidence Based Medicine from the first year, clinical trials will be covered in more detail differentiating between the types of trial methodology and introducing students to techniques for critical appraisal of the literature. Principles of pharmacolvigilance and drug safety will be introduced.
Knowledge from the Disease, Health and Therapeutics modules 
will be applied to public health, focussing particularly on patient attitudes to health and disease and including vaccination, health promotion and healthcare systems.
Through a series of lectures, workshops, small group teaching supported with online reference material, and professional experience 'placements', students will develop their basic consultation and clinical skills to perform procedures including blood pressure measurement, and near patient testing.
Assessment will reflect the applied and professional nature of this module using objective structured clinical examination (OSCEs) to demonstrate capability in communication, clinical and dispensing skills.
Public health, Law and ethics, evidence based medicine, human factors, and healthcare systems will be examined using MCQs and SAQs.
A separate examination will be held in mathematics related to clinical practice.
Coursework will include a presentation assignment related to adverse drug reactions and a media assignment on interprofessional working.

name: The Professional Pharmacist 3
description:
Delivered throughout the third year, this module applies and integrates learning from all of the year 3 modules with the professional practice of pharmacy and in addition delivers material forming the basis of more advanced study, which may be applied and tested in later modules.  This module places such material into a patient context and within the legal frameworks governing the supply of medicines. A strong emphasis will be placed on the development of communication skills and patient management.

This module will further develop student knowledge and skills in evidence-based medicine, and its application to clinical practice. More detailed information on the design and management of clinical trials and post-marketing studies will be provided, along with their application to the assessment of efficacy, effectiveness, and safety. Principles of Health economics will also be taught. The common complementary alternative medicines systems will be taught within a framework of evidence-based medicine.

Further knowledge on the harm from medicines, error theory, and methods of preventing or mitigating such harms will be taught, and students will apply this knowledge to solve problem scenarios. Students will be introduced to the concept of clinical governance.

Students will also be taught basic principles of the use of drugs within veterinary practice with an emphasis on companion animals.

The teaching of law will continue, with examination of regulations concerning veterinary practice, complementary and alternative medicines, poisons, and drugs of abuse. Additional material on the professional regulation of pharmacy will be taught, alongside its relationship to other professional organisations within pharmacy and other professions. Students should expect to deal with more complex ethical considerations.


Assessment will reflect the applied and professional nature of this module using objective structured clinical examination (OSCEs) to demonstrate capability in communication, clinical and dispensing skills.

Written examinations will focus on the application of knowledge using a variety of applied written tasks, some details of which will be specified prior to the examination.

Coursework will include the critical appraisal of a scientific paper, set out as a presentation to a hospital or primary care organisation, and a written report analysing a medical error.

name: The Social Life of the Economy
description: What is the economy? In what sense can we distinguish it from other aspects of social life? How do we make sense of economic changes, and their effects on people around the world? This module asks fundamental questions about how humans produce, exchange, distribute and consume resources. After questioning what the economy is in the first place, we will explore topics such as money, commodities and gifts, seeking to explain what these things do in society. We will examine the different meanings of work in different places, and see how understandings of time lie at the heart of economic life.  The broad, comparative perspective of this module enables students to rethink capitalism itself, asking questions such as: What is the market? How can we best understand globalisation? What is the everyday, social life of global finance?

name: Theology and Religion Semester Abroad
description:
Students choose a host university which is:
1. Approved by the UoB International Office within the Study Abroad and Exchanges scheme, and
2. Deemed by the Departmental International / Year Abroad Officer to offer modules relevant to the students UoB degree programme and comparable with modules offered at UoB.
Students will spend a semester (normally the spring semester) of their second year at an approved overseas institution taking modules that are directly relevant to their Birmingham programme. The choice of modules is subject to the approval of the Departmental International / Year Abroad Officer.

name: Theoretical Meteorology: Atmospheric Composition and Physics
Thinking and Doing (Integrated Case Based Learning 6)
Threats and Defence (Integrated Case Based Learning 2)
Through Life Safety
description: This module addresses the safety issues that arise after system deployment, including safe management of operational systems; procedures required to maintain the safety of systems when maintenance or modification is required; and safety monitoring and advanced safety monitoring techniques. This module is run by the HISE group at the University of York.

name: Towards Urban Renaissance
description: This module provides an opportunity to explore the concept of community involvement in various aspects of the built environment. The idea of community involvement is not a new one that is currently in vogue. Recently, the many government documents that are emerging are advocating the importance of working with local communities in developing and delivering various policy initiatives. Regeneration is no exception. This module will examine the concept of community involvement in the built environment. It will look at what it means and critically examine why past attempts at involving local communities in the building and shaping of the urban environment have often failed. The module is designed to be highly participative in its nature. The teaching process has been set up to make full use of student contributions and to fully involve the participants in the actual learning process.

name: Trans-diagnostic Cognitive Behaviour Therapy for Complex Cases
description: The aims of this Module are for students to develop an understanding of some of the trans-diagnostic Cognitive Behavioural processes that are present in all mental health problems, and to devise highly individualised interventions based upon these principles.  Trans-diagnostic formulation and treatment can be helpful when a presentation is of such complexity that particular CB models are not sufficient to engage and treat the client, including cases with underlying personality disorder.\n

name: Transferable Skills for Postgraduate Students
description: From this module students will be able to enhance their transferable skills especially their communications skills and team working skills. The course is split into two parts. The first part is based in the University and deals with how to present data via a poster and verbal presentations. The second part based at the Priestley Centre in Coniston, concentrates on the development of team and interpersonal skills by participation in activities to encourage strategic, time, and project planning and management. The course is undertaken in a residential environment to facilitate the development of the team ethos, where the team are given progressively challenging scenarios which require team member participation through planning, delegation, team working and problem resolution for the achievement of the task. The tasks are under the responsibility of a facilitator (from the Centre for outdoor pursuits, and from School staff/nominees for the management games/challenges) and teams are each guided by an appointed mentor for the course duration. Teams participate in a debriefing after each half-day of the programme, for the recognition of achievements, and for the recognition of skills and attributes to transfer forward to future challenges.

name: Transforming Development for Sustainability
description:
With international concern escalating as a result of population growth, climate change, food price increases and land grabbing, the environmental challenges facing those living in the developing world become ever more complex, multifaceted and immediate. These challenges are encapsulated within the overarching concept of sustainable development. But, now well over 25 years since the concept was popularised in the 1987 Brundtland Report, just what has been achieved in the name of sustainable development? With climate change impacts becoming ever more apparent, the developing world faces considerable challenges in moving towards adaptation, with the developed world taking limited and slow action to reduce emissions, as noted by the World Bank's 'Turn Down the Heat' report in 2013.

This module introduces students to key concepts, literature and reports on a range of subjects and approaches to understanding how people in developing countries interact with the environment and what factors constrain and influence such interaction. The potential for, and limitations faced by, sustainable development are explored. Drawing on political science, economics and sociology, the module provides essential skills and knowledge for students wishing to gain a broad knowledge-base on environment and development issues for work with government, NGOs, research- and policy-related organisations in both the North and South. A one day visit to the Centre for Alternative Technology in Wales provides practical examples of technology available to support a shift towards a more sustainable future.

name: Transforming the Region: Economy, Society and Politics in the West Midlands in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries
description:
This module explores the history of the West Midlands in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries by focusing on aspects of the economic, political, social and cultural history of industrial areas such as Birmingham, the Black Country, the Ironbridge Gorge, the Potteries and Derwent Valley, established urban centres such as Derby, Lichfield, Shrewsbury and Worcester and the counties of Warwickshire, Worcestershire, Herefordshire, Staffordshire, Shropshire, Gloucestershire and Derbyshire. It aims to develop among students a sense of the region?s place and identity, and provide the necessary skills for further research in English regional and local history. The module is divided into three sections to coincide with the three Saturday schools which provide the vehicle for teaching. 
Urban and Rural Economic Change and Migration. This unit explores urban and rural economies with special focus on the regional urban `renaissance?, the extent of the agricultural revolution in the area and the different experiences of industrialisation in Birmingham, the Black Country and elsewhere in the region. This section also examines demographic dimensions of the West Midlands experience by looking at migration from within Britain and overseas and the creation of communities of, for example, Jews, Irish and Italians and the first Black people in the region.
Culture, Religion and Politics. The West Midlands witnessed the rise of an enlightenment culture in the eighteenth century which is best represented through the Lunar Society and other scientific and philosophical societies. The religious dimension will explore the experiences of Anglicanism and Roman Catholicism and the rise and impact of non-conformity. Political themes will trace, in particular, the emergence of Birmingham as a national centre for political reform and radicalism and the centre of the nineteenth century civic gospel. Issues of anti-slavery and gender in culture, religion and politics will also be addressed. 
Health, Welfare, Medicine and Education. This unit explores the social geography and experience of health, including public health and medicine and the rise of the hospital in the West Midlands. The application of the poor law and the provision of workhouses are also examined. The changing educational experience forms a feature of this section with a focus on charity schools and the rise of mass schooling, the development of grammar and public schools and institutions to teach those with disabilities, education for girls and women and the creation of the University of Birmingham.

name: Turmoil and Change: Economy, Politics and Society in the West Midlands in the Twentieth Century
description: The main aim of the module is to investigate the changes that occurred in the West Midlands region during the twentieth century. Some of the themes discussed in the module will be: ¿  The changing composition of the regional economy, in particular the rise and fall of large scale manufacturing and the permanence of small-scale family based firms ¿  The reasons and the impact of the changing racial mixture of the region ¿  The changes that have taken place in the socio-political configuration of the region's communities

name: Understanding School Improvement
description: This module will provide you with a rigorous, theoretically and evidence informed, view of effects of teaching and school organisation on students' learning. It will enable you to judge the extent to which claims for preferring one approach to another can currently be justified by available evidence whilst also providing a basis for developing your own practise and supporting the development of others and the institution in which you work. The module review effects of teaching on a range of outcomes including attainment, inclusion and aspirations.

name: Urban Encounters: Anthropology in Birmingham
description: This module takes key anthropological concepts and themes in the study of urban environments and asks how we might apply them in order to gain a deeper understanding of the city of Birmingham. Through lectures and seminar readings, students will be introduced to anthropological approaches to topics such as immigration, religious belief, consumption practices, street art, popular culture, inequality, multiculturalism, or food, and will be encouraged to apply an anthropological lens to such topics in the city in which they are studying.

name: Urban Poverty and Development
description:
The course aims to introduce the central issues and policies in relation to processes of urbanization and urban development in the south.  In particular it aims to:
1. Address the nature of urban growth and development in the south
2. Outline the dimensions of urban poverty 
3. Analyse the range of policy options available to confront urban poverty 
4. Critically assess the above range of options and the role of international agencies and national governments

name: Urban Regeneration and Renewal
description: This module provides an introduction to the dynamics of the urban economy and urban poverty.  It considers the government response to these issues in terms of its poverty strategies, urban regeneration activity and urban renewal.   This will be done by exploring the development of policy and by undertaking a critical examination of the operation of specific tensions between central and local government and the role that other agencies play in the process.  The module is practically focused and will involve the examination of regeneration and renewal practice on the ground.

name: Using Evidence in School Improvement
description: This module will enable you to take a constructive and critical view of evidence relevant to professional practice in pursuit of school of improvement. It will also equip you to undertake research in professional contexts which is directed towards improving school outcomes. Particular attention will be paid to the scope for using randomised controlled trials to investigate the effects of different approaches to school organisation and teaching. The module will also provide a basis for the design, implementation and evaluation of the work you undertake for your dissertation.

name: Values, Diversity and Context
description: PWPs must be able to respond to people's needs sensitively with regard to all aspects of diversity. They must demonstrate a commitment to equal opportunities for all and encourage people's active participation in every aspect of care and treatment. They must also demonstrate an understanding and awareness of the power issues in professional / patient relationships and take steps in their clinical practice to reduce any potential for negative impact this may have. This module will, therefore, expose PWPs to the concept of diversity, inclusion and multi-culturalism and equip workers with the necessary knowledge, attitudes and competencies to operate in an inclusive values driven service.\nPWPs must be able to manage caseloads, operate safely and to high standards and use supervision to aid their clinical decision-making. PWPs need to recognise the limitations to their competence and role and direct people to resources appropriate to their needs, including step-up to high-intensity therapy, when beyond their competence and role. In addition, they must focus on social inclusion – including return to work and meaningful activity or other occupational activities – as well as clinical improvement.

name: Weather, Climate and Society
description: The module is designed to make students familiar with basic aspects of mid-latitude weather (observations, analysis, forecasts), and the way operational information will be used for benefit for society. This will include interfaces between scientific knowledge and end users in economy and society on climate scales. Specific applications will be highlighted: the potential of wind and solar power; the cost/benefit of the use of weather information by industry; understanding of climate variability; the two way relationship between climate and society and the methods of climate impact assessment.

name: Why we eat what we eat: a psychological perspective on appetite
Wider Perspectives in Practice
description: The module gives students the opportunity to explore physiotherapy provision within non-standard contexts of practice.  Students will undertake some initial university-based learning where consideration of the diversity of healthcare services within the UK will enable a comparison with international health care systems. This will include exploring the contribution of independent, 3rd sector and non-governmental organisations to population health and well-being. Professional issues addressing implications of working in such settings will be considered, such as developing cultural competence, managing risk, blurred professional boundaries and multiagency working. Students will have the opportunity to select a setting to undertake such a non-standard practice placement experience as a 4 week elective, organised by themselves. This will be followed by a full time 5 week standard placement giving students the opportunity to critically evaluate the diversity of skills necessary for practising as a registered physiotherapist with a developing awareness of the future potential of physiotherapy provision.

name: Work Based Continuing Professional Development
description:
This module is designed to facilitate M level learning in the workplace. It enables students to identity an aspect of learning pertinent to their professional development within their current professional role, and to plan and carry out independent study of that learning with subsequent evaluation of its effectiveness. The area of practice development will be decided through negotiation with the academic tutor.  Examples might include:
Support and mentorship of more junior staff, (for physiotherapists seeking CSP Accreditation for Clinical Educator Status this may include mentorship of undergraduate and pre-registration PG students).
Management of a client/service-user caseload.
Participation in an established/setting up a new in-service education programme.

name: Working with Offenders
description: Managing DangerousnessThe `What Works' approachTreatment of Violent OffendersTreatment of Sexual OffendersTreatment of Offenders with Learning Disabilities/ Major Mental IllnessTreatment of Psychopathy/ Personality Disordered OffendersWorking with Young OffendersWorking with WomenIndividual and Group-work with OffendersCognitive Skills Training and Behavioural Self-Control

name: Working with Organisations and Communities
description: The module aims to introduce the psychology underpinning behaviour in organisations and groups and its application to educational institutions to effect and understand change.Students will have the opportunity to study how organisations are structured according to their purpose, and the wider influences that can affect its effectiveness.  They will also have the opportunity to observe and conduct initial analyses of educational institutions at first hand through supervised professional practice.Methods of data collection including observation and ways of intervening through collaborative action research will be considered.

name: Year 2 Hospital Preparation Course
description: The year 2 Hospital Preparation Course is designed to help students make an effective transition to hospital-based clinical learning.  Prior to year 3 students spend the majority of their time at the university.  From year 3 onwards students spend most of their time in hospital.  This requires students to acquire a new set of learning strategies and skills.  Historically many students have struggled in making this adjustment, and have made a slower than may be hoped start to year 3.  This component aims to help students understand what is required of them and introduce them to their placement hospital.  Students then have the summer break to reflect on the experience.  When they return it will be to a place they know, and this should help reduce anxiety.This placement also ensures students have a thorough induction to their first placement, including such things as fire training and data protection.

name: Year 2 Portfolio
description: Students will record and reflect on their personal and professional development through their personal ePortfolio. This required component in year two builds on the ePortfolio from year 1 and continues through the entire MPharm course as essential preparation for the lifelong learning and continuing professional development. Pharmacy students must continue to demonstrate engagement with this process. Students will be supported through face-to-face contact with academic and practice based pharmacy professionals together with online multimedia, to develop their reflective practice through engagement in reflective learning tasks linked to their professional experience placements and modules. Students should be able to demonstrate progress against outstanding learning needs identified at the end of year1.

name: Year 3 Portfolio
description: Students will record and reflect on their personal and professional development through their personal ePortfolio. This required component in year three develops previous ePortfolio work and continues through the fourth/ fifth year of the MPharm course as essential preparation for the lifelong learning and continuing professional development. Pharmacy students must continue to demonstrate engagement with this process. Students will be supported through face-to-face contact with academic and practice based pharmacy professionals together with online multimedia, to develop their reflective practice through engagement in reflective learning tasks linked to their professional experience placements and modules.

name: Year 3 Professional Development Activities
description:
The Professional Development Activities (PDA) required component of MBChB 3 is designed to build on the structured professional development which students have gained throughout the first two years of their course. There is no summative assessment. Students will need to evidence due diligence in the PDA, measured by attendance registers and submission of a personal development form, in order to progress to MBChB 4. The PDA provides students at the end of their first full time year of clinical medicine with an opportunity to explore several key themes, which will operate as a menu which students can choose from.

First, students will update themselves on professional and legal guidance which has been issued since they completed the formal teaching of these subjects in Year 2 of the course. This will emphasise the need for professionals to maintain their own professional learning requirements.

Second, providing guided independent study via e-learning will allow students to develop the skill of independent learning and professional development in a structured way, which will equip them for completely independent learning later in the course and throughout their career.

Third, students will select a skills workshop from an extensive list of choices. Some of these workshops cover challenging areas in clinical practice including interaction with patients lacking mental capacity, those with various beliefs and sexual orientation, and refugees.  This helps develop the talent of identify learning needs for future clinical years. In addition, they will have the opportunity to select a personal interest activity, from a list of choices, and get in contact with experts to comprehend how professional skills and attitudes can be fostered. These choices will be outside of those conventionally available in a standard medical curriculum such as learning from experts in military and sports medicine, and clinical managers.

Fourth, students will have the opportunity to spend 4-5 working days at schools interacting with pupils of age group 5-11years. This aims primarily at empowering and increasing students' confidence in interacting with children so that improving their interaction and communication in the clinical environment.

name: Year 4 Portfolio
description: Students will utilise the ePortfolio to demonstrate their progress and professional development at this stage of the course, through the process of recording and reflection. This required component in year four develops previous ePortfolio work.\nIn particular students will be expected to record and reflect on the ways in which they have used knowledge to deal with complex and unpredictable situations: showcasing examples where they have used initiative and taken personal responsibility and describing how they have developed the habit of independent learning required for their continuing professional development.\nThis required component in year four builds on the previous ePortfolio as essential preparation for the lifelong learning and continuing professional development. Pharmacy students must continue to demonstrate engagement with this process. Students will be supported through face-to-face contact with academic and practice based pharmacy professionals together with online directed tasks, to demonstrate their reflective practice through engagement in reflective learning tasks linked to their professional experience placements and modules.

name: Year 5 Student Assistantship
description: All medical students who remain in the UK after graduation will begin their medical career as a Foundation Grade doctor.  The transition from being medical students to foundation doctors can be a cause for considerable anxiety, and one for which students will not have invested enough practical thought, as they will, right until the final examinations be engaged in learning that helps them pass the MBChB, rather than specifically focussing on learning for their first job.   This component takes place after the final exams, and pairs students with foundation doctors to allow the students the opportunity to gain a good insight into the role of the foundation doctor, but also to give the student the opportunity to reflect on their preparedness for the role, and to engage in any learning or practical skills development, which may not have been covered sufficiently for the individual student during the MBChB.
